sub-subparagraph.text: The 22nd Alcoholic Beverages District of Prince George’s County; or
Washington County; and

paragraph.text: In addition to item (3) of this subsection, in Montgomery County only to a holder of a Class H beer and light wine license that is issued for use on the premises of a restaurant located in the County.
A holder of a Class 7 micro–brewery license:

subparagraph.text: May brew and bottle malt beverages at the license location;
May obtain a Class 2 rectifying license for a premises located within 1 mile of the existing Class 7 micro–brewery location to bottle malt beverages brewed at the micro–brewery location only;

May contract with the holder of a Class 5 brewery license, a Class 7 micro–brewery license, or a Class 2 rectifying license held under § 2–203 of this subtitle or the holder of a nonresident dealer’s permit to brew and bottle malt beverages on their behalf;

May store the finished product under an individual storage permit or at a licensed public storage facility for subsequent sale and delivery to a licensed wholesaler, an authorized person outside this State, and for shipment back to the micro–brewery location for sale on the retail premises;
May not collectively brew, bottle, or contract for more than 22,500 barrels of malt beverages each calendar year; and
May enter into a temporary delivery agreement with a distributor only for delivery of beer to a beer festival or wine and beer festival and the return of any unused beer if:

sub-subparagraph.text: The beer festival or wine and beer festival is in a sales territory for which the holder does not have a franchise with a distributor under the Beer Franchise Fair Dealing Act; and
The temporary delivery agreement is in writing.

paragraph.text: A Class 7 licensee who wishes to produce more than the barrelage authorized under paragraph (1)(v) of this subsection shall divest of any Class B, D, or any other retail license and obtain a Class 5 manufacturer’s license.

For the purposes of determining the barrelage limitation under paragraph (1)(v) of this subsection, any salable beer produced under contractual arrangements accrues only to the Class 7 micro–brewery licensee who is the brand owner.
In Allegany County only, the holder of a Class 7 license:

subparagraph.text: May brew in one location and may contract for the bottling of the malt beverage in another location; and
Need not meet the hotel/motel requirements for a Class B beer, wine and liquor licensee but shall meet the requirements for those Class B restaurants.

paragraph.text: The on–sale privilege authorizes the holder, each calendar year, to sell at retail up to 4,000 barrels of beer brewed under this license to customers for consumption on the licensed premises.
The off–sale privilege authorizes the holder to sell and deliver beer brewed under this license to:

subparagraph.text: Any wholesaler licensed under this article to sell beer in this State; or
Any person who is located in a state other than Maryland who is authorized under the laws of that state to receive brewed beverages.
This paragraph applies only in:

sub-subparagraph.text: Allegany County;
The City of Annapolis;
Anne Arundel County;
Baltimore City;
Baltimore County;
Calvert County;
Carroll County;
Charles County;
Dorchester County;
Frederick County;
Garrett County;
Harford County;
Howard County;
Kent County;
Montgomery County;
Prince George’s County;
Talbot County;
Washington County;
Wicomico County; and
Worcester County.

subparagraph.text: The holder may sell at retail beer brewed under this license to customers for consumption off the licensed premises in refillable containers that are sealed by the micro–brewery licensee at the time of each refill.

subsection.text: A holder of a Class 7 micro–brewery license:

paragraph.text: May not own, operate or be affiliated with any other manufacturer of beer except for a Class 2 rectifying license authorized by subsection (c)(1)(ii) of this section; and
Notwithstanding § 2–201(b) of this subtitle, may not be granted a wholesale alcoholic beverages license.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the hours and days for consumer sales under a Class 7 micro–brewery license are as established for:

subparagraph.text: A Class B license in the respective jurisdictions listed in subsection (b)(2) of this section, for a holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor license;
A Class D beer license in Worcester County, for a holder of a Class D beer license in the Town of Berlin in Worcester County; or
A Class D license in Kent County.

paragraph.text: For Class D licensees in the 22nd Alcoholic Beverages District in Prince George’s County only, the hours and days for consumer sales under this license are as established for a Class D license in Prince George’s County.
For Class D licensees in Washington County, the hours and days for consumer sales under this license are as established for a Class D license in Washington County.

subsection.text: In Montgomery County, a holder of a Class 7 micro–brewery license shall enter into a written agreement with the Department of Liquor Control for Montgomery County for the sale and resale of malt beverages brewed under this license in accordance with this article.

For Talbot County, the Office of the Comptroller of Maryland shall specify which local license is the equivalent of the Class B beer, wine and liquor license specified in subsection (b)(3) of this section.
In Carroll County, the distance restriction requirement for micro–breweries is found in § 9–207 of this article.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Washington County.

The Comptroller may not issue a Class 7 micro–brewery license for a premises on property that has been leased unless the landlord of the property presents to the Comptroller a receipt or certificate showing that there are no unpaid taxes due to the State, a county, or any local government from the landlord or any entity in which the landlord has a direct or indirect interest that:

subparagraph.text: Is proprietary; or
Has been obtained by a loan, mortgage, or lien, or in any other manner.

paragraph.text: There is a Class 8 farm brewery license.

Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, a Class 8 farm brewery license allows the licensee to sell and deliver beer manufactured in a facility on the licensed farm or in a facility other than one on the licensed farm to:

subparagraph.text: A wholesaler licensed to sell and deliver beer in the State; or
A person in another state authorized to acquire beer.

paragraph.text: The beer to be sold and delivered under paragraph (2) of this subsection shall be manufactured with an ingredient from a Maryland agricultural product, including hops, grain, and fruit, produced on the licensed farm.
A Class 8 farm brewery may be located only at the place stated on the license.
Notwithstanding any local law, a licensee may exercise the privileges of a Class 8 farm brewery license.
A licensee may:

subparagraph.text: Sell beer produced by the licensee for consumption on the licensed farm;
In an amount not exceeding 6 fluid ounces per brand, provide samples of beer that the licensee produces to a consumer:

sub-subparagraph.text: At no charge; or
For a fee; and

subparagraph.text: Sell or serve:

sub-subparagraph.text: Bread and other baked goods;
Chili;
Chocolate;
Crackers;
Cured meat;
Fruits (whole and cut);
Salads and vegetables (whole and cut);
Hard and soft cheese (whole and cut);
Ice cream;
Jelly;
Jam;
Vinegar;
Pizza;
Prepackaged sandwiches and other prepackaged foods ready to be eaten;
Soup; and
Condiments.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsections (d) and (e) of this section, a licensee may exercise the privileges of the license each day during the following times:

subparagraph.text: From 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., for consumption of beer and sales and service of food at the licensed farm; and
From 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., for:

sub-subparagraph.text: Sampling of beer;
Consumption of beer off the licensed farm if the beer is packaged in sealed or resealable containers, such as growlers; and
Guests who attend a planned promotion event or other organized activity at the licensed farm.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a Class 8 farm brewery license allows the licensee to operate 7 days a week.

In Garrett County, a licensee may open on Sundays during the hours allowed under § 11–512(c)(3) of this article to engage in the activities listed in paragraph (3) of this subsection only in an election district where the voters, in a referendum authorized by law, have approved Sunday sales at a farm.

paragraph.text: Except as provided under subsection (d) of this section, a licensee may not sell or allow to be consumed at the location of the farm brewery any alcoholic beverage other than the beer produced by the licensee under the authority of this section.
Nothing in this subsection limits the application of relevant provisions of Title 21 of the Health – General Article, and regulations adopted under that title, to a licensee.

subsection.text: The place listed on the Class 8 farm brewery license shall be in compliance with § 9–103 of this article.
A licensee may:

paragraph.text: Store on its licensed farm, in a segregated area approved by the Comptroller, beer produced at the licensed farm for sale and delivery to a wholesaler licensed in the State or a person outside of the State authorized to acquire the beer;
Brew, bottle, or contract for not more than 15,000 barrels of beer each calendar year;
Contract with the holder of a Class 5 brewery license or a Class 2 rectifying license to brew and bottle beer from ingredients produced on the licensed farm;
Import, export, and transport its beer in accordance with this section; and

Store beer at a warehouse for which the licensee has been issued an individual storage permit, for sale and delivery to a wholesaler licensed in the State or a person outside of the State authorized to acquire the beer, or shipment back to the licensed farm, if:

subparagraph.text: The licensee does not serve or sell beer at the warehouse; and
The Comptroller has full access at all times to the warehouse to enforce this article.

paragraph.text: A licensee may sponsor a multibrewery activity at the licensed farm that:

subparagraph.text: Includes the products of other Maryland breweries; and
Provides for the sale of beer by the glass for consumption on the premises only.

paragraph.text: In a segregated area approved by the Comptroller on the licensed farm, a licensee may store the products of other Maryland breweries for the multibrewery activity.
The multibrewery activity:

subparagraph.text: May be held from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. each day; and
May not exceed 3 consecutive days.

paragraph.text: The Office of the Comptroller may issue a special brewery promotional event permit to a licensee.

At least 15 days before holding a planned promotional event, the licensee shall obtain a permit from the Comptroller by filing a notice of the promotional event on the form that the Comptroller provides.
The permit authorizes the licensee to conduct at the licensed farm a promotional event at which the licensee may:

subparagraph.text: Provide samples of not more than 6 fluid ounces per brand to consumers; and
Sell beer produced by the licensee to persons who participate in the event.

paragraph.text: The beer at the event shall be sold by the glass and for consumption on the premises only.
The licensee may not be issued more than 12 permits in a calendar year.
A single promotional event:

subparagraph.text: May be held from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. each day; and
May not exceed 3 consecutive days.

paragraph.text: The permit fee is $25 per event.
The annual fees for the following classes of wholesaler’s licenses are:
Upon approval of the application:

subparagraph.text: A Class 1 wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of beer, wine and liquor upon the payment of an additional fee of $2,000 for each additional location.
A Class 2 wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of wine and liquor upon the payment of an additional fee of $1,750 for each additional location.
A Class 3 wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of beer and wine upon the payment of an additional fee of $1,500 for each additional location.
A Class 4 wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of beer upon the payment of an additional fee of $1,250 for each additional location.
A Class 5 wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of wine upon the payment of an additional fee of $1,250 for each additional location.
A Class 6 limited wine wholesale licensee may use additional locations for the warehousing, sale and delivery of wine upon the payment of an additional fee of $50 for each additional location.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a wholesaler’s license issued in accordance with the fee paid entitles the holder to acquire the alcoholic beverages indicated on the license from licensees and holders of nonresident dealer’s permits and resident dealer’s permits authorized by this State to make the sales and deliveries. The license authorizes the sale and delivery of those alcoholic beverages from the licensed premises to licensees and permit holders in Maryland and to persons outside of this State.
A Class 6 limited wine wholesaler’s license shall be issued only to a wine manufacturer that:

subparagraph.text: Produces not more than 27,500 gallons of its own wine annually; and
Holds a Class 4 limited winery manufacturer’s license issued under this article.

paragraph.text: A person who holds a Class 6 limited wine wholesaler’s license, on approval of the application and payment of the fee:

subparagraph.text: May sell and deliver its own brand of wine produced at the licensee’s premises to a retail licensee or permit holder in the State authorized to acquire the wine; and
May not sell its wine to a licensed wholesaler.

paragraph.text: In Allegany County the holder of a Class 1 or Class 2 wholesaler’s license may not sell liquor in any size container smaller than 23 ounces or 680 milliliters to any holder of a special permit issued under § 7–101(h) of this article.

A wholesaler’s license of the appropriate class authorizes the holder to directly import beer, wine, or distilled spirits from sources outside the continental limits and possessions of the United States. However, any wholesale licensee that imports for subsequent distribution in or outside the State of Maryland shall be:

subparagraph.text: The brand owner;
A wholesale licensee that purchases directly from the brand owner or the authorized agent of the brand owner; or
A wholesale licensee that purchases from the authorized United States importer.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (5) of this subsection only applies if the wholesale licensee’s jurisdiction and authority to sell has been submitted to the Comptroller by the brand owner.

subsection.text: The holder of a Class 1, Class 2 or Class 3 wholesaler’s license, upon approval of application and the payment of the fee, may obtain more than one such license provided separate records are kept.

Delivery from a truck or vehicle under the exclusive control of the holder of a wholesaler’s license of beer previously purchased by and delivered to the license holder constitutes delivery from his place of business within the meaning of this section.

Delivery from a truck or vehicle under the exclusive control of the holder of a wholesaler’s license of wine or a wine–based beverage constitutes delivery from the wholesaler’s place of business within the meaning of this section if:

paragraph.text: The wholesaler has a license to sell wine; and
The wine or wine–based beverage has an alcoholic content by volume of 6.5 percent or less.
This subsection does not apply to a nonresident winery permit holder.
Before any sale and delivery to a retail licensee, any alcoholic beverages acquired by a wholesaler from any source shall first come to rest on the licensed premises of the wholesaler.
This subsection applies in Montgomery County.

The Department of Liquor Control may sell its inventory through county liquor dispensaries at wholesale and retail and through retail outlets operated by individuals with whom the Department contracts under § 15–203(d) of this article.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, this article may not be interpreted to prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages in whole cases or in individual bottles by the director of the Department of Liquor Control, through county liquor dispensaries selling at wholesale or retail, to a licensee in Montgomery County.
The Department of Liquor Control may not sell alcoholic beverages at different prices to different licensees or classes of licensees.

subsection.text: An individual applicant, an applicant qualifying as a resident applicant for a corporation, or each applicant for a partnership applying for a manufacturer’s or wholesaler’s license shall have been a resident of this State for 2 years immediately preceding the filing of the application.

Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a holder of a manufacturer’s or wholesaler’s license may not sell or deliver alcoholic beverages to any person in this State other than a licensee or permit holder, except as provided in § 7–101(c) of this article.

Nothing in this section prevents a holder of a Class 4 limited wine manufacturer’s license and a Class 6 limited wine wholesaler’s license from holding a license issued under the authority of Title 4, Subtitle 2 of this article.
In addition to any license fee otherwise required under this article:

paragraph.text: An applicant for initial issuance of a license issued by the Comptroller under Subtitle 2 or 3 of Title 2 of this article shall pay to the Comptroller a nonrefundable application fee of $200; and
An applicant for renewal of a license issued by the Comptroller under Subtitle 2 or 3 of Title 2 of this article shall pay to the Comptroller a renewal fee of $30.

subsection.text: The application and renewal fees required under this section do not apply to a license for which a license fee is not otherwise required under this article.

paragraph.text: A Class A beer license shall be issued by the license issuing authority of the county in which the place of business is located. The holder of the license may keep for sale and sell beer at retail in any quantity to any consumers at the place described in the license. The holder shall deliver the beer in a sealed package or container, which may not be opened nor its contents consumed on the premises where sold.
The annual fee for the license shall be paid to the local collecting agent before any license is issued, for distribution as provided.
In Allegany County the annual fee is $125.
The package or container may not be opened nor its contents consumed on any premises in which the licensee has any direct or indirect interest.

subsection.text: This section does not apply in Anne Arundel County.
This section does not apply in Baltimore City.
This section does not apply in Baltimore County.
In Calvert County the annual license fee is $150.
In Caroline County the annual license fee is $250.
In Carroll County the annual license fee is $100.
In Cecil County the annual license fee is $60.
This section does not apply in Charles County.
In Dorchester County the annual license fee is $200.
In Frederick County the annual license fee is $100.

paragraph.text: In Garrett County the annual license fee is $150.
A new-license issuing fee is an additional $150. The new-license issuing fee shall be paid in addition to the annual license fee.

subsection.text: This section does not apply in Harford County.
In Howard County the annual license fee is $150.
In Kent County the annual license fee is $150.

paragraph.text: In Montgomery County the annual license fee is $200.

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph (2), “establishment” means a bowling alley, billiard hall, or drugstore or a restaurant located within these businesses.

A license may not be issued to, or for use in conjunction with, or upon the premises of any establishment or for use upon any premises which has a door, archway, opening or other passageway providing direct public access to any establishment.

subsection.text: In Prince George’s County the annual license fee is $245.
In Queen Anne’s County the annual license fee is $250.
In St. Mary’s County the annual license fee is $200.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies in Somerset County.
The annual license fee for a 6 day license is $126.
The annual license fee for a 7 day license is $158.

A person may not hold a license under the provisions of this section upon any premises having any direct or indirect connection with any drug or pharmaceutical dispensing business, or other business establishments of a type commonly known as or referred to as drugstore.
In Talbot County the annual license fee is $25.
Section 18-101 of this article permits the Talbot County Council to provide for the retail alcoholic beverage laws for the county which, if enacted, supersede the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: In Washington County the annual license fee is $100.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies in Wicomico County.
The annual license fee for a six day license is $175.
The annual license fee for a seven day license is $275.

A person may not hold a license under the provisions of this subsection upon any premises having any direct or indirect connection with any drug or pharmaceutical, or other business establishments of a type commonly known as or referred to as drugstore.
This subsection applies in Worcester County.
The annual 6 day license fee is $225.
The annual 7 day license fee is $250.
The hours for sale are as provided in § 11-524 of this article.

A Class B license shall be issued by the license issuing authority of the county in which the place of business is located. The holder of the license may keep for sale and sell beer at retail at any hotel or restaurant at the place described in the license for consumption on the premises or elsewhere.
The annual fee for the license shall be paid to the local collecting agent before any license is issued, for distribution as provided.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to Allegany County.
This section does not apply in Anne Arundel County.
This section does not apply to Baltimore City.
This section does not apply to Baltimore County.
In Calvert County the annual license fee is $250.
In Caroline County the annual license fee is $250.
In Carroll County the annual license fee is $130.
In Cecil County the annual license fee is $75.
This section does not apply in Charles County.
In Dorchester County the annual license fee is $250.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Frederick County.
The annual license fee is $130.

subparagraph.text: The area of the licensed premises normally used as a restaurant for the preparation and consumption of food and beverages on the premises may occupy no less than 80 percent of the square foot area, except for recreational use premises such as bowling alleys and pool halls.

The provisions of this paragraph of this subsection do not apply to or affect any licensee that had a license on December 31, 1993, or to any person who has a permit for a building that was under construction on that date.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Garrett County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B beer license for use in:

subparagraph.text: A bona fide hotel, motel, or inn that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Accommodates the public;
Provides services ordinarily found in hotels, motels, or inns;
Is equipped with at least 10 bedrooms for public accommodation; and
Has a lobby with a registration and mail desk and seating facilities; or

subparagraph.text: A restaurant that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Has a seating capacity at tables, not including seats at bars or counters, for at least 20 persons; and
Can prepare and serve full–course meals for at least 20 persons at one seating.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue the license with or without a catering option.
A holder of a license without a catering option may sell beer for consumption on or off the licensed premises.

subparagraph.text: In addition to exercising the privileges stated in paragraph (4) of this subsection, a holder of the license with a catering option may keep for sale and sell beer for consumption at events that the holder caters off the licensed premises.
To exercise the catering option, a holder of a license:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall provide food if the holder provides beer at a catered event off the licensed premises; and
May exercise the catering option only during the hours and days that are allowed under the license.

paragraph.text: For a license without a catering option:

subparagraph.text: The issuing fee is $150; and
The annual fee is $150.

paragraph.text: For a license with a catering option:

subparagraph.text: The issuing fee is $250; and
The annual fee is $250.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: This section does not apply in Harford County.

paragraph.text: In Howard County the annual license fee is $150.
A restaurant as defined in § 1-102(a)(22) of this article may apply for a Class B beer license.

subsection.text: In Kent County the annual license fee is $300.

paragraph.text: In Montgomery County the annual license fee is $250.

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph (2), “establishment” means a bowling alley, billiard hall, or drugstore or a restaurant located within these businesses.

A license may not be issued to, or for use in conjunction with, or upon the premises of any establishment or for use upon any premises which has a door, archway, opening or other passageway providing direct public access to any establishment.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County the annual license fee is $365.

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County may not issue any Class B beer license with other than the privilege of selling beer for consumption on the licensed premises (on–sale only). However, licensees holding this class of license prior to July 1, 1975, who have been exercising the privilege of selling beer for consumption off the licensed premises may continue to exercise this privilege.

subsection.text: In Queen Anne’s County the annual license fee is $250.
This section does not apply to St. Mary’s County.
In Somerset County the annual license fee is $253.

paragraph.text: In Talbot County the annual license fee is $250.
Section 18-101 of this article permits the Talbot County Council to provide for the retail alcoholic beverage laws for the county which, if enacted, supersede the provisions of this article.

subsection.text: In Washington County the annual license fee is $50.

paragraph.text: In Wicomico County the annual license fee is $275.

subparagraph.text: This license may be issued only for a hotel or restaurant that has the average daily receipts from the sale of food for each month exceed the average daily receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages.
In calculating average daily receipts from the sale of food, an allocation of foodstuff contained in a mixed drink may not be included in average daily receipts from the sale of food.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies in Worcester County.
The annual six-day license fee is $275.
The annual seven-day license fee, applied countywide (exclusive of the tenth election district), is $350.
The annual seven-day license fee, for the tenth election district only, is $350.
The hours for sale are as provided in § 11-524 of this article.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Montgomery County.
In this section, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: For a Class H license, the annual license fee is $400.
For a Class H-TP license issued pursuant to subsection (g) of this section, the annual license fee is $400. A Class H-TP licensee may not be charged for such a license until May 1, 1998.

paragraph.text: The fee shall be paid before the license is issued.

subsection.text: Subject to § 9-102.2 of this article, a Class H beer license may be issued by the Board. It authorizes the licensee to keep for sale and sell beer at retail at any hotel or restaurant at the place described in the license, for consumption on the premises.

The license may not be issued to, or for use in conjunction with, or upon the premises of any restaurant located within a drugstore or for use upon any premises which has a door, archway, opening or other passageway providing direct public access to any drugstore.

paragraph.text: A Class H beer license may be issued for the use of a bowling establishment if the bowling establishment:

subparagraph.text: Has at least 24 lanes; and
Is equipped with automatic pin setters.

paragraph.text: The licensee may sell beer:

subparagraph.text: For on-premises consumption only; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ix) of this paragraph, capital investment of $500,000 for restaurant facilities not including the cost of the land, the building, or improvements that are not to the interior of a building on the licensed premises; and

The annual fee for a Class BWL–VLF license is $15,000.
The annual fee for a Class BWL–VLC license is $5,000.
The annual license fees shall be paid on May 1 to the Board.
An off–sale privilege is not conferred by a Class BWL–VLF license or a Class BWL–VLC license.

Beer, wine, and liquor purchased under a Class BWL–VLF license or a Class BWL–VLC license may be taken anywhere in a video lottery facility or on grounds controlled by the Class BWL–VLF licensee, as defined in the Class BWL–VLF license.

paragraph.text: A Class BWL–VLF license and a Class BWL–VLC license authorize:

subparagraph.text: The playing of music and dancing; and

The sale and providing of beer, wine, and liquor throughout the video lottery facility and grounds controlled by the Class BWL–VLF licensee during those days and hours that the video lottery facility is open for business.

paragraph.text: Class BWL–VLF and Class BWL–VLC licenses and licensees are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages not inconsistent with this subsection.

Any penalty or other sanction that is imposed for a violation of a regulation of the Board on the licensed premises of a Class BWL–VLC licensee shall apply to the concessionaire that the Board determines to be responsible for the violation.
This subsection applies only in Baltimore County.
The annual fee for a license is $1,500.

The area of the licensed premises normally used as a restaurant for the preparation and consumption of food and beverage on the premises may occupy no less than 80 percent of the square foot area. These occupancy requirements do not apply to or affect any present licensee having this license prior to December 31, 1966.
This subsection applies only in Calvert County.
The annual fee for a Class B license is:

subparagraph.text: $1,250, if the place of business remains open until midnight; or
$2,250, if the place of business remains open until 2 a.m.
There is a Class BR beer, wine and liquor license which authorizes licensees to sell beer, wine, and liquor in restaurants for on–sale consumption with meals only.
The annual license fee for each license is $500.
Hours and days for sale are those for other Calvert County Class B licensees.
In the 27th Legislative District of Calvert County, there is a Class BLX license for luxury–type restaurants.
The Class BLX license shall be applied for in the same manner as are other classes of licenses.
The license fee is $2,400.
A luxury–type restaurant shall be defined by the County Liquor Board.
To qualify for a Class BLX license, a restaurant shall have:

sub-subparagraph.text: A minimum capital investment of $500,000 for the dining room facilities and kitchen equipment, not including the cost of land, buildings, or leases; and
A seating capacity of at least 150 persons.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership, joint venture, association, or other person or combination of persons may not have a direct or indirect interest in any combination in more than 4 Class B and Class BLX licenses.

An indirect interest is presumed to exist between any combination of individuals, corporations, limited liability companies, partnerships, limited partnerships, joint ventures, associations, or other persons if any of the following conditions exist between them:

sub-subparagraph.text: A common parent company;
A franchise agreement;
A licensing agreement;
A concession agreement;
Dual membership in a chain of businesses commonly owned and operated;
A sharing of directors, stockholders, partners, or members, or a sharing of directors, stockholders, partners, or members of parents or subsidiaries;
Common direct or indirect sharing of profit from the sale of alcoholic beverages; or
A sharing of a common trade name, trademark, logo or theme, or mode of operation identifiable by the public.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Caroline County.
Bona fide hotels and restaurants, as defined by the Board of License Commissioners, may serve liquors, wines, and beers by the drink only and only upon the premises.
The annual license fee for a:

subparagraph.text: 6–day license is $1,000; and
7–day license is $1,250.
This subsection applies only in Carroll County.
In this subsection “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.
The annual license fee is $1,500 for a restaurant and $1,500 for a hotel.
This license may be issued to a bona fide hotel which:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is an establishment for the accommodation of the public providing service ordinarily found in hotels;

Is equipped with not fewer than 25 rooms, a lobby with registration and mail desk, seating facilities and a dining room which serves full–course meals at least twice daily and which has a regular seating capacity at tables (not including seats at bars or counters) for 50 or more persons; and
Is operated in facilities which are valued for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation at not less than $50,000.
This license may be issued to a restaurant which meets the following requirements and conditions:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Is open for business at least 5 days each week and serves at least 2 full–course meals each day Monday through Friday that it is open and at least 1 full–course meal each day it is open on Saturday and Sunday;
Has a regular seating capacity at tables (not including seats at bars or counters) for 50 or more persons; and
Is operated in facilities which are valued for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation at not less than $50,000.

In this subparagraph “premises” means an area inside the restaurant building where meals are prepared and served, and an area on the outside of the restaurant building that is approved in writing by the Board.

This license permits the sale of beer, wine, and liquor for on–premises consumption, the sale of beer for off–premises consumption on any day of the week, and, subject to subsubparagraph 3 of this subparagraph, the sale of wine for off–premises consumption on any day of the week.

A holder of the license may sell wine for off–premises consumption if the area used for the preparation and consumption of food and beverages occupies at least 90% of the total square footage of the licensed premises; and
The holder of the license may not sell more than six bottles of wine to an individual at one time.

subparagraph.text: Whenever application is made for licensing under this subsection for any new or improved building, the supervisor of assessments, at the request of the Board, shall assess the building and advise the Board of the valuation of the building for assessment and taxation purposes.

The valuation of the building for assessment and taxation purposes as set out in subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph does not affect or prohibit in any manner the renewal or transfer of any Class B license issued prior to May 1, 1979.
There is a Class BC license.
The Board may issue a Class BC restaurant or hotel and caterer’s (on– and limited off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license to an applicant:

sub-subparagraph.text: Who has a restaurant or hotel which meets the licensure requirements and conditions provided under this section; or

Who is a holder of a Class B hotel or restaurant (on– and off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license issued in Carroll County, if the holder surrenders the license to the Board before being issued a new license under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: The Class BC restaurant or hotel and caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to sell:

sub-subparagraph.text: Beer, wine and liquor, 7 days a week, on the restaurant or hotel premises for on–premises consumption;
Beer, 7 days a week, on the restaurant or hotel premises for off–premises consumption; and
Beer, wine and liquor, 7 days a week, at catered events held in Carroll County off the restaurant or hotel premises for on–premises consumption.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a license issued under this paragraph shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
The annual fee for a license issued under this paragraph is $250 more than the annual fee for a Class B hotel or restaurant (on– and off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license issued in Carroll County.

The holder of a license issued under this section may exercise the license privileges only during the hours and days that are permitted under this article for a Class B hotel or restaurant (on– and off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license issued in Carroll County.

Upon payment of an additional annual license fee of $250, the holder of a Class BR license has the privileges of the holder of a Class BC license specified in subparagraph (3)(iii)3 of this subsection, subject to the restrictions set forth in subparagraph (iv) of this subsection.

sub-subparagraph.text: There is a Class BR license.

In this paragraph, “premises” means an area inside the restaurant building where meals are prepared and served and an area on the outside of the restaurant building that is approved in writing by the Board.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $2,000.
The Board may issue a Class BR beer, wine and liquor license to an applicant who owns or operates a restaurant that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Serves at least one full–course evening dinner meal at least 5 days a week;
Is only open during the time meals are served;
Has a regular seating capacity at tables (not including seating at bars and counters) for 50 or more people; and
Is operated in facilities which are valued for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation at not less than $50,000.

subparagraph.text: Whenever an application is made for a Class BR license for a new or improved building, the Supervisor of Assessments, at the request of the Board, shall assess the building and advise the Board of the valuation of the building for assessment and taxation purposes.

A Class BR license authorizes the licensee to sell beer, wine and liquor, 7 days a week, on the premises of the restaurant for consumption with meals on the premises or for consumption on the premises pursuant to regulations adopted by the Board.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Cecil County.
The annual license fee is $750.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding the license quota provisions of § 8–208 of this article, the Board of License Commissioners may issue special Class B licenses known as Class BLX beer, wine and liquor on–sale restaurant licenses.
To qualify for a Class BLX on–sale license the restaurant shall have:

sub-subparagraph.text: A minimum capital investment of $450,000 for dining room facilities and kitchen equipment, which sum may not include the cost of land, buildings, or a lease; and
A minimum seating capacity of 100 persons.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class BLX license:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the licensed premises only;
May not sell alcoholic beverages for off–premises consumption; and
May serve alcoholic beverages:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Monday through Saturday during the hours and days authorized under a Class B beer, wine and liquor license; and
On Sunday as provided under § 11–508 of this article without paying an additional fee.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for a Class BLX license is $2,500.
There is a Class EF (entertainment facility) beer, wine and liquor license.

A Class EF license authorizes the holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor by the drink and by the bottle, from one or more outlets in the entertainment facility, for consumption anywhere within the entertainment facility.
A holder of a Class EF license may not sell alcoholic beverages for off–sale consumption.

Notwithstanding § 8–208(b) of this article, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class EF license if the applicant has a capital investment in the facility for which the license is sought, not including any real property, of at least $35,000,000.
The Board may issue one or more Class EF licenses for the same facility.
A Class EF license authorizes the playing of music and dancing.
A Class EF license authorizes the sales and serving of beer, wine, and liquor throughout the entertainment facility during those days and hours that the entertainment facility is open for business.
The annual license fee is $7,500.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Charles County.
The annual license fee is $360.
This license shall provide for the consumption of beer, wine and liquor on the premises only.

subparagraph.text: There is in addition to the classes provided for, a special Class B license known as a Class BLX, which is issued only to luxury–type restaurants.
The Class BLX license shall be applied for in the same manner as are other classes of licenses.
The license fee is $2,400.
A luxury–type restaurant shall be defined by the Board of License Commissioners.
To qualify for a Class BLX license a restaurant shall have:

sub-subparagraph.text: A minimum capital investment of $550,000 for the dining room facilities and kitchen equipment, not including the cost of land, buildings, or leases; and
A seating capacity of at least 150 persons.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, limited partnership, joint venture, association, or other person or combination of persons may not have a direct or indirect interest in any combination in more than 6 Class B–BLX licenses.

An indirect interest is presumed to exist between any combination of individuals, corporations, limited liability companies, partnerships, limited partnerships, joint ventures, associations, or other persons if any of the following conditions exist between them:

sub-subparagraph.text: A common parent company;
A franchise agreement;
A licensing agreement;
A concession agreement;
Dual membership in a chain of businesses commonly owned and operated;
A sharing of directors, stockholders, partners, or members, or a sharing of directors, stockholders, partners, or members of parents or subsidiaries;
Common direct or indirect sharing of profit from the sale of alcoholic beverages; or
A sharing of a common trade name, trademark, logo or theme, or mode of operation identifiable by the public.
In this paragraph, “guest” means a person whose name and address appear on the registry that is maintained by the establishment and who is an occupant of a sleeping room in the establishment.
“Guest” does not include a person who is registered only for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages.

subparagraph.text: There is a special Class B–B&B (bed and breakfast) on–sale beer, wine, and liquor license.
The Board may issue a Class B–B&B license.
To qualify for a Class B–B&B license, the applicant’s establishment:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall have rooms, excluding the resident management quarters, that the public, for consideration, may use for sleeping accommodations for a specified period of time; and
May not have dining facilities that are open to the general public.

subparagraph.text: A Class B–B&B licensee may sell beer, wine, and liquor only to guests for consumption on the licensed premises.
The annual license fees are:

sub-subparagraph.text: $25 for an establishment with one to five bedrooms; or
$50 for an establishment with six or more bedrooms.

subparagraph.text: The hours and days for sale under the license shall be in accordance with § 11–509 of this article.
An applicant for a Class B–B&B license shall meet all other qualifications to hold an alcoholic beverages license in the county.
The Board may adopt additional regulations consistent with this paragraph.
If the licensed premises ceases to be operated as a bed and breakfast establishment, the license is void.
There is a Class B–Stadium (baseball stadium) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a 7–day Class B–Stadium license to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The owner of any professional team franchise, whether the franchise is a partnership, corporation, or limited liability company; or
A private concessionaire that is under contract with the County or a professional baseball team franchise.

subparagraph.text: A Class B–Stadium license authorizes the holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor on the premises of a baseball stadium owned or operated by the County to individuals present at baseball games or other events held at the stadium.
Except as provided in subparagraph (v) of this paragraph, beer, wine, and liquor shall be served in plastic, styrofoam, or paper containers on the stadium premises.
Beer, wine, and liquor may be served in glass containers in an enclosed stadium dining area in which patrons are seated.
A patron:

sub-subparagraph.text: May consume and carry beer and wine anywhere on the stadium premises; but
May consume liquor only in the enclosed stadium dining area or bar; and
May not carry liquor out of the enclosed stadium dining area or bar.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for the Class B–Stadium license is $2,200.

Except for a distributor of beer who is conducting business with a holder of a Class B–Stadium license for the purposes of this paragraph, the holder may not allow any individual to carry alcoholic beverages onto or from the licensed premises.
The Board of License Commissioners may adopt additional regulations consistent with this paragraph relating to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The manner of dispensing alcoholic beverages;
The number of outlets authorized to dispense alcoholic beverages; and
The hours and days of sale of alcoholic beverages.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Dorchester County.

subparagraph.text: Bona fide restaurants, motels and hotels having restaurant facilities for serving full–course meals at least twice daily and seating capacity at tables for 50 or more persons, not including seats at bars or counters, may obtain a license from the Board of License Commissioners. This license entitles the licensee to sell beer, wines, and liquors.
The annual license fee is $1,000.

paragraph.text: This license provides for the consumption of beer, wine, and liquor on the premises only.
This subsection applies only in Frederick County.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $1,500 for a restaurant and $2,000 for a hotel.

Any hotel meeting the minimum requirements of subsection (a)(3) of this section may elect to be issued a license under that subsection, or any bona fide hotel may elect to be issued a license under this subsection if it:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is an establishment for the accommodation of the public providing service ordinarily found in hotels;

Is equipped with not fewer than 25 rooms, a lobby with registration and mail desk, seating facilities and a dining room which serves full–course meals at least twice daily and which has a regular seating capacity at tables (not including seats at bars or counters) for 50 or more persons; and

Is operated in a physical plant which has a valuation for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation of not less than $20,000 and which has a valuation of personal property for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation of not less than $3,000. This license in a hotel does not permit sales at bars or counters, or sales for consumption anywhere except on the premises on which the meals are prepared and served.

subparagraph.text: This license may be issued to a restaurant which:

sub-subparagraph.text: Serves full–course meals at least twice daily;
Has a regular seating capacity at tables (not including seats at bars or counters) for 50 or more persons;

Is operated in a physical plant which has a valuation for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation of not less than $40,000 and which has a valuation of personal property for purposes of State and local assessment and taxation of not less than $5,000. This license in a restaurant permits sales for consumption on the premises on which meals are prepared and served, except in the case of beverages with an alcoholic content of not more than 14.5 percent by volume, which may be sold for off–premises consumption; and

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The area of the licensed premises normally used as a restaurant for the preparation and consumption of food and beverages on the premises may occupy no less than 80 percent of the square foot area, except for recreational use premises such as bowling alleys and pool halls.

The provisions of this sub–subparagraph of this subparagraph do not apply to or affect any licensee that had a license on December 31, 1993, or to any person who has a permit for a building that was under construction on that date.

sub-subparagraph.text: A restaurant issued a license under this subsection may remove its tables and chairs to accommodate additional patrons at not more than four special events held in the restaurant in a calendar year.
A restaurant that removes its tables and chairs for a special event:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Shall give notice to the Board of License Commissioners not less than 1 week before the event;
Shall store the removed tables and chairs in an appropriate location in the restaurant and in a manner that does not block the exits of the restaurant; and
May not allow into the restaurant more than the maximum number of occupants that the County Fire Marshal allows.

subparagraph.text: Any bona fide hotel or motel may obtain a special Class B (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license issued by the Board of License Commissioners providing:

sub-subparagraph.text: It is an establishment for the accommodation of the public providing services ordinarily found in bona fide hotels and motels;
It contains no less than 15 rooms;
It contains a dining room with facilities for preparing and serving full–course meals for at least 50 persons at one seating; and
The capital investment in the hotel or motel facility is not less than $400,000.
Subject to this special Class B license, sales of all alcoholic beverages may be by the individual drink at any place on the hotel or motel premises.

Sales of all alcoholic beverages may be by the bottle at any place on the premises for banquets, parties, hospitality rooms, meetings, and similar functions, and for dinners in the restaurant portion of the premises. However, the customer is not permitted to remove the unused portion of any such bottle from the premises.

Alcoholic beverages by the bottle may be sold through room service to bona fide registered patrons in the hotel or motel rooms. However, no more than two bottles may be sold through room service to any one patron in any 24–hour period. Bottles sold through room service may be removed from the premises by the patron upon checking out from the hotel or motel.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for this special Class B license is $2,000.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B–B.F. (Banquet Facility) beer, light wine and liquor on–sale license for a banquet facility that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Accommodates the public for banquets, parties, meetings, and similar functions;
Contains a dining room with adequate facilities for preparing and serving full–course meals for at least 100 persons at one seating;
Is eligible for inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places; and
Has a capital investment of not less than $500,000, excluding the cost of the land, buildings, and leases.

subparagraph.text: The Class B–B.F. beer, light wine and liquor license authorizes the holder to keep for sale, and sell at retail, beer, light wine, and liquor by the drink or by the bottle for on–premises consumption only; provided that:

sub-subparagraph.text: The beer, light wine, and liquor are only sold during the function;
The licensee may not sell alcoholic beverages for off–premises consumption;
The licensee may not permit alcoholic beverages to be carried off the premises; and
Food is furnished at the function where the alcoholic beverages are provided.

subparagraph.text: The days and hours of sale under this license are as provided in § 11–511 of this article.
The annual license fee for a Class B–B.F. license is $1,500.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special Class B–DT (Dinner Theater) on–sale beer, light wine and liquor license for the use of an establishment that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is operated as a dinner theater;
Provides live Broadway–style musicals, comedy, or drama to its customers;
Is open to the public by reservation only; and
Contains a dining room with facilities for preparing and serving full–course meals for at least 120 persons at one seating.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–DT license is authorized to sell at retail beer and light wine by the drink or by the bottle and liquor by the drink only for on–premises consumption beginning 2 hours before the live performance through the end of the performance on:

sub-subparagraph.text: Monday through Saturday; and
Sunday no sooner than 1 p.m.

subparagraph.text: The license does not authorize the holder to sell alcoholic beverages:

sub-subparagraph.text: For off–premises consumption by the drink or by the bottle; or
At any time except in conjunction with the dinner theater.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for a Class B–DT license is $1,500.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B–BB (bed and breakfast) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license for the use of an establishment that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Provides services ordinarily found in a bed and breakfast establishment; and
Contains at least one room with sleeping accommodations, excluding resident management quarters, that the public for consideration may use for a specified time.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–BB license may sell alcoholic beverages only:

sub-subparagraph.text: For consumption on the premises during the hours and days that are permitted for a Class B on–sale beer, wine and liquor license issued in the county; and
To a guest whose name and address appears on the registry that is maintained by the establishment and who is an occupant of a sleeping room in the establishment.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–BB license may not sell alcoholic beverages to a person who is registered at the establishment only to obtain alcoholic beverages.
The annual license fee is $500.
If an establishment ends operations as a bed and breakfast establishment:

sub-subparagraph.text: The Class B–BB license is voided; and
The holder shall return the Class B–BB license to the Board of License Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this paragraph.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B–CI (country inn) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license for the use of an establishment that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Provides services ordinarily found in a country inn establishment;
Contains at least eight rooms with sleeping accommodations, excluding resident management quarters, that the public for consideration may use for a specified time; and
Has a kitchen facility for guests that is separate from the kitchen facility of the resident management quarters.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–CI license may sell alcoholic beverages only:

sub-subparagraph.text: For consumption on the premises during the hours and days that are permitted for a Class B on–sale beer, wine and liquor license issued in the county; and
When accommodating the public for banquets, parties, meetings, and similar functions.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $2,500.
If an establishment ends operations as a country inn facility:

sub-subparagraph.text: The Class B–CI license is voided; and
The holder shall return the Class B–CI license to the Board of License Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this paragraph.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Garrett County.

subparagraph.text: A Class B beer, wine and liquor license may be issued for use in a bona fide hotel or motel that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is an establishment for the accommodation of the public;
Provides services ordinarily found in hotels or motels;
Is equipped with not less than 25 rooms; and
Has a lobby with a registration and mail desk and seating facilities.

subparagraph.text: A Class B beer, wine and liquor license may be issued to a restaurant that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Has a seating capacity at tables, not including seats at bars or counters, for 20 or more persons; and
Is capable of preparing and serving full–course meals for 20 or more persons at one seating.

subparagraph.text: Except at catered events, if the holder has the catering option, the holder is authorized to sell brewed beverages, as defined in this article, for off–premises consumption.

sub-subparagraph.text: If the holder has the catering option, this license also authorizes the holder to keep for sale and sell beer, wine, and liquor for consumption at events catered in the county by the licensee off the licensed premises.
If the licensee provides alcoholic beverages at a catered event off the licensed premises the holder shall also provide food.
The licensee may exercise the catering privileges only during the hours and days that are permitted under the Class B license.
The annual fee for a license with the catering option is $2,000 and the issuing fee for a new license is $2,000, in addition to the annual fee.
The annual fee for a license without the catering option is $1,500. The issuing fee for a new license is $1,500, in addition to the annual fee.

subparagraph.text: An application for a license under this subsection shall be denied if the Liquor Control Board determines that the business to be operated under this license will not enhance the recreational, business, and economical development within the county.

In this paragraph, “guest” means a person whose name and address appears on the registry that is maintained by the establishment and who is an occupant of a sleeping room in the establishment. “Guest” does not include a person who is registered solely for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages.

sub-subparagraph.text: There is a Class B–B&B license. The Board may issue a 7–day special Class B (bed and breakfast) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license.
To qualify for a license under sub–subparagraph 1 of this subparagraph:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The applicant’s establishment shall be registered by the county to operate as a bed and breakfast establishment;

The applicant’s establishment shall have rooms, excluding the resident management quarters, which the public, for consideration, may use for sleeping accommodations for a specified period of time; and
The establishment’s dining facilities may not be open to the general public.

sub-subparagraph.text: A holder of a Class B–B&B license may sell beer, wine, and liquor only to guests for consumption on the premises.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fees are:

sub-subparagraph.text: One to five bedrooms: $25;
Six to ten bedrooms: $50; and
Eleven or more bedrooms: $75.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall charge an issuing fee in an amount equal to the annual license fee.
A Class B–B&B license is an on–sale only license.
The days and hours of sale under this license shall be in accordance with § 11–512(b)(1) of this article.
An applicant shall meet all other qualifications to hold a license within the county. The Board may adopt additional regulations consistent with this paragraph.
If the establishment ceases to be operated as a bed and breakfast, the license is void.
In this paragraph, “resort” means a complex that has two or more facilities that are:

sub-subparagraph.text: Located on the same contiguous property;
Separated by at least 150 feet from the main area of the licensed premises; and
Determined by the Board of License Commissioners to be recreational, hotel, motel, or restaurant facilities.

subparagraph.text: The Board may issue a Class B–resort license.
A Class B–resort license authorizes the licensee to exercise the same privileges as a licensee of a regular Class B (on–sale) hotels and restaurants beer, wine and liquor license.
The annual license fees are:

sub-subparagraph.text: Two facilities, $3,000; and
Each additional facility, $1,500.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners shall charge an issuing fee for new licenses in an amount equal to the annual license fee.
The days and hours of sale under a Class B–resort license shall be in accordance with § 11–512 of this article.
An applicant shall meet all other qualifications to hold a license within the county.
The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations consistent with this paragraph.
There is a Class BDR (deluxe restaurant) beer, wine and liquor license, which is a Special Class B license.
A Class BDR license may be issued for a deluxe restaurant, as defined by the Board of License Commissioners.

Notwithstanding § 9–102(a) of this article, a Class BDR license may be issued to an applicant who already holds a Class B (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license or a Class B Resort (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
A Class BDR license may be issued only for the use of a restaurant with:

sub-subparagraph.text: A minimum seating capacity for 85 persons; and
A minimum capital investment of $250,000 for the restaurant facilities, not including the cost of land or buildings.

subparagraph.text: If an applicant purchases or leases an existing building, the capital investment attributable to the cost of the land and improvements shall be based on the assessed value of the land and improvements in accordance with the records of the Department of Assessments and Taxation at the time of purchase.
The annual license fee is $2,250.
The Board of License Commissioners shall charge a one–time issuing fee for a new license in an amount equal to the annual fee.

sub-subparagraph.text: A holder of a Class BDR license may acquire the same catering option that is described under paragraph (2)(iii) and (iv) of this subsection for Class B beer, wine and liquor licenses.
The annual catering option fee is $500.

subparagraph.text: The days and hours of sale under a Class BDR license are in accordance with § 11–512(b)(1) of this article.
The Board of License Commissioners may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this paragraph.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Harford County.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is:

sub-subparagraph.text: For a 6–day, Monday through Saturday, license:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: $1,720 for a restaurant; and
$2,260 for a hotel; and

sub-subparagraph.text: For a 7–day license:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: $2,145 for a restaurant; and
$2,685 for a hotel.

sub-subparagraph.text: The license permits the sale of liquor for consumption inside the premises only.
As to any 6– or 7–day restaurant or hotel license issued prior to July 1, 1984, beer and wine may be sold for consumption on– and off–sale pursuant to § 5–201(n) of this article.
As to any 6– or 7–day restaurant license issued on or after July 1, 1984, beer and wine may be sold for consumption on the premises only.
These licenses shall be issued by the Liquor Control Board.

subparagraph.text: This license may be issued to an applicant for a bona fide hotel which:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is an establishment for the accommodation of the public, providing services ordinarily found in hotels; and
Is equipped with no fewer than 25 rooms, a lobby with a registration and mail desk and seating facilities, and a dining room which serves full–course meals at least twice daily.
This license in a hotel permits sales at bars or counters, but not liquor, beer, or wine for consumption off the premises.
As to any such license issued prior to July 1, 1984, beer and wine may be sold for consumption on– and off–sale pursuant to § 5–201(n) of this article.

subparagraph.text: This license may be issued to an applicant for a restaurant which meets the following requirements and conditions:

sub-subparagraph.text: Serves full–course meals at least twice daily;
Has a regular seating capacity of tables, not including seats at bars or counters for 60 or more persons;

Has been in full–time operation as a restaurant for not less than 6 months immediately preceding the time the application is made for the license. However, the 6–month time period requirement does not apply to a licensee whose business has been disrupted or interrupted as a result of fire or other disaster; and
Has had daily average receipts from the sale of food in excess of sales of alcoholic beverages during the 6–month period immediately preceding the application for license.

There is a “Class B–3 restaurant/hotel license”, which may be issued by the Liquor Control Board to a licensee who has been operating his business establishment under the Class B beer, wine and liquor license for 1 year prior to the application for this license and who is, in the judgment of the Board, equipped and stocked for the continued regular sale of food to customers and guests and does at least 25 percent of his business in the sale of food.
The annual license fee:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: For a six–day, Monday through Saturday, license is $2,050 for a restaurant and $2,620 for a hotel.
For a seven–day license is $2,435 for a restaurant and $3,045 for a hotel.

sub-subparagraph.text: The restaurant or hotel may purchase liquor or spirituous beverages from licensed suppliers.
This subsection may not be construed to limit the powers of the Liquor Control Board to control the number of licensees under §§ 9–201 and 16–301 of this article.
This subsection may not contravene the provisions of §§ 10–103, 10–104, and 11–513 of this article, as the several sections may be amended from time to time.

subparagraph.text: Any Class B licensee who was granted an option that authorizes the sale of liquor off–sale as provided for in § 6–101(n) of this article shall pay the following additional fees:

sub-subparagraph.text: Six–day restaurant – $350; and
Seven–day restaurant – $450.

subparagraph.text: Any licensee who has been previously granted an option under the provision of § 6–101(n)(5) of this article shall apply that option only to the area described in the application and that area may not exceed 20 percent of the area normally used in the operation of the restaurant business. This area shall be separate and distinct from the restaurant seating area, unless sales are merely from behind the bar. The 20 percent area limitation does not apply to additions or extensions. If the application indicates that off–sale of liquor will be more extensive than from behind the bar, a separate outside entrance for the use of off–sale customers shall be provided.

Class B licensees who utilize this option shall meet all of the appropriate operating requirements stipulated in this subsection and § 5–201(n) of this article. However, for the purposes of meeting food sale requirements, off–sale liquor receipts may not be included in the calculation of sales.
There is a special Class B on–sale license known as Class BNR which may be issued only to newly opened restaurants that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Have a minimum capital investment of $250,000 for new dining room facilities and newly installed kitchen equipment, which sum may not include the cost of land, buildings, or a lease;
Comply with paragraph (2)(v)1 and 2 of this subsection; and
Are as further defined by the regulations of the Liquor Control Board.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $3,000.
The licensee may serve alcoholic beverages on Monday through Sunday and only between 8 a.m. and 2 a.m. the following morning.
The Liquor Control Board has complete discretion as to:

sub-subparagraph.text: The number of licenses to be issued; and
To whom these licenses shall be issued.

subparagraph.text: A BNR license is restricted to the purpose of providing alcoholic beverages for consumption on the licensed premises only and provides no off–sale privileges.

paragraph.text: Repealed.

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph, “guest” means an individual whose name and address appear on the registry that is maintained by the establishment.
The Liquor Control Board may issue a 7–day special Class B (inn) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license.
To qualify for the issuance or reissuance of a special Class B (inn) license, the establishment of the applicant or the special Class B (inn) license holder shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Be approved by the appropriate governing authority to operate as an inn;
Have a minimum of 11 rooms or suites, excluding the resident management quarters, which the public, for consideration, may use as guests for sleeping accommodations for a specified period of time;

Have a seated dining capacity of a sufficient size to accommodate overnight guests and dinner patrons who are participating in regular meals and special dinner events on the premises of the establishment as allowed under subparagraph (vi) of this paragraph; and
Have a kitchen facility that has been approved by the local governing authority.

The holder of a 7–day special Class B (inn) license may sell, only in conjunction with a meal, alcoholic beverages to guests for consumption on the premises during the days and hours established for a Class B on–sale beer, wine and liquor license for Harford County under this article.

The holder of a Class B (inn) license issued after March 6, 2006, may sell beer and wine from the dining room to guests for consumption off the premises, if the holder previously held a Class B (restaurant) license permitting sales of beer and wine for consumption off the premises.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for a 7–day special Class B (inn) license is:

sub-subparagraph.text: For an establishment that has 11 through 24 rooms or suites, $2,500; and
For an establishment that has 25 or more rooms or suites, $3,295.
The special Class B (inn) license authorizes the holder of the license to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Conduct special dinner events on the premises of the establishment;
Allow individuals who are not guests to patronize the establishment for regular and special dinner meals; and

Allow guests in buildings that are considered part of the inn establishment operation and are within a reasonable distance from the inn establishment to have alcoholic beverages delivered to them in sealed packages by the licensed inn establishment.

sub-subparagraph.text: For purposes of subsubparagraph 1C of this subparagraph, a building that is within a reasonable distance from the inn establishment means a building that is located within the same mail unit number as the inn establishment or is not more than one–eighth of a mile from the inn establishment.

subparagraph.text: At no time may alcoholic beverages in open containers be transferred, carried, taken, or delivered to, from, or between the inn establishment and other buildings that are considered part of the inn establishment operations.
The holder of a special Class B (inn) license may not sell alcoholic beverages to a person who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is not a guest or a patron of the dining facility of the establishment; or
Is a guest registered at the establishment only for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a special Class B (inn) license may serve alcoholic beverages to guests and dinner patrons on a patio, deck, terrace, or the grounds or other outdoor area that is an integral part of the premises of the inn establishment only with the prior approval of the Liquor Control Board.

sub-subparagraph.text: Subject to the requirement of subsubparagraph 2 of this subparagraph, the special Class B (inn) license authorizes the holder of the license to keep for sale and sell beer, wine, and liquor for on–premises consumption during catered events that are catered by the license holder at the inn establishment if the license holder is under contract to cater the event.
Food must be served at all catered events at the inn establishment at which alcoholic beverages are provided or sold.
At no time may an inn be operated solely for the purpose of selling or providing alcoholic beverages.
If an establishment ceases to be operated as an inn:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The 7–day special Class B (inn) license is void; and
The license holder shall return the license to the Liquor Control Board.

subparagraph.text: The Liquor Control Board shall adopt regulations to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Implement the provisions of this paragraph; and
Ensure that the primary purpose of the special Class B (inn) license is to allow the holder of the license to operate an establishment as an inn.

subparagraph.text: There is a 7–day Class B–BB (bed and breakfast) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license that may be issued by the Liquor Control Board.
To qualify for the issuance or reissuance of a Class B–BB license, the applicant’s or the Class B–BB license holder’s establishment, as appropriate, shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Provide services ordinarily provided by a bed and breakfast establishment;
Contain at least one room but not more than 10 rooms, each with sleeping accommodations, excluding resident management quarters, that the public for consideration may use for a specified time;
Be approved by the appropriate local government authority to operate as a bed and breakfast establishment; and
Have a kitchen facility that has been approved by the appropriate local government authority.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–BB license may sell alcoholic beverages only:

sub-subparagraph.text: For consumption on the premises during the hours and days that are allowed for a Class B on–sale beer, wine and liquor license issued in the county; and
To a guest whose name and address appears on the registry that is maintained by the establishment and who is an occupant of a sleeping room in the establishment.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class B–BB license may not sell alcoholic beverages to a person who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Is not a guest of the establishment; or
Is registered as a guest at the establishment only for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages.

Subject to the requirement of subsubparagraph 2 of this subparagraph, the Class B–BB license authorizes the holder of the license to keep for sale and sell beer, wine and liquor for on–premises consumption during catered events that are catered by the license holder at the bed and breakfast establishment if the license holder is under contract to cater the event.
Food must be served at all catered events at the bed and breakfast establishment at which alcoholic beverages are provided or sold.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee for a Class B–BB license is $1,000.

sub-subparagraph.text: At no time may a bed and breakfast establishment be operated solely for the purpose of selling or providing alcoholic beverages.
If an establishment ends operations as a bed and breakfast establishment:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: The Class B–BB license is void; and
The holder shall return the Class B–BB license to the Liquor Control Board.

subparagraph.text: The Liquor Control Board shall adopt regulations to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Implement this paragraph; and
Ensure that the primary purpose of the Class B–BB license is to allow the holder of the license to operate an establishment as a bed and breakfast establishment.

subparagraph.text: The Liquor Control Board may issue a special Class BFD (fine dining) on–sale beer, wine and liquor license.
The license authorizes the licensee to serve only full–course dinners at least 5 days a week.
A restaurant with a Class BFD license must open for business not later than 5 p.m. and comply with the requirements of § 1–102(a)(22)(iii) of this article.
The annual fees are:

sub-subparagraph.text: $2,500 for a 6–day license, Monday through Saturday; and
$2,900 for a 7–day license.

subparagraph.text: The Liquor Control Board shall adopt rules to carry out this subsection.

subsection.text: In Howard County the annual fee is $1,000.

subparagraph.text: This subsection applies only in Kent County.
In this subsection, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.
The Board may issue a Class B beer, wine and liquor license for use in a restaurant.
To qualify for licensure under this subsection, the restaurant shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Be fully equipped with a proper and adequate dining room;
Have sufficient facilities for preparing and serving meals to the public; and
Be approved by the Board.

subparagraph.text: When operating under this license, a holder’s average daily receipts from the sale of food shall comprise at least 60 percent of the average daily receipts of the business.
The annual license fee under this subsection is $2,000.
On Sunday, the holder is authorized under the license to sell:

sub-subparagraph.text: Beer, wine and liquor for consumption on–premises to a customer:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: If the customer is seated at a table and not at a bar or on a bar stool;
If the alcoholic beverage is a supplement to the customer’s meal; and
If the total price of the alcoholic beverages does not exceed the total price of the meal; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Only beer and light wine for consumption off the premises.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection, “guest” means a person whose name and address appears on the registry that is maintained by the establishment and who is an occupant of a sleeping room in the establishment. “Guest” does not include a person who is registered solely for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages.
