In this section, “caterer” means an establishment that owns or leases 1 or more banquet rooms suitable for public gatherings, with food preparation facilities on the premises, which contracts to provide food and alcoholic beverages to sponsors of public or private events.

A Class H beer, wine and liquor license may be issued upon the approval of the Liquor Control Board and authorizes the owner or operator of a catering establishment to keep for sale and sell all alcoholic beverages at retail at the premises described therein for consumption on the premises during the catered event.

Notwithstanding the provisions of § 12-107 of this article or any other contrary provision of this article, a caterer licensed under this section also may contract with patrons to permit them to bring personal alcoholic beverages onto the premises of the caterer for consumption at catered events.
A caterer licensed under this section may contract to provide alcoholic beverages at events held off the premises, provided that:

subparagraph.text: The caterer contracts to provide food, as well as alcoholic beverages, for consumption at the catered event; and
The event is held in Harford County.

paragraph.text: A caterer licensed under this section may provide food and keep and sell at retail alcoholic beverages, for consumption only on the premises of the caterer, at a self-sponsored event held once during a calendar year on a day selected by the caterer.

This section does not require a hotel or restaurant which presently holds a Class B beer, wine and liquor license to obtain a Class H license if catering is, or has been, a part of the service provided by the hotel or restaurant.

If a holder of an existing hotel or restaurant Class B beer, wine and liquor license provides catering services on or off the licensed premises, the holder is subject to the requirements of subsection (b)(3) of this section.

subsection.text: A beer, wine and liquor license may be issued to a caterer who has entered into an exclusive lease with a volunteer fire company for a banquet facility owned by that volunteer fire company.
This section applies only in Kent County.
The annual license fee is $100.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of:

paragraph.text: A Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license; and
A Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer and light wine license.

subsection.text: A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license or the Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer and light wine license premises.
The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.

A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are permitted in this article for a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license or a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer and light wine license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license or an existing Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer and light wine license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the existing license.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.

A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license premises.
The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are permitted in this article for a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the existing license.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.
There is a caterer’s (CAT) license.
The annual license fee is $1,250.
The hours and days during which the holder of a CAT license may exercise the privileges of the license are the same as for the holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor license.
The holder of a CAT license shall meet all the requirements of this article.

The holder of a CAT license shall have the facilities to prepare food and deliver food to the site of the catered affair. The county health department shall approve those facilities before the license may be issued, reissued, or renewed.

The holder of a CAT license shall contract for and provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at catered events. The holder may not provide only alcoholic beverages at a catered event. The holder shall meet the same ratio of gross receipts between food sales and alcoholic beverage sales as a holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor license.
An applicant for a CAT license need not have a banquet hall. Persons holding existing licenses are not eligible for a CAT license. A CAT license is a separate alcoholic beverages license.
The holder of a CAT license may not hold any self-sponsored events and may only hold off-sale events.
The holder of a CAT license shall purchase all alcoholic beverages from the Department of Liquor Control.
The holder of a CAT license who violates the requirements of this section is subject to the provisions of Title 16, Subtitle 5 (Penalties) of this article.
This section applies only in Queen Anne’s County.
The annual license fee is $100.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.

A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license premises.
The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are permitted in this article for a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the existing license.
This section applies only in St. Mary’s County.
The annual license fee is $250.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.

A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license premises.
The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are permitted in this article for a Class B restaurant or hotel (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B (on-sale) beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the existing license.

paragraph.text: This section applies only in Washington County.
In this section, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of a pouring license or a Class B restaurant or hotel (on and off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
The annual license fee is $1,500.

A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the premises covered by the pouring license or the Class B restaurant or hotel license.
The holder shall prepare, deliver, and provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
Before a caterer’s license may be issued, reissued, or renewed, the county health department shall approve the facilities that prepare the food.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are allowed under this article for the underlying pouring license or Class B restaurant or hotel license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing pouring license or Class B restaurant or hotel license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the existing license.
The holder of a caterer’s license shall:

paragraph.text: Provide all the service employees to serve the alcoholic beverages at the catered event; and
Ensure that at least one of those employees is certified by an alcohol awareness program and on the premises at all times during the catered event.
This section applies only in Wicomico County.
In this section, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $550.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a caterer’s license.
If a caterer’s license is issued, it shall only be issued to a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine license; or
A Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license.

subsection.text: A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes:

paragraph.text: The holder of a Class B beer and light wine license to provide beer and light wine at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine licensed premises; and
The holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor license to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor licensed premises.

subsection.text: The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are allowed under this article for the underlying Class B license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine license or a Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the Class B license.
This section applies only in Worcester County.
The annual license fee is $500.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of a:

paragraph.text: Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license; or
Class D beer, wine and liquor license.

subsection.text: A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off premises licensed as a Class B restaurant or hotel or a Class D establishment.
The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.

A holder may exercise the privileges under a caterer’s license only during the hours and days that are permitted in this article for the holder’s Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license or Class D beer, wine and liquor license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license or Class D beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the Class B or Class D license.
This section applies only in Cecil County.
The annual license fee is $100.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a caterer’s license to a holder of:

paragraph.text: A Class B restaurant or hotel beer, wine and liquor license; or
A Class B restaurant or hotel beer and light wine license.

subsection.text: A caterer’s license authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the premises for which the Class B restaurant or hotel beer, wine and liquor license or Class B restaurant or hotel beer and light wine license is issued.
The holder of a caterer’s license shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.

A holder may exercise the privileges under a caterer’s license only during the days and hours that are authorized under this article for a Class B restaurant or hotel beer, wine and liquor license or a Class B restaurant or hotel beer and light wine license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B beer, wine and liquor license or an existing Class B restaurant or hotel beer and light wine license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises for which the existing license is issued.
This section applies only in Dorchester County.
The Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B caterer’s license to a licensee who:

paragraph.text: Holds a Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine license or Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license;
Holds a caterer’s license issued by the county health department; and
Contracts to provide food and alcoholic beverages to sponsors of public or private events.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $150.

paragraph.text: A Class B caterer’s license authorizes the holder to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the premises covered by the Class B beer and light wine license or Class B beer, wine and liquor license.

A holder of a Class B beer and light wine license or a Class B beer, wine and liquor license need not have a Class B caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the holder’s license.

subsection.text: The Board of License Commissioners need not publish an application for a Class B caterer’s license before issuing the license.
The holder of a Class B caterer’s license:

paragraph.text: Shall notify the Board in writing at least 7 days before the event for which the license is to be used;
Shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event; and
May exercise the privileges of the license only during the hours and days that are authorized for the holder’s Class B beer and light wine license or Class B beer, wine and liquor license.

subsection.text: When catering a public event, a holder of a Class B caterer’s license:

paragraph.text: Shall distribute a wristband to each individual at least 21 years old at the catered event; and
May not serve an alcoholic beverage to an individual at the catered event who does not wear the wristband.
This section applies only in Somerset County.
In this section, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $550.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a caterer’s license.
If a caterer’s license is issued, it shall be issued only to a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine license; or
A Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license.

subsection.text: A caterer’s license issued under this section authorizes:

paragraph.text: The holder of a Class B beer and light wine license to provide beer and light wine at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine licensed premises; and
The holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor license to provide alcoholic beverages at events that are held off the Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor licensed premises.

subsection.text: The holder shall provide food as well as alcoholic beverages for consumption at the catered event.
A holder may exercise the privileges under this license only during the hours and days that are allowed under this article for the underlying Class B license.

This section does not require a holder of an existing Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer and light wine license or a Class B restaurant or hotel (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license to have a caterer’s license for catering on the premises that is covered by the Class B license.

paragraph.text: On approval by the board of license commissioners for that jurisdiction, if any, of a proper application, made on forms prescribed by the State Comptroller, signed and sworn to, the license issuing authority may grant the types of special licenses for the periods and at the fees specified in this section.
For an application for a statewide license, the Comptroller may grant the license.

In Anne Arundel County, the provisions of §§ 10–103(b) and 10–202 of this article and § 10–501 of the State Government Article do not apply to an applicant for a special Class C beer license, special Class C beer and wine license, or special Class C beer, wine and liquor license for a period not to exceed 7 consecutive days from the effective date of the license.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subsection (a) of this section, a special Class C beer license or a special Class C beer and wine license entitles the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses for the use of any person holding any bona fide entertainment conducted by any club, society or association at the place described in the license, for a period not exceeding seven consecutive days from the effective date thereof.
The fee is $5 per day.

paragraph.text: In Anne Arundel County:

subparagraph.text: The fee is $25 per day; and

The provisions of §§ 10–103(b) and 10–202 of this article and § 10–501 of the State Government Article do not apply to an applicant for either the special Class C beer license or the special Class C beer and wine license.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore City the fee is $25 per day.
In Baltimore County the fee is $30 per day, except that for any bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, war veterans’, hospital or charitable organization, the fee is $20.
In Carroll County the fee is $50 per day.
In Dorchester County:

subparagraph.text: A holder of a special Class C beer license or a special Class C beer and wine license may cater an event at the place described in the license on the effective days of the license;
The fee is $15 per day; and
A holder of a special Class C beer license or a special Class C beer and wine license:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall distribute at the event for which the license is issued a wristband to each individual who is at least 21 years old; and
May not serve an alcoholic beverage to any individual who does not wear the wristband.

subparagraph.text: A person who violates this paragraph is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: For the first offense, a fine of $50; and
For the second offense, a fine not exceeding $500 and denial of further requests for licenses for catering additional events.

paragraph.text: In Frederick County the fee is $10 per day.
In Harford County the fee is $15 per day.
In Howard County the fee is $15 per day.
In Montgomery County:

subparagraph.text: The fee is $30 per day; and

In addition to paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection and notwithstanding § 1–102(a)(4) of this article, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a one–day special Class C beer license or a one–day special Class C beer and wine license to a community swimming pool club.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County:

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in items (ii) and (iv) of this paragraph, the fee is $75 per day;

For a club, society, or association holding a casino or gambling event, the fee is $100 per day, which shall be paid by the club, society, or association and shall be considered as part of the club’s, society’s, or association’s special license fee;
The Board of License Commissioners may deny an application for this license if it is determined that the applicant does not qualify under the provisions of this article; and

sub-subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class D beer and wine license to an individual or on behalf of an entity that holds an event in the property of a conceptual site plan at least part of which includes a waterfront entertainment retail complex as defined by the county zoning ordinance;
A holder of the license may display and sell beer and wine at retail for consumption on or off the licensed premises during the days and hours designated for the event;
An event for which the license is issued may not last longer than 7 consecutive days;
This subparagraph does not prevent a holder of the license from holding another alcoholic beverages license of a different class or nature;
The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this subparagraph; and
The license fee is $100 per day.

paragraph.text: In Washington County:

subparagraph.text: The fee for a special Class C beer license is $15 per day; and
The fee for a special Class C beer and light wine license is $25 per day.

paragraph.text: In Wicomico County the fee is $30 per day.

subsection.text: Whenever a special one–day license is issued under subsection (b) of this section, the holders of wholesale licenses may enter into an agreement with the holder of a special one–day license to deliver beer or wine two days prior to the effective date, and to accept returns two days after the expiration date of the special license. Delivery of the beer or wine only may be made if the holder of the special license has in hand the special license at time of delivery.

subparagraph.text: A special Class C beer, wine and liquor license entitles the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by this class of license for the use of any person holding a bona fide entertainment conducted by a club, society, or association at the place described for a period not exceeding seven consecutive days, upon the payment of a fee of $15 per day.

The provisions of § 11–517 of this article do not apply to holders of this license. Alcoholic beverages sold under this special license shall be purchased by such special license holder from retail dealers.

paragraph.text: In Anne Arundel County:

subparagraph.text: A special beer, wine and liquor license, Class C licensee may purchase beer from a wholesaler;
The fee is $50 per day; and
The provisions of §§ 10–103(b) and 10–202 of this article and § 10–501 of the State Government Article do not apply to an applicant for the license.

paragraph.text: In Baltimore City:

subparagraph.text: The holder of a Class C special beer, wine and liquor license may purchase beer and light wine from a wholesale dealer.
The Board of Liquor License Commissioners may collect from the holder of the Class C special beer, wine and liquor license:

sub-subparagraph.text: A license fee of $50 per day; and
Reimbursement for costs incurred while monitoring the event for which the license is issued.

subparagraph.text: In Baltimore County:

sub-subparagraph.text: The fee for this license is $50 per day, except that for any bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, war veterans’, hospital or charitable organization, the fee for this license is $35; and
The holder of a special 7–day Class C beer, wine and liquor license may purchase beer and light wine from a wholesale dealer.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, the holder of a special 7–day Class C beer, wine and liquor license may agree with the holder of a wholesale license to deliver beer and wine on the effective days of the license and accept returns on the same day of delivery.

paragraph.text: In Calvert County the fee for this license is $25 per day, except that for any bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, war veterans’, hospital or charitable organization, the fee for the license is $15.
In Carroll County the fee is $50 per day.
In Dorchester County:

subparagraph.text: A holder of a special Class C beer, wine and liquor license may cater an event at the place described in the license on the effective days of the license;
The fee is $25 per day; and
A holder of a special Class C beer, wine and liquor license:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall distribute at the event for which the license is issued a wristband to each individual who is at least 21 years old; and
May not serve an alcoholic beverage to any individual who does not wear the wristband.

subparagraph.text: A person who violates this paragraph is subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: For the first offense, a fine of $50; and
For the second offense, a fine not exceeding $500 and denial of further requests for licenses for catering additional events.

paragraph.text: In Frederick County the fee is $30 per day.
In Garrett County, a holder of a special Class C beer, wine and liquor license may purchase beer and light wine from a wholesale dealer.
In Harford County the fee is $30 per day.
Notwithstanding paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection, in Montgomery County:

subparagraph.text: The fee is $60 per day; and
Notwithstanding § 1–102(a)(4) of this article, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a one–day special Class C beer, wine and liquor license to a community swimming pool club.
This paragraph applies only in Prince George’s County.
Except as provided in item (iii) of this paragraph, the fee is $200 per day.

For a club, society, or association holding a casino or gambling event, the fee is $150 per day, which shall be paid by the club, society, or association and shall be considered as part of the club’s, society’s, or association’s special license fee.

When the Board of License Commissioners issues a license under this paragraph, the Board shall notify the chief of police, the fire chief, the director of the Department of Environmental Resources, and, if applicable, the municipal corporation in which the event is to be held, as to the time, place, and expected size of the event for which the license is issued.
The Board of License Commissioners may deny an application for this license if it is determined that the applicant does not qualify under the provisions of this article.

paragraph.text: In Wicomico County the fee is $45 per day.

subsection.text: A special license of any class entitles its holder to exercise the privilege of the license for a period not exceeding ten consecutive days at a fee of $5 per day. In cases where a license has been cancelled, revoked, or suspended, renewal has been denied by the local board, or where a renewal license has been granted by the local board and the court on appeal has reversed the local board’s decision, the licensee may dispose of the licensee’s stock of alcoholic beverages. The special license shall carry with it the privilege of selling the stock at retail or to one or more holders of wholesale licenses. The holders of wholesale licenses may purchase them. This subsection does not authorize the licensee to purchase alcoholic beverages for the purpose of resale under this license.

When the move is necessitated by fire or other catastrophe, the holder of a special license of any class may temporarily move the licensed premises from one location to another while the premises are being restored. The holder may exercise the privileges of the license for a period in the discretion of the Comptroller or board of license commissioners, as the case may be, but not to exceed six months. A fee may not be charged for this special license but the Comptroller or board shall approve, as in the case of the original application, the new location to which the license holder has temporarily moved.

The special licenses provided for in this section may not be issued in any county or in Baltimore City, or in this State in case of application for statewide license, if the issuance of a regular license of the same class is not authorized by this article.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subsection apply only in Allegany County.

The Board of License Commissioners may grant special licenses of any class, except manufacturer’s and wholesaler’s, which entitles their holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any club, society, or association at the place described in the license, for a period not exceeding seven consecutive days from the effective date of the license, upon the payment, before the license is issued, to the Board of License Commissioners of a fee of:

subparagraph.text: $20 per day for any beer or beer and light wine license; or
$50 per day, for not more than 14 consecutive days, for any beer, wine and liquor license.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special permit to holders of Class D beer and Class D beer and light wine licenses that allows the sale of beer, wine and liquor by the drink for consumption on the premises.

A holder of this special permit may continue to sell beer or beer and wine for consumption on or off the premises, but the holder may not sell liquor for consumption off the premises, or purchase or possess liquor on the premises in any size container smaller than 23 ounces or 680 milliliters.
Application for this special permit shall be made not less than 30 days prior to the day on which the permit is to take effect.
The annual fee for this special permit is $500.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue a 1–day special retail license of any class that entitles the holder to exercise any privilege conferred by that class of license at a bona fide entertainment event.
The license is valid for a period not exceeding 5 consecutive days.
The fee for the license shall be set by the Board of County Commissioners on the recommendation of the Board of License Commissioners.
The license holder may exercise the privileges of the license only on county–owned property.
The Board of County Commissioners shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Distribute $100 of the license fee to the Board of License Commissioners; and
Donate the balance of the license fee to a bona fide nonprofit charitable organization that is tax exempt under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the United States Internal Revenue Code.

subparagraph.text: The license holder, with the approval of the County Commissioners, shall designate the bona fide charitable organization to be the recipient of the donation under subparagraph (v) of this paragraph.
To qualify for the license, a person shall submit an application not less than 30 days before the day on which the license is to take effect.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subsection apply only in Baltimore County.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue multiple one–day alcoholic beverages licenses under this section to any bona fide nonprofit charitable organization that is tax exempt under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the United States Internal Revenue Code.

subparagraph.text: The applicant shall list, on the application for the license, the dates of the events for which a license is required.
A multiple one–day alcoholic beverages license issued under this subsection may not include more than 12 dates.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners shall adopt regulations necessary for the implementation of this subsection.
The provisions of this subsection apply only in Caroline County.

The Board of License Commissioners may grant special licenses of any class, except manufacturer’s and wholesaler’s, which entitle the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any club, society, or association.
The license shall be in the form prescribed by the Board, and the applicant shall sign and swear to the license.
The fee for each license is $50.
Before a license is issued, the fee shall be paid to the Board for the use of the county.
A special license may not be granted to any organization more than 12 times in any calendar year.

subparagraph.text: Instead of purchasing individual event licenses for a particular class of license, an applicant may purchase a special multiple event license for the same class of license.
Fees for a special multiple event license are:

sub-subparagraph.text: $250 for not more than 10 events per year;
$500 for not more than 20 events per year;
$750 for not more than 30 events per year; and
$1,000 for not more than 40 events per year.

subparagraph.text: The total number of days for which special multiple event licenses may be issued to a single applicant may not exceed 40 days per calendar year.

sub-subparagraph.text: The applicant shall pay in advance the fee for a special multiple event license.
The Board may not issue a refund if the holder of the license in a calendar year holds fewer than the number of events that the holder is entitled to conduct.

subparagraph.text: A special multiple event license shall be issued:

sub-subparagraph.text: For one premises only; and
Subject to subparagraph (vi) of this paragraph, to the same applicant for all events for which the license is issued, unless the Board in writing approves a substitute applicant.

subparagraph.text: The Board may hold a hearing before approving a substitute applicant under subparagraph (v)2 of this paragraph.

A server who is currently certified as having completed an alcohol awareness program shall be on the premises for which a special multiple event license is issued whenever alcoholic beverages are served under the license.

paragraph.text: The Carroll County Board of License Commissioners may grant special Class C beer, wine and liquor licenses which entitle the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by that class of license at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any Carroll County fire department or an arts center on West Main Street in Westminster.
The license shall be in the form prescribed by the Board, and the applicant shall sign the license.
The annual fee for a special license is as follows:

subparagraph.text: Up to 10 events per year – $125;
Up to 20 events per year – $250;
Up to 30 events per year – $375; and
Up to 40 events per year – $500.

paragraph.text: The fee shall be paid before a license is issued.
This special license may not be granted to any fire department or an arts center on West Main Street in Westminster more than one time in any year.
The total number of days authorized by this special license may not exceed 40 in any calendar year.
This subsection does not preclude a fire company or an arts center on West Main Street in Westminster from obtaining a single event special Class C license under other provisions of this section.
This subsection applies only in Cecil County.
In this subsection “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.

In this subsection, where action of the Board is required, a simple majority of the total number of the members of the Board may act in the following ways to give its approval or disapproval to an application for a special license:

subparagraph.text: A formal meeting, with a quorum present; or

Oral or written contact by the chairman with each member of the Board. This contact may be by any method, including telephone or facsimile. If this approach is chosen, the chairman shall indicate in writing for the records of the Board how each member and the chairman voted.

Upon approval of an application on a form prescribed by the Board, signed and sworn to, the Board may grant special licenses of any class, except manufacturer’s and wholesaler’s. The licensee may exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any club, society, or association at the place described in the license, upon the payment of the following fees:

sub-subparagraph.text: A beer or beer and light wine license – $10 per day; or
A beer, wine and liquor license – $20 per day.

subparagraph.text: The fee shall be paid to the Board for the use of the county before the license is issued.

This special license may not be granted to any organization more than four times in any year, nor may the total number of days authorized by special licenses for any organization exceed four in a calendar year.

paragraph.text: The Board may not require the publication of an application for a special temporary alcoholic beverages license as a prerequisite to the granting of such a license.

subparagraph.text: The Board may grant a special Class T license. The license shall be in the form prescribed by the Board. The applicant shall sign and swear to the license. The Class T license permits the holder to conduct wine tasting parties and demonstrations.
The fee is $25 per day and shall be paid prior to the issuance of this license.

This license may not be issued to any person more than four times in any calendar year. The total number of days authorized by the Class T license for any person may not exceed four in a calendar year.

The Board may grant special licenses of any class, except manufacturer’s and wholesaler’s, which entitle the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any Cecil County fire department. The license shall be in the form prescribed by the Board, and the applicant shall sign the license.
The fee shall be paid before a license is issued and is:

sub-subparagraph.text: For any beer or beer and light wine license – $120 per year; or
For any beer, wine and liquor license – $240 per year.

subparagraph.text: This special license may not be granted to any fire department more than one time in any year. The total number of days authorized by this special license may not exceed 24 in any calendar year.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Charles County.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special Class D (on–sale) beer permit to any bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, veterans’, hospital or charitable organization for a period not exceeding ten consecutive days from the effective date of the license, subject to any conditions the Board may impose on the issuance of this permit. The fee for this permit is $25.
This subsection applies only in Dorchester County.

The Board of License Commissioners may grant a special license of any class, except for any license issued by the Comptroller, that entitles the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by that class at an event conducted by a not for profit club, society, association, or organization.
An applicant for a license shall submit to the Board a completed, signed, and notarized application on the form that the Board provides.
The fees are:

subparagraph.text: $15 per day for a beer license or a beer and light wine license; and
$25 per day for a beer, wine and liquor license.

paragraph.text: An applicant shall pay the fee to the Board before a license is issued.
A holder of a special license under this subsection may cater an event at the place described in the license on the effective days of the license.

The Dorchester County Board of License Commissioners may not require the publication of an application for a special temporary alcoholic beverages license as a prerequisite to the granting of such a license.
This subsection applies only in Frederick County.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph:

sub-subparagraph.text: Permits sales for off–premises consumption only on the days permitted by the license for the special anniversary or special event; and
Applies only to special anniversary or special event collectible bottles.

subparagraph.text: After obtaining a license pursuant to this section, the following licensees may sell collectible bottles of wine or liquor:

sub-subparagraph.text: Special Class C beer and light wine; and
Special Class C beer, wine and liquor.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other restrictions imposed by this article, special licenses may be issued for the volunteer fire companies described in § 8–211(g) of this article.

subsection.text: In Garrett County, there are 4 types of special Class C beer, beer and wine, or beer, wine and liquor licenses available, as follows:

paragraph.text: A special 2–day Class C license for a fee of $50;
A special 6–day Class C license for a fee of $150;
A special 12–day Class C license for a fee of $300; or
A special multiple event Class C license under the following conditions:

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special multiple event license to an organization that otherwise qualifies for a special Class C license;
The annual fee for a special multiple event license is as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: $125 for up to 5 events per year;
$250 for up to 12 events per year;
$375 for up to 18 events per year; and
$500 for up to 24 events per year;

subparagraph.text: The Board may not issue more than 1 special multiple event license to an organization in a license year;
A special multiple event licensee shall notify the Board in writing at least 7 days before an event; and
The Board shall publish a notice for application for a special multiple event license one time at least 7 days before the hearing on the license.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Howard County.
There is a Class B special beer and wine (B–SBW) (off–sale) license.
A holder of a B–SBW license may sell beer and wine for consumption off the licensed premises.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a B–SBW license only to a holder of a Class B beer, wine and liquor (7–day) (on–sale) license that is issued for a restaurant.
The term of a B–SBW license issued to a successful applicant shall be the same as that of the Class B beer, wine and liquor license that the applicant holds.
Before the Board of License Commissioners issues a B–SBW license to an applicant:

subparagraph.text: The applicant shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Complete the form that the Board of License Commissioners provides; and
Pay an annual license fee of $500; and

subparagraph.text: The same advertising, posting of notice, and public hearing requirements as those for other Class B licenses shall be met.

paragraph.text: A holder of a B–SBW license:

subparagraph.text: May sell beer and wine for consumption off the licensed premises only to persons who have purchased food or alcohol from the licensed premises; and
In areas of the establishment that are accessible to the public, may not display or provide shelving for beer or wine for off–premises sales.

paragraph.text: Off–sale alcoholic beverages receipts collected under a B–SBW license shall be included in the calculation of average daily receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages under § 1–102(a)(22)(i)1C of this article.
The hours for sale for a B–SBW license are from 10 a.m. to midnight, Monday through Sunday.
A holder of a B–SBW license may exercise the privileges of the license only if the licensed premises is open for business as a restaurant.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a refillable container permit to a holder of any class of alcoholic beverages license issued by the Board of License Commissioners except a Class C license and a Class GC license:

sub-subparagraph.text: On completion of an application form that the Board provides; and
At no cost to the B–SBW license holder.

subparagraph.text: A refillable container permit entitles the holder to sell draft beer for consumption off the licensed premises in a refillable container with a capacity of not less than 32 ounces and not more than 128 ounces.
To be used as a refillable container under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a container shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Be sealable;
Be branded with an identifying mark of the license holder;
Bear the federal health warning statement required for containers of alcoholic beverages under 27 C.F.R. 16.21;
Display instructions for cleaning the container; and
Bear a label stating that:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Cleaning the container is the responsibility of the consumer; and
Contents of the container are perishable and should be refrigerated immediately and consumed within 48 hours after purchase.

subparagraph.text: The term of and hours of sale for a refillable container permit issued to an applicant are the same as that of the applicant’s alcoholic beverages license.

An applicant who holds an alcoholic beverages license without an off–sale privilege shall meet the same advertising, posting of notice, and public hearing requirements as those for the alcoholic beverages license that the applicant holds.
A holder of a refillable container permit may refill only a refillable container that was branded by the permit holder.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this subsection, including a limit on the number of licenses to be issued.

subsection.text: In Kent County, a special Class C beer license, a special Class C beer and wine license and a special Class C beer, wine and liquor license may be issued to any bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, veterans’, hospital, or charitable club, society, association, or organization, for a period not exceeding 3 days. The fee for the special beer license is $5 per day, the fee for the special beer and wine license is $15 per day, and the fee for the special beer, wine and liquor license is $25 per day.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in St. Mary’s County.
There is a special Class C beer license, a special Class C beer and wine license, or a special Class C beer, wine and liquor license.
The Board of License Commissioners may:

subparagraph.text: Issue a license listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection to a bona fide religious, fraternal, civic, veterans’, hospital, or charitable club, society, association, or organization; and
Impose conditions on the issuance of the license.

paragraph.text: The periods for which the licenses listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection may be issued are:

subparagraph.text: Special Class C beer license — not exceeding 10 consecutive days from its effective date;
Special Class C beer and wine license — 1 day; and
Special Class C beer, wine and liquor license — 1 day.

paragraph.text: The fee for each license is $10.
A holder of a special license under this subsection may purchase the alcoholic beverages to be sold under the special license from a retail dealer.
This subsection applies only in Somerset County.
The Board of License Commissioners may grant special licenses of any class except manufacturer’s and wholesaler’s licenses.

The licenses entitle the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by the respective classes of licenses at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any club, society, association, or civic or charitable organization.

subparagraph.text: A special beer or beer and light wine license may be issued for up to 7 consecutive days.
A special beer, wine and liquor license may be issued for up to 14 consecutive days.
The fee for a special beer, beer and light wine, or beer, wine and liquor license is $63 for each license day.
After the initial 2–day period, the fee for each additional day is $32.

paragraph.text: The fees shall be paid to the Board for the use of the county before the license is issued.
The Board may not require the publication of an application for a special temporary alcoholic beverages license as a prerequisite to the granting of such a license.
This subsection applies only in Washington County.

subparagraph.text: There is a special Class C (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license, which shall be issued solely to clubs having an annual on–sale beer, wine and liquor license. This special license entitles the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages at any place other than its regular place of business.
The license permits sales for a period not to exceed five days.
The daily fee is $30. There is no fee on Sunday.

There is an additional special license, referred to locally as a “picnic” license. This license permits the club owner to sell only beer at any place other than the club owner’s regular place of business.
The license may be exercised only on Sundays between 12 noon and midnight notwithstanding daylight saving time.
The license fee is $15 per each Sunday a “picnic” is held.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Worcester County.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special license to the holder of a 6–day Class B or Class C beer, wine and liquor license located in the county. The license permits the licensee to sell alcoholic beverages to bona fide conventions and such other special groups that are approved by the:

sub-subparagraph.text: Mayor and city council of the incorporated town (if any) in which the premises are located, if the mayor and city council elect to exercise this power; and
Board of License Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: The license permits consumption on the premises only on Sunday during the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 1:00 a.m. the following Monday, prevailing time.
The holder of the license may exercise the privileges of the license at the time and place described in the license upon the payment of a fee.
The daily license fee is $10.
Application for the permit shall be made not less than 10 days prior to the day upon which the permit is to be exercised.
There is a special Sunday club license.
The license may be issued to bona fide clubs which already hold a Class C beer, wine and liquor license.
The additional fee is $10.
A club may be issued no more than 20 special Sunday licenses during a calendar year.

Application for the license shall be made at least 14 days in advance to the Board of License Commissioners. The license is subject to the approval of application by the Board and subject also to other conditions, regulations and restrictions as established by the Board for the consumption of those alcoholic beverages on the premises.
There is a nonprofit charitable organization license.
The license is a multiple one–day alcoholic beverages license to any bona fide nonprofit charitable organization.
The applicant shall specify the dates of the events for which the license will be used.
A multiple one–day alcoholic beverages license may not include more than 12 dates.
An alcoholic beverages license is not needed pursuant to the provisions of this paragraph of this subsection.

sub-subparagraph.text: In this paragraph the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.
“Commission” means the Ocean City Convention Hall Commission.
“Organization” includes the following bona fide, nonprofit groups:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Armed services;
Charitable;
Civic;
Employee;
Firemen;
Fraternal;
Governmental–support;
Hospital;
Labor;
Patriotic;
Political;
Professional;
Religious;
Trade; and
War veterans.

subparagraph.text: The Board, with the approval of the Commission or their successors, may permit the members and guests of any organization to bring their own alcoholic beverages onto the premises of the Hall without any type of alcoholic beverages license, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: These beverages are not sold; and
Their consumption is restricted to the premises.

subparagraph.text: The Board, with the approval of the Commission or their successors, may permit the Mayor and City Council of Ocean City or its designee to sponsor a function at which the patrons are permitted to bring their own alcoholic beverages onto the premises of the Hall without any type of alcoholic beverage license, if:

sub-subparagraph.text: These beverages are not sold; and
Their consumption is restricted to the premises.

subparagraph.text: All licensees shall purchase all wines and liquors, except light wine and beer, from the Liquor Control Board. They shall be charged 85 percent of the retail price or any special sale price or discount price, whichever is lower, set by the Board for wines and liquors. However, the price the Board charges to the licensees may not be lower than 10 percent above the cost the Liquor Control Board must pay for the merchandise to wholesalers. All licensees may purchase beer and light wine from licensed wholesalers.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Harford County.

subparagraph.text: The Liquor Control Board may grant a special Class C beer and wine license which entitles the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by that class of license at any bona fide entertainment held or conducted by any county fire department.
The Board shall prescribe the form for the application and the applicant shall sign it. The fee shall be paid before the license is issued.
The annual license fees are as follows for up to:
A license may not be granted to a fire department more than one time in any year.
The total number of days authorized by this special license may not exceed 40 in any calendar year.
A licensee shall notify the Board in writing at least 7 days prior to each event.
This paragraph does not preclude a fire department from obtaining a single event special Class C license under other provisions of this section.

The Board may issue a special Class C–3 (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license to a miscellaneous organization or club, as defined under § 6–301(n)(6)(i)1 of this article, that holds a Class C–3 organization or club license.
A special Class C–3 license authorizes the holder to sell or provide beer, wine, and liquor only for on–premises consumption by:

sub-subparagraph.text: Nonmembers of the organization or club who have leased an area of the licensed premises for a bona fide entertainment, conference, or social event; and
Guests who attend the event.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall prescribe the form for the application, and the applicant shall sign it.
The applicant shall pay the license fee before the Board issues the license.
The annual license fees are as follows for up to:

sub-subparagraph.text: 10 events per year……………….$250;
20 events per year……………….$400;
30 events per year……………….$550;
40 events per year……………….$700; and
60 events per year……………….$850.

subparagraph.text: The Board may not issue more than one license to a single miscellaneous organization or club in any license year.
The total number of days authorized for events held under a license may not exceed 60 in any license year.
A license holder shall notify the Board of an event in writing on a prescribed form at least 7 days before each event.
This paragraph does not preclude an organization or club from obtaining a single event special Class C license under other provisions of this section.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Wicomico County.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special Class C beer, beer and wine, or beer, wine and liquor license.
A special license entitles the holder to exercise any of the privileges conferred by that class of license at a bona fide entertainment event held by a fire department in the county.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a special license shall sign and submit to the Board of License Commissioners an application in the form that the Board provides.
The annual fee for a special license is:

subparagraph.text: $400, for not more than 10 days;
$800, for at least 11 but not more than 20 days;
$1,000, for at least 21 but not more than 30 days; and
$1,100, for at least 31 but not more than 40 days.

paragraph.text: The total number of days during which a special license may be used may not exceed 40 in a calendar year.
A license holder shall notify the Board of License Commissioners in writing at least 7 days before each day when the license is to be used.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue only one multiple event license to a license holder in a licensed year.
This subsection does not prevent a fire department from obtaining a single event special Class C license authorized elsewhere under this section.
The Board of License Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this subsection.
This subsection applies only in Prince George’s County.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special 3–day Class C beer, wine and liquor license to a nonprofit organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
The special license entitles the holder to sell beer, wine, or liquor at the National Harbor.
Beer, wine, and liquor sold under the special license may be consumed on or off the premises.
The fee for a special license is $200 per day.
The special license may not be issued to any one organization for:

subparagraph.text: More than 3 consecutive days in a single calendar year; or
2 consecutive years.
A holder of the special license shall purchase beer, wine, or liquor only from a wholesaler licensed in the State.
A wholesaler licensed in the State may donate alcoholic beverages to the holder of the special license.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Common carrier” means a business entity that:

subparagraph.text: Holds itself out as being available to the public to transport in interstate or foreign commerce for compensation any class of passenger or property; and
Holds a common carrier permit issued under § 2–101(y) of this article.

paragraph.text: “Common carrier” does not include a business entity that transports only property it owns or that is consigned to it.

subsection.text: “Direct wine shipper” means the holder of a direct wine shipper’s permit issued under this title.
“Pomace brandy” means brandy that is distilled from the pulpy residue of the wine press, including the skins, pips, and stalks of grapes.

paragraph.text: “Wine” includes pomace brandy.
“Wine” does not include beer, distilled spirits, or any alcoholic beverage other than wine.

section.text: A person shall be issued a direct wine shipper’s permit by the Office of the Comptroller as a direct wine shipper before the person may engage in shipping wine directly to a consumer in the State.
To qualify for a direct wine shipper’s permit, an applicant shall be:

paragraph.text: A person licensed outside the State to engage in the manufacture of wine; or
A holder of a Class 3 manufacturer’s license or a Class 4 manufacturer’s license issued under this article.

subsection.text: An applicant for a direct wine shipper’s permit shall:

paragraph.text: Submit to the Office of the Comptroller a completed application on a form that the Office of the Comptroller provides;
Provide to the Office of the Comptroller a copy of the applicant’s current alcoholic beverages license; and
Pay a fee of $200 for initial issuance of the direct wine shipper’s permit.

subsection.text: The Office of the Comptroller shall issue a direct wine shipper’s permit to each applicant who meets the requirements of this title for the direct wine shipper’s permit.

section.text: A direct wine shipper’s permit entitles the holder to sell wine manufactured by the holder through a holder of a common carrier permit to a consumer by receiving and filling orders that the consumer transmits by electronic or other means.
The term of a direct wine shipper’s permit is 1 year and begins on July 1.

subsection.text: A direct wine shipper shall:

paragraph.text: Ensure that all containers of wine shipped directly to a consumer in the State are conspicuously labeled with:

subparagraph.text: The name of the direct wine shipper;
The name and address of the consumer who is the intended recipient; and
The words “Contains Alcohol: Signature of Person at Least 21 Years of Age Required for Delivery”;

paragraph.text: Report quarterly to the Office of the Comptroller the total amount of wine, by type, shipped in the State, the price charged, and the name and address of each purchaser;
File a quarterly tax return in accordance with § 5–201(d) of the Tax – General Article;
Pay quarterly to the Office of the Comptroller all sales taxes and excise taxes due on sales to consumers in the State and calculate the taxes as if the sale were made in the State;
Maintain for a period of 3 years complete and accurate records of all information needed to verify compliance with this title;
Allow the Office of the Comptroller to perform an audit of the direct wine shipper’s records on request; and
Consent to the jurisdiction of the Office of the Comptroller or other State unit and the State courts concerning enforcement of this section and any related law.

subsection.text: A direct wine shipper may not:

paragraph.text: Ship more than 18 9–liter cases of wine each year to a single delivery address; or
Cause wine to be delivered on Sunday to an address in the State.

subsection.text: A direct wine shipper may renew its direct wine shipper’s permit each year if the direct wine shipper:

paragraph.text: Is otherwise entitled to have a direct wine shipper’s permit;
Provides to the Office of the Comptroller a copy of its current permit; and
Pays to the Office of the Comptroller a renewal fee of $200.

subsection.text: The Office of the Comptroller may deny a renewal application of a direct wine shipper who fails to:

paragraph.text: File a tax return required under this title;
Pay a fee or tax when due; or
After receiving notice, comply with a provision of this article or a regulation that the Office of the Comptroller adopts under this article.

subsection.text: To receive a direct shipment of wine, a consumer in the State shall be at least 21 years old.
A person who receives a shipment of wine shall use the shipment for personal consumption only and may not resell it.
A person shall be issued a common carrier permit before the person may engage in transporting wine from a direct wine shipper to a consumer.
The term of a common carrier permit is 1 year and begins on July 1.
To complete delivery of a shipment, the common carrier shall require from a consumer at the address listed on the shipping label:

paragraph.text: The signature of the consumer or another individual at the address who is at least 21 years old; and
Government–issued photographic identification showing that the signing individual is at least 21 years old.

subsection.text: A common carrier shall refuse delivery when the intended receiving individual appears to be under 21 years of age or refuses to present valid identification.

At the time of initial application for a common carrier permit and on request of the Comptroller, a common carrier shall submit to the Comptroller information concerning the training of its drivers in verifying the age of recipients of direct wine shipments under this title.

At least once each year, in a manner acceptable to the Comptroller, a holder of a common carrier permit shall verify that the shipper of wine into the State under this title holds a valid direct wine shipper’s permit.
A common carrier shall report quarterly to the Office of the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: The date of each delivery of wine in the State; and
The name and address of the direct wine shipper and the receiving consumer of each delivery.

subsection.text: A common carrier shall maintain for a period of 3 years complete and accurate records of all information needed to verify compliance with this title.

section.text: The Office of the Comptroller may adopt regulations to carry out this title.
A person without a direct wine shipper’s permit may not ship wine directly to consumers in the State.
Each violation of this title is a separate violation.

subsection.text: A municipal corporation may not impose any additional license fees or taxes, other than the usual property tax, upon alcoholic beverages or upon the exercise of the privileges conferred by the licenses issued under the provisions of this article, except as hereinafter provided in this article.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in the following counties:

subparagraph.text: Prince George’s County; and
Worcester County.

paragraph.text: A municipal corporation may require any license holder for any place of business situated in the municipal corporation to pay to that municipal corporation an additional annual license fee not exceeding 20 percent of the fee payable under the provisions of this article.

section.text: For Class F and G licenses, the provisions of this article may not be deemed as repealed by any local or general act unless expressly referred to and expressly repealed in terms.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Anne Arundel County.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of License Commissioners.
“License” means a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages that is issued by the Board.

subsection.text: In the City of Annapolis the Mayor, Counselor, and Aldermen have the power to:

paragraph.text: Fix the fees for all licenses authorized to be issued in the city; and
Determine a periodic basis on which payments for the renewal of a license may be made.
There is a special Sunday license.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article and except for “special licenses” provided for in § 6–501 of this article, a licensee may not sell any alcoholic beverages after 2 a.m. on Sundays except as provided in this section.

Upon application made in the same manner as for new licenses and approved by the Board as provided for by §§ 10–202(d) and 10–208(b) of this article, a licensee shall be issued an additional license known as a “special Sunday license” upon payment of the required fee.

subparagraph.text: The holder of a “special Sunday license” may sell alcoholic beverages on Sundays. The licenses shall be of the same kind as the ongoing license and are subject to the same limitations as to hours, restrictions, and other provisions found in licenses issued by the Board. The alcoholic beverages shall contain the same alcoholic content as is found in other alcoholic beverages.
A “special Sunday license” may not be issued to any person:

sub-subparagraph.text: Who holds a hotel–limited service license under subsection (j) of this section; or
Who does not hold an alcoholic beverages license of some other class issued by the Board.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for each beer and light wine “special Sunday license” is $60.
The annual fee for each beer, wine and liquor “special Sunday license” is $120.

paragraph.text: “Special Sunday licenses” may be renewed in the same manner as other licenses. “Special Sunday licenses” are not “special licenses” under the provisions of § 10–301 of this article.
The granting of a “special Sunday license” in addition to a license of any other class, to the same licensee, shall not be deemed to be in conflict with the provisions of § 9–102 of this article.
If any other license held by the holder of a “special Sunday license” is suspended or revoked, the “special Sunday license” is suspended or revoked by operation of law.
Section 9–203(c) of this article does not prohibit any person who holds any other class of alcoholic beverages license from obtaining a “special Sunday license”.
This subsection does not apply in the sixth district, which is the City of Annapolis.
This section does not apply to beach and amusement park licenses.
There is a racetrack license.

The owner of any regularly licensed racing establishment, whether individual, association of individuals, or a corporation, without further residential, voting or locative qualifications, may procure a license for the sale of any and all alcoholic beverages within the confines of its racing park.
The license fee is $60 per day to be paid on January 1 for the racing of the preceding year, payable to the Board. It entitles the holder to sell at one or more locations within its park.
Licenses and licensees are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages not inconsistent with the provisions of this section.
This subsection does not apply to the sixth district, which is the City of Annapolis.

subsection.text: The Board may permit the sale of any alcoholic beverages permitted by law to be sold in any district other than the sixth, which is the City of Annapolis, on or in any parking lot, picnic grounds, building or terrace which forms an integral part of the licensed premises.

paragraph.text: There is an airport concessionaire license.

subparagraph.text: An individual, association of individuals, or a corporation which is a lessee, sublessee, or a concessionaire at any airport, without further residential, voting or locative qualifications, may obtain an airport concessionaire license for the sale of any and all alcoholic beverages within the airport terminal buildings.

sub-subparagraph.text: This subparagraph does not apply to duty free shops.

A person who is a lessee, sublessee, or concessionaire at Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport may hold one airport concessionaire license for multiple locations within the terminal building of Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport, even if the person already holds one or more alcoholic beverages licenses of any other type issued by the Board.

The Board may issue a second airport concessionaire license for a leased premises or concessionaire space that is licensed as of March 1, 2004, at Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport to maintain service during a transition involving different licensees; but
The first airport concessionaire license shall expire when the privileges under the second are exercised.

subparagraph.text: On receipt of an application for an airport concessionaire license under subparagraph (ii) or (iii) of this paragraph, the Board shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Give precedence to the application over all other license applications; and
Hold a hearing on the application at the Board meeting that immediately follows receipt of the application.

subparagraph.text: The annual fee for the airport concessionaire license and one location from which alcoholic beverages may be sold is $5,000.
The annual fee for each additional location from which alcoholic beverages may be sold is $5,000.
Each fee shall be paid on May 1 to the Board.
The licensee may sell alcoholic beverages every day from each location within the airport terminal buildings.
The license permits the playing of music and dancing.
The provisions of subsection (d) of this section relating to special Sunday licenses do not apply to the holder of a license issued under this subsection.

paragraph.text: Licenses and licensees are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages not inconsistent with the provisions of this section.
There is a resort complex license.
“Resort complex” means a recreational area of 10 or more acres with beach facilities and facilities to serve and accommodate 500 or more persons at one time.

The Board may issue a resort complex license covering “on–sales” of beer, wine and liquor to any person, for the sale of any and all alcoholic beverages within the confines of the resort complex. This license shall be issued only to the person, firm, or corporation owning or leasing a resort complex.

subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $1,800.
It shall be paid on May 1 to the Board and entitles the holder to sell daily at one or more locations within the resort complex.
The license permits playing of music and dancing.
The provisions of subsection (d) of this section relating to special Sunday licenses do not apply to the holder of a license issued under this subsection.

paragraph.text: The licenses and licensees are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages not inconsistent with the provisions of this subsection.
This license permits the sale of alcoholic beverages at bars or counters, but not for consumption off the premises.
Licensees may serve alcoholic beverages at one or more outside locations within the resort complex from 8 a.m. to midnight for each outing and from 6 a.m. to 2 a.m. in main, permanent areas.
There is a motel/hotel–restaurant license.

The license covers “on–sales” of beer, wine and liquor to any person, without further residential, voting or locative qualifications being required of the applicant, for the sale of any and all alcoholic beverages within the confines of the motel–restaurant complex or hotel–restaurant complex.

subparagraph.text: These licenses shall be issued only to the person, firm, or corporation owning or leasing motel–restaurant complexes or hotel–restaurant complexes that have:

sub-subparagraph.text: A capital investment of not less than $500,000;
100 rooms or more; and
An enclosed dining room which serves at least twice daily full–course meals from menus.

subparagraph.text: If the food concession is leased to a concessionaire, the concessionaire is exempt from having a capital investment of not less than $500,000.
Any motel–restaurant complex or hotel–restaurant complex with 100 or more rooms shall have a motel–restaurant or hotel–restaurant complex license by October 1, 1977.
The annual license fee for each separate establishment is $3,600.
The fee shall be paid on May 1 to the Board and entitles the holder to sell alcoholic beverages every day at one or more locations within the hotel–restaurant or motel–restaurant complex.
The license permits the playing of music and dancing.
The provisions of subsection (d) of this section relating to special Sunday licenses do not apply to the holder of a license issued under this subsection.
The licenses and licensees are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages, not inconsistent with the provisions of this subsection.
This license permits the sale of alcoholic beverages at bars or counters, but not for consumption off the premises.
There is a beer and wine (hotel–limited service) (on–sale) license.
There is a beer, wine and liquor (hotel–limited service) (on–sale) license.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a license under paragraph (1)(i) or (ii) of this subsection only to a person who owns or leases a hotel that contains at least 50 rooms and operates a kitchen licensed at least as a food service facility.
A license issued under this subsection entitles the holder to sell alcoholic beverages every day at one or more locations within the hotel.
The annual license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $2,400 for a beer and wine (hotel–limited service) license; and
$2,800 for a beer, wine and liquor (hotel–limited service) license.

paragraph.text: The annual license fee shall be paid on May 1 to the Board.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Concessionaire” means a lessee, sublessee, or any other operator of an establishment that:

sub-subparagraph.text: Engages in the daily sale of beer, wine, and liquor on its premises for consumption anywhere in an entertainment facility; and
Is operated as a concession adjacent to but independent of the entertainment facility.

subparagraph.text: “Entertainment facility” means a facility that holds a license under Title 9, Subtitle 1A of the State Government Article.
There is an entertainment facility license.

The Board may issue an entertainment facility license for an entertainment facility that contains one or more food service facilities, bars, or lounges that are part of the operation of the entertainment facility.

The entertainment facility license shall be issued to an individual, entity, or subsidiary of an entity that owns an entertainment facility and holds a license under Title 9, Subtitle 1A of the State Government Article.
An applicant for an entertainment facility license need not meet any location, voting, or residency requirements.

An entertainment facility license authorizes the holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor on any premises of the entertainment facility that is not covered by an entertainment concessionaire license for consumption anywhere in the entertainment facility.
There is an entertainment concessionaire license.
The Board may issue an entertainment concessionaire license to a concessionaire operating in conjunction with an entertainment facility.
The entertainment concessionaire license authorizes the holder to sell beer, wine, and liquor on the premises of the concessionaire for consumption anywhere in the entertainment facility.
The annual fee for an entertainment facility license is $15,000.
The annual fee for an entertainment concessionaire license is $5,000.
The annual license fees shall be paid on May 1 to the Board.
An off–sale privilege is not conferred by an entertainment facility license or an entertainment concessionaire license.
Beer, wine, and liquor purchased under an entertainment facility license or an entertainment concessionaire license may be taken into and consumed anywhere in an entertainment facility.

The hours for the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages under an entertainment facility license or an entertainment concessionaire license are the same as the hours of operation for a video lottery facility established under § 9–1A–23 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: An entertainment facility license and an entertainment concessionaire license authorize the playing of music and dancing in their respective licensed premises.
Subsection (d) of this section, relating to special Sunday licenses, does not apply to a license issued under this subsection.
An entertainment facility license or an entertainment concessionaire license may not be counted as a Class B or Class H license for purposes of § 9–102(h–1) of this article.
The licenses and holders are subject to all laws and regulations applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages not inconsistent with this subsection.

Any penalty or other sanction that is imposed for a violation of a regulation of the Board on the licensed premises of the holder of an entertainment concessionaire license shall apply to the concessionaire that the Board determines to be responsible for the violation.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Anne Arundel County.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of License Commissioners of Anne Arundel County.
“Capital investment” means amounts paid for the acquisition of property:

subparagraph.text: For a useful life greater than 1 year; or
For a permanent improvement or betterment of the property that has a useful life greater than 1 year.

paragraph.text: “Cost of land” includes:

subparagraph.text: The purchase price, plus taxes and fees incidental to the purchase, including costs related to obtaining appropriate zoning and licensing;
The cost of site grading, preparation, paving, sidewalks, gutters, curbs, and landscaping; and
The cost of the construction and installation of all utilities to the exterior of the building shell.

paragraph.text: “Cost of the building shell” includes the cost attributable to a structure with a roof, sidewalls, doors, and windows completely enclosed and weatherproofed on a slab or other subflooring.
There is a 7–day Class BLX (deluxe restaurant) (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license.
A BLX license may be issued only for the use of an establishment that:

subparagraph.text: Qualifies as a restaurant under the regulations of the Board;
Has a minimum seating capacity of 100 persons for dining;
Has a cocktail lounge or bar area seating capacity not exceeding 25% of the seating capacity for dining;
