In addition to the restrictions in subsubparagraphs 2 and 3 of this subparagraph, the holder of a special B–K beer and wine license or a special B–K beer, wine and liquor license in the commercial areas specified in subsubparagraph 1I, J, K, and L of this subparagraph may not serve alcoholic beverages after 11 p.m.

In the town of Kensington, the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners may issue not more than three Class A (off–sale) beer and light wine licenses for use in the commercial areas specified in subparagraph (iv)1 of this paragraph.
A Class A beer and light wine license authorizes the holder to keep for sale and sell beer or light wine for consumption off the premises 7 days a week, from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily.
A holder of a Class A beer and light wine license may not:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Sell single bottles or cans of beer;
Sell refrigerated products; or
On a side, door, or window of the building of the licensed premises, place a sign or other display that advertises alcoholic beverages in a publicly visible location.

sub-subparagraph.text: The annual license fee is $250.

subparagraph.text: In Damascus (12th election district), the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners may issue a special 7–day Class C on–sale beer, wine and liquor license to any bona fide volunteer fire department.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not prohibit the issuance of an on–sale license for the sale of beer only during daylight hours only for any restaurant or snack bar or similar facility located upon land owned by the Montgomery County Revenue Authority and operated by the Revenue Authority or others in connection with the operation by the Revenue Authority of a public golf course.

This subsection does not prohibit the issuance of an on–sale license for the sale of beer and wine for any restaurant located upon land owned by the Montgomery County Revenue Authority and operated by the Revenue Authority or others in connection with the operation of an airport.
The City of Takoma Park is excepted from the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection if subsection (d) of this section becomes effective.
The town of Laytonsville is excepted from the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection if subsection (e) of this section becomes effective.
Damascus (12th election district) is excepted from the provisions of paragraph (2) of this subsection if subsection (f) of this section becomes effective.

The Commissioners of Poolesville may, in their discretion, from time to time, submit to the legal and qualified voters of Poolesville the question or questions whether or not the sale of all or any class of alcoholic beverages or the issuance of any class, or classes or for the sale of such class or classes of alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited within the corporate limits of said town.

The Commissioners may submit any such question or questions to the voters at any regular election or at a special election called for that purpose. Submission of any question at one election shall not prevent the submission of the same or other questions at subsequent elections.

If a majority of the votes cast on any such question favor permitting sales of all or any classes of alcoholic beverages or issuance of any class or classes of license, the sale of alcoholic beverages of such class or classes and the issuance of licenses of such class or classes in said town shall, after such election, either continue as theretofore if such sales or licenses were permitted in the town at the time of such election, or be permitted in accordance with the State law authorizing such sales or licenses if theretofore prohibited in the town.

If a majority of the votes cast on any such question favor prohibiting sales of all or any class of alcoholic beverages or issuance of any class or classes of licenses, then no licenses of such class or classes or for the sale of such class or classes of alcoholic beverages within the corporate limits of said town shall thereafter be issued, renewed or extended, but licenses theretofore issued shall continue in force until the date of expiration in accordance with their terms but shall not be renewed or extended.

subsection.text: In Montgomery County it is unlawful for any person, corporation, club or organization to sell, give, serve, dispense, keep or allow to be consumed on his or its premises or on premises under his or its possession or control any alcoholic beverages other than as specifically permitted or provided in this article if these premises constitute a restaurant, tavern, hotel, club, place of public entertainment, or premises open to the public or on premises in any way licensed in any manner by the State of Maryland or Montgomery County. It is unlawful for any person to keep or consume any alcoholic beverage on any premises open to the public other than as specifically permitted or provided in this article. This subsection does not apply in a room of a registered guest in a hotel if the hotel meets the minimum requirements as set forth in § 6–201(q) of this article.

paragraph.text: The Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners may issue, renew, and transfer and otherwise provide for 8 classes of alcoholic beverages licenses in the City of Takoma Park as follows:

subparagraph.text: Class B (on–sale) beer and light wine, hotel and restaurant licenses;
Class H (on–sale) beer and light wine, hotel and restaurant licenses;
Class B (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor, hotel and restaurant licenses;
Class H–TP (on–sale) beer license;
Class D–TP (on– and off–sale) beer and light wine license;
Class A–TP (off–sale) beer, wine and liquor license;
Class C–TP (on–sale) beer, wine and liquor license; and
Beer and wine sampling or tasting (BWST) licenses issued under § 8–408.2 of this title.
The provisions of this paragraph apply only to Class –TP type licenses.

The Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners shall certify a list to the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners of the alcoholic beverages licenses as of June 30, 1997, in that portion of the City of Takoma Park that became part of Montgomery County on July 1, 1997.

On July 1, 1997, the Montgomery County Board shall issue Class –TP type licenses to those licensees who were certified by the Prince George’s County Board. License fees may not be charged until May 1, 1998.
Unless revoked or not renewed for good cause, the certified licenses shall continue in existence and be renewed, subject to payment of the annual license fee.

The Class –TP type licenses are not transferable to other locations but are transferable to other persons, subject to the restrictions on similar transfers for other alcoholic beverages licenses in Montgomery County.

Class –TP licenses are subject to the same conditions and restrictions specified by law or by the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners as are other licenses issued by the Board. However, the Board may waive whatever statutory and regulatory provisions it so chooses for the affected licenses so that equity, fairness, and reasonableness are achieved.
The Montgomery County Department of Health and Human Services may not charge an annual fee to the Class –TP licensees until January 1, 1998.

Notwithstanding that Class –TP licensees as of July 1, 1997 are subject to Montgomery County laws and regulations, those same licensees may retain the particular Prince George’s County alcoholic beverages license they possessed prior to unification.

The Prince George’s County license shall remain valid in every sense except that it does not apply to the licensed premises to which the Class –TP license applies, but is an open–location license. The Prince George’s County licensee may transfer, to another person or to a new location with the same licensee, the license into Prince George’s County without statutory or regulatory restriction.

While the Class –TP licensee remains in the same location where it was located on July 1, 1997, another license issued by Prince George’s County may not be granted or transferred to another Prince George’s licensee if the premises for which that license was issued is located within 300 feet of the premises licensed under the Class –TP license.

subsection.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue, renew, and transfer and otherwise provide a maximum of 2 Class H (on–sale) beer and light wine, hotel and restaurant licenses for use in the town of Laytonsville provided that:

paragraph.text: No license may be issued to any restaurant in which pool tables, billiard tables, shuffleboards, dart boards, video games, pinball machines, or recreational devices are used; and
Alcoholic beverages served by a licensee may only be consumed by patrons while patrons are seated.

subsection.text: The Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners may issue, renew, and transfer and otherwise provide Class H (on–sale) beer and light wine, hotel, and restaurant licenses for use in Damascus (12th election district) provided that:

paragraph.text: A license may not be issued to any restaurant in which pool tables, billiard tables, shuffleboards, dart boards, video games, pinball machines, or recreational devices are used; and
Alcoholic beverages served by a licensee may be consumed by a patron only while the patron is seated.

subsection.text: There is a special theater license.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners.
“Movie theater” means a building designed or used primarily for the exhibition of motion pictures to the general public.

subparagraph.text: “Performing arts theater” means those areas, buildings, or structures designed and used for plays, acts, dramas, or histrionics by actors or actresses performing on a stage.
“Performing arts theater” does not include either the showing or exhibition of motion pictures or a building or amphitheater that is part of a sports complex regularly used by minors.

subsection.text: The Board may issue a special theater (on-sale) beer and wine license for use on the premises of:

paragraph.text: A performing arts theater; or
A movie theater operated by a bona fide nonprofit organization.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, a holder of a special theater license is authorized to sell beer and wine at retail for on-premises consumption when snacks are served:

paragraph.text: 1 hour before and after a performance;
During intermissions; and
During cast parties and receptions before and after a performance.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $100.
A special theater (on-sale) beer and wine license may not be transferred from the location of original issuance to another location.
In this section, “Board” means the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.
There is a Special Class B – Corporate Training Center beer, wine and liquor (on–sale) license.

The Board may issue the license for use in a corporate headquarters support facility that serves only the workforce training and education needs of employees, customers, and visitors to the corporate headquarters of a corporation that employs at least 500 employees in the County.
Sales of alcoholic beverages under this section are only for on–premises consumption.
The annual license fee is $2,500.
In this section, “Board” means the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.
There is a special culinary school license.
The Board, by unanimous vote, may issue the license for use on the premises of a private culinary educational institution that:

paragraph.text: Is accredited by a nationally recognized accrediting association;
Is approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and
Holds a private educational institution license issued by Montgomery County.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $400.

paragraph.text: The license authorizes the holder to:

subparagraph.text: In connection with a wine tasting course offered by the license holder, allow the consumption of wine by individuals who are at least 21 years old and registered in the wine tasting course; and

In connection with a culinary or confectionary course offered by the license holder, allow the consumption of beer and wine by individuals who are at least 21 years old and registered in the culinary or confectionary course.

paragraph.text: An individual may consume beer or wine covered by a special culinary school license only on the licensed premises.
A license holder may conduct the activities specified in paragraph (1) of this subsection during the following hours:

subparagraph.text: On Monday through Thursday, from 9 a.m. to 1 a.m. the following day;
On Friday and Saturday, from 9 a.m. to 2 a.m. the following day; and
On Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 1 a.m. the following day.

paragraph.text: A license holder shall provide food during the hours alcoholic beverages are served.

subsection.text: A license holder may not simultaneously hold any other license issued under this article.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special art gallery beer and wine license to a nonprofit or for–profit retail business engaged in the display and sale of original artwork by an individual artist or a group of artists.
A business that displays and sells commercially prepared or mass–produced artistic products may not be issued the license.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a holder of the license may sell or serve beer and wine at retail for consumption on the premises when snacks are served during normal business hours but not later than midnight.
The annual license fee is $100.
The license may not be transferred from the location for which the license was originally issued to another location.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County it is unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years for any purpose, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., to enter or to remain upon any portion of the premises of the holder of any Class B or Class D beer, or beer and light wine license where the privileges conferred by the license are exercised, unless the person is in the immediate company of at least one of his parents, or of his legal guardian, or spouse.

In Prince George’s County, in addition to the other powers and duties conferred upon them, the Board of License Commissioners may prescribe such rules and regulations as they deem necessary, regarding the presence of any person under the age of 21 years on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages, in addition to or in lieu of the provisions stated in this section; and, the Board shall prescribe and have the power to enforce such rules and regulations as it may adopt for regulating the conduct of business by licensees and their employees and licensed premises in relation to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages, and for requiring the maintenance of records on the licensed premises by the license holder containing the names, addresses and ages of all persons employed by the licensee on the premises and such other regulations as may be deemed necessary for maintenance of standards for sanitation and health, including provisions for adequate and sanitary facilities for consumption of alcoholic beverages, for safe water and plumbing facilities, for proper utensil cleaning and storage, for refuse disposal and rodent control and for the preparation and service of meals or food with alcoholic beverages.

In Prince George’s County it is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to purchase alcoholic beverages, or to enter the premises of any holder of any alcoholic beverages license for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages or to misrepresent his age for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages, or to have alcoholic beverages on or about his person. It is unlawful for any person to misrepresent the age of a person under the age of 21 years for the purpose of obtaining alcoholic beverages for such person, or for any person to obtain alcoholic beverages for the use of a person under the age of 21 years.

In Prince George’s County, in addition to the other powers and duties conferred upon them, the Board of License Commissioners may prescribe rules and regulations concerning the granting and the date of issuing licenses when the actual use of the license is to be deferred until the completion of construction work or alteration on the premises; and further, said Board may prescribe rules and regulations concerning alterations and additions to any licensed premises and the use thereof; the provisions hereof shall not be construed to prevent the issuance, or renewal, of a license previously issued, or authorized for issuance, where the premises licensed or to be licensed are under construction or the alterations to be made therein are in progress.

Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, a person shall be entitled to enter or remain upon any portion of the premises of the holder of a license granted under this article regardless of age, provided that there is operated thereon a bona fide bowling alley and that such bowling alley is then in use.

subsection.text: A person or persons or body corporate may not sell directly or indirectly at any place within the corporate limits of the City of Hyattsville, or give away at any place of business in the City, any alcoholic beverages or any intoxicating drinks of any kind other than beer, light wine and on-sale liquor, the liquor being only for consumption on the immediate premises of a Class B license. The Board of License Commissioners for Prince George’s County may not issue any license, for the sale of any alcoholic beverages or intoxicating drinks of any kind, within the limits of the City of Hyattsville, other than beer, light wine and on-sale liquor, the liquor being only for consumption on the immediate premises of a Class B license, except that the Board may transfer one Class B beer, wine and liquor license with an off-sale privilege, as defined in § 6-201(r) of this article, for use within the corporate limits of the City of Hyattsville, for which the licensee shall pay an annual fee of $1,500.
Repealed.

Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the Prince George’s County Board of License Commissioners may not issue any class of alcoholic beverages license for use in a business establishment with a commercial fuel pump located on the premises that is used by the general public for the purchase of fuel.

paragraph.text: In Prince George’s County, if two corporations with direct or indirect interests in alcoholic beverages licenses for use by restaurants undergo a merger, consolidation, or share exchange that results in a single successor corporation during the time period beginning on September 1, 2007 and ending on June 1, 2008, the total number of alcoholic beverages licenses that the successor corporation may hold is the sum of the licenses held by the two corporations after the successor corporation was formed if the number of licenses held is 8 or less.
An indirect interest in a license is evidenced by any of the following relationships involving the licensee and another licensee or the licensee and an applicant for a license:

subparagraph.text: A common parent company;
A franchise agreement;
A licensing agreement;
A concession agreement;
Membership by the licensee and the other person in a chain of businesses commonly owned and operated and so portrayed to the public;
Sharing of directors or stockholders or sharing of directors or stockholders of parent companies or subsidiaries;
Common direct or indirect sharing of profit from the sale of alcoholic beverages; or
Sharing of a common trade name, trademark, logo, theme, or mode of operation identifiable by the public, except hotels and motels.

subsection.text: In the alcoholic beverage laws for Queen Anne’s County, the following words mean:

paragraph.text: The word “restaurant” as used in § 3-201 and in § 6-201 of this article, when applied to Queen Anne’s County, means a business establishment for the accommodation of the public, fully equipped with a proper and adequate dining room having a seating capacity of at least 12 persons and with sufficient facilities for preparing and serving meals, which has been approved by the Board of License Commissioners of Queen Anne’s County, wherein the average daily receipts from the sale of food comprise at least 51 percent of the average daily receipts of the business.

The word “hotel” as used in § 3-201 and § 6-201 of this article, when applied to Queen Anne’s County, means a building or structure erected or constructed for hotel purposes having 20 or more bedrooms providing services ordinarily found in hotels, for the accommodation of the public, containing a dining room with facilities for preparing and serving meals wherein the average daily receipts from the sale of food exceed the average daily receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages.

subsection.text: Holders of all classes of retail alcoholic beverages licenses in Queen Anne’s County may exercise their license privileges on Sunday from 8 a.m. until the closing hour permitted by that class of license during any other day of the week.

paragraph.text: Any licensee holding a Class B license, of any type, issued in Queen Anne’s County, biannually, on dates to be set by the Board of License Commissioners, shall file with the Board a sworn statement that the gross receipts from food sales in the restaurant for the six-month period immediately preceding the filing of this report, are in excess of the gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages. However, nothing prohibits the Board of License Commissioners from requiring more frequent sworn statements.

The Board may require any licensee to provide any supporting data as it, in its discretion, considers necessary in order to establish that the requirements of subsection (a) relating to the ratio of gross receipts from the sale of food to those from the sale of alcoholic beverages have been met.

As a prerequisite for the initial issuance of a Class B license, of any type issued in Queen Anne’s County, the applicants shall attest in a sworn statement that gross receipts from food sales in the restaurant will be in excess of the gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages.

In the event that a Class B licensee of any type issued in Queen Anne’s County fails to maintain gross receipts from the sale of food in excess of gross receipts from the alcoholic beverages during any six-month period, the Board, in its discretion, may revoke the license.

The Board of License Commissioners of Queen Anne’s County may authorize the issuance of an additional license to be known as a Class B-D beer, wine, and liquor license. This special license authorizes the holder to keep for sale, and sell, all alcoholic beverages at retail at the place described on the license for consumption on the premises. The holder of this license may also sell beer for consumption off the premises.

This license is issued only to establishments having facilities for preparing and serving food to the public, whose average daily gross receipts from the sale of food comprise at least 25 percent of the average daily gross receipts of the entire business and have been approved by the Board of License Commissioners for Queen Anne’s County.
All restaurants having a valid Class B beer, wine, and liquor license are entitled to exchange their current license for a Class B-D license.
The annual fee for this license is $1,800.

section.text: In St. Mary’s County, no license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be issued for the use of any corporation unless the owners of fifteen per centum (15%) of the total stock of such corporation are residents of St. Mary’s County. For the purposes of this section the term “resident” shall include all persons who have resided in St. Mary’s County for six months next preceding the application for a license.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Washington County.

paragraph.text: The operators of any amusement park, whether individual, association of individuals, or a corporation, may be entitled to a license for the sale of beer within the confines of its park.

The fee for such license shall be one hundred dollars ($100) each calendar year, and shall entitle the holder to sell beer at one or more locations within the park from 8 a.m. to midnight on every day from May 1 to September 30 of each year, except Sundays and election days.

Such licensees shall be subject to all laws, rules and regulations applicable in the county to the sale of beer, not inconsistent with the provisions of this section; nothing contained in § 9–102 of this article shall apply to any license issued pursuant to this section.
A separate license, called a Class P “pouring license” may be issued countywide by the Board of License Commissioners.
The holder of a Class P “pouring license” may only sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
The annual fee for each Class P “pouring license” is:

subparagraph.text: $350 for a beer license;
$400 for a beer and light wine license;
$750 for a beer, light wine, and liquor license; and
$250 for a Sunday sale license.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “premises” includes the entire stadium facility and the stadium parking lots.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a stadium (on–sale) license to the owner of a professional baseball team franchise.
The franchise may be in any form of business organization, including partnership, corporation, and limited liability company.
The annual fee is $2,000.
A license entitles the holder to sell beer and light wine:

subparagraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, for consumption on the licensed premises to persons present at any event held in the stadium;
In plastic, Styrofoam, or paper containers; and
From the time the stadium opens for the event until the event ends.

paragraph.text: The written approval of the Board of License Commissioners is required before beer and light wine may be sold, served, or consumed:

subparagraph.text: On the parking lots of the stadium; or
During any event other than a baseball game in which the team of the license holder is playing.

paragraph.text: Except for a wholesaler or distributor of beer and light wine that is conducting business with the license holder, the license holder may not allow any person to carry alcoholic beverages onto or from the licensed premises.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a sidewalk cafe license to a holder of a Class B or Class P “pouring license”.
A license entitles the holder to sell and serve alcoholic beverages in an area on the sidewalk directly in front of the licensed establishment.
The annual fee is $500.
A sidewalk cafe license may be issued only with an application for a Class B license or Class P “pouring license”.
To maintain a sidewalk cafe license, a holder:

subparagraph.text: Shall comply with all rules and regulations applicable to the issuance of the underlying Class B license or Class P “pouring license” and with all municipal ordinances and fire and health department regulations;
Shall ensure that at least one employee is certified by an alcohol awareness program and on the premises at all times during the operation of the sidewalk cafe; and
Shall keep the kitchen open during all hours of operation and have prepared meals available to be served in the sidewalk cafe.

paragraph.text: A holder may sell or serve alcoholic beverages in the sidewalk cafe from noon to midnight, every day of the week.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Wicomico County.

The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class B beer and light wine on-sale (stadium) license to the owner of any professional baseball team franchise, whether the franchise is a partnership or a corporation.
The license authorizes the holder to sell beer and, if sold with meals, light wine at the stadium:

paragraph.text: For consumption only on the licensed premises;
In plastic, Styrofoam, or paper containers on the stadium premises, except that glass containers may be used in an enclosed dining premises in which the patrons are seated;
To persons present:

subparagraph.text: At the baseball game in which the licensee’s team is playing; or
At other events that are held at the stadium; and

paragraph.text: During the hours and days for sale specified in § 11-523(c)(8) of this article.

subsection.text: The annual license fee is $2,000.

Except for a distributor of beer who is conducting business with the licensee for the purposes of this section, the licensee may not permit any person to carry any alcoholic beverages onto or from the licensed premises.

paragraph.text: This license may be issued only for a stadium that has the average daily receipts from the sale of food for each month exceed the average daily receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages.
In calculating average daily receipts from the sale of food, an allocation of foodstuff contained in a mixed drink may not be included in average daily receipts from the sale of food.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Worcester County.
There is a Class I beer, wine and liquor license.
A Class I beer, wine and liquor license may be issued only within:

paragraph.text: The corporate limits of Ocean City;
The boundary lines of the 10th election district;
The boundary lines of the 2nd precinct of the 3rd election district; or
The area bounded by Maryland Route 589 to the north and east, U.S. Route 50 to the south, and U.S. Route 113 to the west, all of which lie within the 1st precinct of the 3rd election district.
The annual license fee for the 6-day license is $2,500.
The annual license fee for the 7-day license is $3,000.

subsection.text: A licensee may sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption only.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, all license fees shall go to the general funds of the county.
If the licensed premises are in a municipal corporation, 75 percent of the fees shall go to that municipal corporation.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a licensee shall purchase all alcoholic beverages, except light wine and beer, from the Worcester County Department of Liquor Control.

Beginning on May 1, 2016, a licensee may elect to purchase wine and liquor from a licensed wholesaler or may continue to purchase all alcoholic beverages, except light wine and beer, from the Worcester County Department of Liquor Control.

paragraph.text: A licensee may purchase beer and light wine from a licensed wholesaler.
A licensee shall be charged not more than 85 percent of the retail price or any special sale price or discount price, whichever is lower, set by the Department for wine and liquor.

subsection.text: The hours for sale are as provided in § 11-524 of this article.
In this section, “Board” means the Allegany County Board of License Commissioners.
This section applies only in Allegany County.
The Board may issue annually one special festival license.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an applicant for a special festival license shall be a holder of an existing State retail alcoholic beverages license, State Class 3 winery license, or State Class 4 limited winery license issued under this article.
A special festival licensee shall:

paragraph.text: Only display and sell:

subparagraph.text: Wine that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: Manufactured and processed in any state;
Price filed in accordance with regulations adopted by the Comptroller; and
Distributed in the State at the time the application is filed; or

subparagraph.text: Beer that is brewed by a brewer:

sub-subparagraph.text: Who brews less than 60,000 barrels of beer annually; and
Whose product is distributed in the State at the time the application is filed;

paragraph.text: Display and sell beer and wine at retail for consumption on or off the licensed premises on the days and for the hours designated for the special festival; and
Display and sell wine that is manufactured and processed in any state at retail for consumption off the licensed premises on the days and for the hours designated for the special festival.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit the holder of a special festival license from holding another alcoholic beverages license of a different class or nature.
The Board:

paragraph.text: May establish the license fee;
May select one weekend, Friday through Sunday inclusive, annually for the special festival provided that the weekend that is selected does not occur on the same weekend as the Maryland Wine Festival;
Shall choose a location in the county that is not licensed under this article for the special festival; and
Shall assure that the primary focus of the special festival is the promotion of Maryland beer and wine.
Products displayed and sold shall be:

subparagraph.text: Invoiced to the special festival license holder by a licensed State wholesaler, winery, or limited winery; and
Delivered to the special festival from the licensed premises of the wholesaler, winery, or limited winery.

paragraph.text: Whenever a special festival license is issued under this subsection, holders of wholesale, winery, or limited winery licenses may enter into an agreement with the holder of a special festival license to deliver beer and wine 2 days prior to the effective date of the special festival license and to accept returns 2 days after the expiration date of the special festival license.

“Festival organization” means a nonprofit organization that is selected by Montgomery County to organize the festival and that has extensive experience in organizing and managing large-scale public events.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Montgomery County.

Under the supervision of the Montgomery County Department of Liquor Control, the county each year may conduct the Montgomery County Wine Festival on not more than 4 weekends that a festival organization selects.

A festival organization may contract with holders of a Montgomery County retail alcoholic beverage license, a State Class 3 winery license, or a State Class 4 limited winery license to sell and display wine at the festival.

paragraph.text: A festival organization, through contractors who hold a special festival license issued under subsection (g) of this section, may display and sell wine that is price filed in accordance with regulations adopted by the State Comptroller and distributed in the State.
Wine may be displayed and sold at retail for consumption on or off the premises on the days and for the hours designated for the festival.

subsection.text: A festival organization:

paragraph.text: Shall choose for the festival a location that is a licensed or an unlicensed premises in the county; and
Shall assure that the primary focus of the festival is the promotion of Montgomery County.
Before a person may sell, offer for sale, or display wine at a festival, the person must contract with the festival organization and obtain a special festival license from the Board.
The license fee is $30 for each day of the festival.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a person may hold a special festival license in addition to another license issued under this article.

The Board may deny a special festival license to any applicant, suspend or revoke a special festival license, or impose a fine not exceeding $20,000 if the applicant or license holder violates a provision of this article or the regulations of the Board.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, all license fees collected under this subsection shall be deposited into the general fund of the county.

May select one weekend annually during the month of June, July, or August for the Cumberland and Shenandoah Valley Wine Festival that does not conflict with the dates of the Maryland Wine Festival; and
Shall adopt regulations for the implementation of this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Washington County Board of License Commissioners.
“Festival” means the Washington County Wine Festival.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Washington County.
The Board may issue a special wine festival (WF) license.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, to be eligible for a special WF license, an applicant must be a holder of an existing State retail alcoholic beverages license, a State Class 3 winery license, or a State Class 4 limited winery license.
A special WF license entitles the holder to display and sell at retail wine for consumption on or off the premises on the days and for the hours designated for the festival in the county.

paragraph.text: The Board shall assure that the primary focus of the Festival is the promotion of Maryland wine.
A holder of a special WF license shall display and sell wine that is distributed in the State.

subsection.text: The special WF license fee is $20.
This section does not prohibit the holder of a special WF license from holding another alcoholic beverages license of a different class or nature.
The Board may choose 2 weekends annually for the festivals.
The Board shall choose locations in the county for the festivals that are not licensed under this article.
The Board shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Wicomico County Board of License Commissioners.
“Festival” means the Wicomico County Wine Festival.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Wicomico County.
The Board may issue a special WCWF license.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, to be eligible for a special WCWF license an applicant must be a holder of an existing State retail alcoholic beverages license, a State Class 3 winery license, or a State Class 4 limited winery license.
A holder of a special WCWF license shall:

paragraph.text: Display and sell wine that is:

subparagraph.text: Manufactured and processed in any state;
Price filed in accordance with regulations adopted by the Comptroller; and
Distributed in the State at the time the application is filed; and

paragraph.text: Display and sell wine at retail for consumption on or off the licensed premises on the days and for the hours designated for the Festival.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit the holder of a special WCWF license from holding another alcoholic beverages license of a different class or nature.
The special WCWF license fee is $50 per day.

paragraph.text: The Board shall choose:

subparagraph.text: One weekend, Friday through Sunday inclusive, annually for the Festival; and
A location for the Festival that is in the county but that is not licensed currently under this article.

paragraph.text: The Board shall assure that the primary focus of the Festival is the promotion of Maryland wine.
Products displayed and sold at the Festival shall be:

subparagraph.text: Invoiced to the holder of the special WCWF license by a licensed State wholesaler, winery, or limited winery; and
Delivered to the Festival from the licensed premises of the wholesaler, winery, or limited winery.

paragraph.text: Whenever a special WCWF license is issued, a holder of a wholesale, winery, or limited winery license may enter into an agreement with the holder of a special WCWF license to deliver wine 2 days before the effective date of the special WCWF license and to accept returns 2 days after the expiration date of the special WCWF license.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations to carry out this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Worcester County Board of License Commissioners.
“Festival” means:

subparagraph.text: The Worcester County Beer and Wine Festival (WBWF); or
A similar festival featuring beer and wine that the Board approves.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Worcester County.
The Board may issue not more than three special festival licenses each year.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an applicant for a special festival license shall be a holder of an existing State retail alcoholic beverages license, State Class 3 winery license, or State Class 4 limited winery license issued under this article.
A special festival licensee shall:

paragraph.text: Only display and sell:

subparagraph.text: Wine that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: Manufactured and processed in any state;
Price filed in accordance with regulations adopted by the Comptroller; and
Distributed in the State at the time the application is filed; and

subparagraph.text: Beer that is brewed by a brewer:

sub-subparagraph.text: Who brews less than 60,000 barrels of beer annually; and
Whose product is distributed in the State at the time the application is filed;

paragraph.text: Display and sell beer and wine at retail for consumption on or off the licensed premises on the days and for the hours designated for the Festival; and
Display and sell wine that is manufactured and processed in any state at retail for consumption off the licensed premises on the days and for the hours designated for the Festival.

subsection.text: This section does not prohibit the holder of a special festival license from holding another alcoholic beverages license of a different class or nature.
The Board:

paragraph.text: May establish the license fee;
May select one weekend, Friday through Sunday inclusive, annually for each Festival provided that the weekend that is selected does not occur on the same weekend as the Maryland Wine Festival;
Shall choose a location in the county for each Festival which is not licensed under this article; and
Shall assure that the primary focus of the Festival is the promotion of Maryland beer and wine.
Products displayed and sold shall be:

subparagraph.text: Invoiced to the festival license holder by a licensed State wholesaler, winery, or limited winery; and
Delivered to each Festival from the licensed premises of the wholesaler, winery, or limited winery.

paragraph.text: Whenever a festival license is issued pursuant to this subsection, holders of wholesale, winery, or limited winery licenses may enter into an agreement with the holder of a festival license to deliver beer and wine 2 days prior to the effective date, and to accept returns 2 days after the expiration date of the festival license.

subsection.text: The Board shall adopt regulations for implementing this section.
A bona fide nonprofit organization may receive a wine permit for a fund-raising event by applying to the alcoholic beverages licensing authority for the county in which the event is to be held.
The wine permit authorizes the holder to:

paragraph.text: Hold a fund-raising event on the federally bonded premises of a winery, provided the winery is operated under a Class 3 or Class 4 manufacturer’s license and holds a Class A light wine license; and
Purchase wine in sealed containers from the winery and sell the wine at the event in open containers at retail for consumption on the permit premises.

subsection.text: Each permit shall be cosigned by the winery hosting the event.
The permit fee under this section is $15.
A winery may not host more than 6 events under this section per calendar year.
This section applies only in Anne Arundel County.
In this section, “Board” means the Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners.

There is a Class BWST cordial, beer, and wine (on–premises) tasting license, a Class BWT beer and wine (on–premises) tasting license, a Class WS wine sampling (on–premises) license, and a Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license.

subparagraph.text: A Class BWST license may only be issued to a holder of a Class BWL beer, wine and liquor (on–premises) license.
A Class BWT license may only be issued to a holder of a Class BWL beer, wine and liquor (on–premises) license or a Class BW beer and wine (on–sale) license.

paragraph.text: The annual fee for a Class BWT license is $150.
The annual fee for a Class BWST license is $500.
The annual fee for a Class BWST or BWT license is in addition to the Class BWL or BW annual fee.
A Class BWST license authorizes a holder to permit the on–premises consumption of the following alcoholic beverages for tasting or sampling purposes only:

subparagraph.text: Liquor to be served in a quantity of not more than one–half ounce from each of any of five brands to any one person per day;
Light wine to be served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from each given brand to any one person; and
Beer to be served in a quantity of not more than 3 ounces to any one person.

paragraph.text: The Class BWT license authorizes a holder to permit the on–premises consumption of the following alcoholic beverages for tasting or sampling purposes only:

subparagraph.text: Light wine to be served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from each given brand to any one person; and
Beer to be served in a quantity of not more than 3 ounces to any one person.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a WS (wine sampling) license to bona fide nonprofit organizations.
The WS license authorizes the consumption of wine for tasting or sampling purposes:

subparagraph.text: On Class B beer and wine or beer, wine and liquor licensed premises with the consent of the licensee; or
On premises without a permanent alcoholic beverages license.

paragraph.text: The licensee may not serve more than 2 ounces from each brand to any 1 person.
The bona fide nonprofit organization:

subparagraph.text: Shall apply for a WS license at least 15 days prior to the day of issuance; and
May not be issued more than 12 WS licenses in any given license year.

paragraph.text: The daily license fee is $15.
The WS licensee may bring wine onto Class B licensed premises for sampling or tasting purposes only.
A Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license may only be issued to a holder of a Class BWL license or a holder of a Class BW license.

A Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license authorizes a holder to permit the on–premises consumption for tasting or sampling purposes only of light wine to be served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from each given brand to any one person.
The annual license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $150 for a holder of a Class BWL license; and
$50 for a holder of a Class BW license.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by:

paragraph.text: The provisions in subsection (b) of § 12–107 of this article; and
The provisions of law under § 9–102 of this article prohibiting the issuance of 2 licenses for the same premises.

subsection.text: In the City of Annapolis, the Mayor and City Council may approve the issuance of a BWT license or a WS license. The fees for the licenses shall be set by the Mayor and City Council.
This section applies only in Anne Arundel County.
In this section, “Board” means the Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners.
There is a Class BWT beer and wine (on–premises) tasting license, a Class WS wine sampling (on–premises) license, and a Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license.

paragraph.text: A Class BWT license may only be issued to a holder of a Class BWL beer, wine and liquor (on–premises) license or a Class BW beer and wine (on–sale) license.
The annual fee for a Class BWT license is:

subparagraph.text: $50 for a holder of a Class BWL license; and
$50 for a holder of a Class BW license.

paragraph.text: The annual fee for a Class BWT license is in addition to the Class BWL or BW annual fee.
The Class BWT license authorizes a holder to permit the on–premises consumption of the following alcoholic beverages for tasting or sampling purposes only:

subparagraph.text: Light wine to be served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from each given brand to any one person; and
Beer to be served in a quantity of not more than 3 ounces to any one person.

paragraph.text: The Board may issue a WS (wine sampling) license to bona fide nonprofit organizations.
The WS license authorizes the consumption of wine for tasting or sampling purposes:

subparagraph.text: On Class B beer and wine or beer, wine and liquor licensed premises with the consent of the licensee; or
On premises without a permanent alcoholic beverages license.

paragraph.text: The licensee may not serve more than 2 ounces from each brand to any 1 person.
The bona fide nonprofit organization:

subparagraph.text: Shall apply for a WS license at least 15 days prior to the day of issuance; and
May not be issued more than 12 WS licenses in any given license year.

paragraph.text: The daily license fee is $15.
The WS licensee may bring wine onto Class B licensed premises for sampling or tasting purposes only.
A Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license may only be issued to a holder of a Class BWL license or a holder of a Class BW license.

A Class WT wine tasting (on–premises) license authorizes a holder to permit the on–premises consumption for tasting or sampling purposes only of light wine to be served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from each given brand to any one person.
The annual license fee is:

subparagraph.text: $150 for a holder of a Class BWL license; and
$50 for a holder of a Class BW license.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by:

paragraph.text: The provisions in subsection (b) of § 12–107 of this article; and
The provisions of law under § 9–102 of this article prohibiting the issuance of 2 licenses for the same premises.

subsection.text: In the City of Annapolis, the Mayor and City Council may approve the issuance of a BWT license or a WS license. The fees for the licenses shall be set by the Mayor and City Council.
The Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners may issue a WS (wine sampling) license to bona fide nonprofit organizations.
The fee for this license is $15 per day.
The Board of License Commissioners may not grant more than 12 WS licenses to any 1 bona fide nonprofit organization in each license year.
Application shall be made for this license at least 15 days before the date on which the license is issued.
The WS license permits the transportation of wine and the consumption of wine for sampling purposes:

paragraph.text: On a Class B or Class B-D-7 licensed premises with the authorization of the respective holder; or
On a premises that is not permanently licensed under this article.

subsection.text: A holder may not serve more than 2 ounces of wine from a given brand to any one person.
The Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners may issue a 1-day Class BWT beer and wine (on-premises) tasting license.
The Board may issue a maximum of 12 Class BWT licenses per year.
The Board may issue a Class BWT license only to a Class A beer and light wine licensee or a Class A beer, wine and liquor licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board shall set a fee for a Class BWT license.
The fee for a Class BWT license is in addition to the Class A license annual fee.

subsection.text: A holder of a Class BWT license may permit on-premises consumption of the following alcoholic beverages for tasting or sampling purposes only:

paragraph.text: Light wine, served in a quantity of not more than 1 ounce from a given brand to any one person; and
Beer, served in a quantity of not more than 3 ounces from a given brand to any one person.

subsection.text: At the end of the day for which a license is valid, a holder of a Class BWT license shall dispose of unconsumed alcoholic beverages remaining in a container opened for tasting or sampling.
A Class BWT licensee is not restricted by:

paragraph.text: § 12-107(b) of this article; or
§ 9-102 of this article.

subsection.text: A Class BWT licensee may exercise the privileges under the Class BWT license only during the hours and days provided for under the respective Class A license.
This section applies only in:

paragraph.text: Ward 27, precincts 42 and 44 of the 41st Legislative District of Baltimore City;
Ward 27, precincts 41 and 48 of the 43rd Legislative District of Baltimore City; and
Ward 11, precinct 5 of the 44th Legislative District of Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City may issue a Class BWLT beer, wine, and liquor (on–premises) tasting license to a holder of a Class A beer, wine and liquor license.

paragraph.text: The fees for a Class BWLT license are as follows:

subparagraph.text: $20 for a daily tasting license, which may be issued not more than 12 times in any annual license year;
$200 annually for a 26–day tasting license, which may be used consecutively or nonconsecutively;
$300 annually for a 52–day tasting license, which may be used consecutively or nonconsecutively; and
$750 annually for a tasting license that may be used daily throughout the year.

paragraph.text: The fees for a Class BWLT license are in addition to the Class A annual license fee.
A Class BWLT license authorizes the holder to allow the on–premises consumption of beer, light wine, and liquor for tasting or sampling.
A person may consume beer, light wine, or liquor covered by a Class BWLT license in a quantity not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: 1 ounce of light wine from a given brand in a single day;
3 ounces of beer from a given brand in a single day; and
One–half ounce of liquor from a given brand in a single day.

subsection.text: At the end of each day for which a Class BWLT license is valid, the holder of the license shall dispose of any unconsumed alcoholic beverage remaining in a container that was opened for tasting or sampling.

paragraph.text: Each Class A license holder that seeks issuance of a Class BWLT license for which the holder is eligible shall apply for the license on forms provided by the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City.

The forms provided by the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City under paragraph (1) of this subsection for licenses issued under subsection (c)(1)(i) through (iii) of this section shall specify the date or dates on which the tasting is requested to occur.

The application and payment for the daily license under subsection (c)(1)(i) of this section shall be submitted at least 7 days in advance of the tasting event or 7 days in advance of the first day of consecutive day tasting events.
The application and payment for the 26–day tasting license and the 52–day tasting license shall be made at least 7 days in advance of the first proposed tasting event.

The holder of a 26–day tasting license and a 52–day tasting license shall notify the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City, on forms approved by the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City, of additional tasting events authorized by the licenses.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by:

paragraph.text: § 12–107(b) of this article; and
The provisions in § 9–102 of this article that prohibit the issuance of two licenses for the same premises.

subsection.text: The holder of a Class BWLT license may exercise the privileges of this section during the hours and days provided for under the holder’s respective Class A license.

paragraph.text: The Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners may issue a WS (wine sampling) permit to bona fide nonprofit organizations.
The WS permit authorizes the consumption of wine for tasting or sampling purposes:

subparagraph.text: On Class B licensed premises with the consent of the licensee; or
On premises without a permanent alcoholic beverages license.

paragraph.text: The permit holder may not serve more than 2 ounces from each brand to any 1 person.
The bona fide nonprofit organization:

subparagraph.text: Shall apply for a WS permit at least 15 days prior to the day of issuance; and
May not be issued more than 12 WS permits in any given license year.

paragraph.text: The permit fee is $30 per day.
The WS permit holder is authorized to bring wine onto Class B licensed premises for sampling or tasting purposes only.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by the provisions in subsection (b) of § 12-107 of this article.
This section applies in Baltimore County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class BWT beer and light wine (on–premises) tasting license to the holder of a Class A beer and light wine license.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a Class BWLT beer, wine and liquor (on–premises) tasting license to a holder of a Class A beer, wine and liquor license.

paragraph.text: The fees for a Class BWT and Class BWLT license are as follows:

subparagraph.text: $20 for a daily tasting license, which may be issued not more than 12 times in any annual license year;
$200 annually for a 26–day tasting license, which may be used consecutively or nonconsecutively;
$300 annually for a 52–day tasting license, which may be used consecutively or nonconsecutively; and
$400 annually for a 104–day tasting license, which may be used consecutively or nonconsecutively.

paragraph.text: The fees for a Class BWT license and Class BWLT license are in addition to the Class A annual license fee.
The Class BWT license authorizes the holder to allow the on–premises consumption of light wine or beer for tasting.
A person may consume light wine or beer covered by a Class BWT license in a quantity not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: 1 ounce of light wine from all brands in a single day; and
3 ounces of beer from all brands in a single day.

paragraph.text: The Class BWLT license authorizes the holder to allow the on–premises consumption of beer, light wine, and liquor for tasting or sampling.
A person may consume light wine, beer, or liquor covered by a Class BWLT license in a quantity not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: 1 ounce of light wine from all brands in a single day;
3 ounces of beer from all brands in a single day; and
One–half ounce of liquor from all brands in a single day.

subsection.text: At the end of each day for which a Class BWT or a Class BWLT license is valid, the holder of the license shall dispose of any unconsumed alcoholic beverage remaining in a container that was opened for tasting or sampling.

paragraph.text: Each Class A license holder that seeks issuance of a BWT or BWLT license for which they are eligible shall apply for the type of tasting license authorized by this section on forms provided by the Board of License Commissioners.
The forms provided by the Board of License Commissioners under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall specify the date or dates on which the tasting is requested to occur.
The application and payment for the daily license shall be submitted at least 7 days in advance of the tasting event or 7 days in advance of the first day of consecutive day tasting events.
The application and payment for the 26–day tasting license and the 52–day tasting license shall be made at least 7 days in advance of the first proposed tasting event.

The holder of a 26–day tasting license and a 52–day tasting license shall notify the Board of License Commissioners, on forms approved by the Board, of additional tasting events authorized by the licenses.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by:

paragraph.text: § 12–107(b) of this article; and
The provisions in § 9–102 of this article which prohibit the issuance of two licenses for the same premises.

subsection.text: The holder of a Class BWT or Class BWLT license may exercise the privileges of this section during the hours and days provided for under the holder’s respective Class A license.
This section applies only in Calvert County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a special beer, wine and spirits tasting (BWST) license to a holder of a Class A beer and wine license or a Class A beer, wine and liquor license.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a BWST license entitles a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A Class A beer and wine license to allow tastings of wine or beer and wine; and
A Class A beer, wine and liquor license to hold tastings of wine, beer and wine, or beer, wine and liquor.

paragraph.text: To hold a tasting, a holder of a BWST license shall provide alcoholic beverages to consumers at no charge.

subsection.text: A person may consume alcoholic beverages covered by a BWST license in a quantity not exceeding:

paragraph.text: 1 ounce from a single brand of beer or wine; and
One–half ounce from a single brand of any other alcoholic beverage.

subsection.text: A BWST license entitles the holder to hold tastings 365 days per year.
A single tasting held under a BWST license may not exceed 3 hours.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a BWST license shall submit to the Board of License Commissioners an application on the form that the Board of License Commissioners provides.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a BWST license without a hearing.
A renewal of a BWST license shall be made at the time that the Class A beer and wine or Class A beer, wine and liquor license is renewed.

subsection.text: The annual fee for a BWST license is:

paragraph.text: $200, if the license is used for wine;
$250, if the license is used for beer or wine; and
$300, if the license is used for beer, wine and liquor.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Caroline County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a 1-day Class BWTS beer and wine (on-premises) tasting or sampling license.

A Class BWTS license may be issued only to a holder of a current alcoholic beverages license or an organization that qualifies for a special Class C beer or Class C beer and wine license under § 7-101(b) of this article.
The license fee is $50.
A Class BWTS license authorizes the holder to permit the consumption of wine or beer for tasting or sampling, if the alcoholic beverages are given to consumers at no charge.
A person may consume wine or beer covered by a Class BWTS license in a quantity not exceeding:

paragraph.text: 1 ounce from a single brand of wine, and 4 ounces from all brands in a single day; and
3 ounces from a single brand of beer, and 8 ounces from all brands in a single day.

subsection.text: All consumption of alcoholic beverages shall occur on the licensed premises of the holder of the Class BWTS license.
The Board of License Commissioners need not publish an application for a Class BWTS license before granting the license.
A Class BWTS license may not be granted to a person more than 26 times in a calendar year.
At the end of the day for which a Class BWTS license is valid, the license holder shall dispose of unconsumed alcoholic beverages remaining in a container opened for tasting or sampling.

paragraph.text: In Carroll County, the Board of License Commissioners may approve the issuance of a wine tasting (WT) alcoholic beverages license.
The license is issued only to holders of a beer, wine and liquor (BWL) or a beer and wine (BW) license.

The license permits the consumption of wine authorized to be sold by the beer, wine and liquor license (BWL) or the beer and wine license (BW) for tasting or sampling purposes only and for which no consideration may be charged or exacted.
The Board of License Commissioners shall regulate:

subparagraph.text: The quantity of wine to be served to each person; and
The number of bottles of wine from which this quantity is being served.

paragraph.text: The annual license fee:

subparagraph.text: For holders of a BWL license, is $100 in addition to the cost of the BWL license; and
For holders of a BW license, is $100 in addition to the cost of the BW license.

subsection.text: The Carroll County Board of License Commissioners may adopt rules or regulations providing additional requirements to implement this section.
This section applies only in Dorchester County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a 1-day wine tasting (WT) alcoholic beverages license.

paragraph.text: A WT license may be issued only to a holder of a beer, wine and liquor (BWL) license, a beer and wine (BW) license, or a Class A wine (W) license.
A WT license permits the consumption of wine for tasting or sampling if:

subparagraph.text: The licensee is authorized to sell the wine; and
A consideration for the wine is not charged or exacted from the consumer.

subsection.text: A person may consume wine covered by a WT license in a quantity not exceeding:

paragraph.text: 1 ounce from a single brand; and
4 ounces from all brands in a single day.

subsection.text: The fee for a WT license is $25 per day.
The Board of License Commissioners may not require the publication of an application for a WT license before granting the license.
This section applies only in Dorchester County.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a beer and wine sampling or tasting (BWST) license to a holder of a Class A license to hold tastings or samplings of beer or wine.
A holder of a Class A beer license may use a BWST license to hold tastings or samplings of beer only.
A BWST license authorizes sampling or tasting of alcoholic beverages only on the licensed premises of the holder of a Class A license.
The alcoholic beverages shall be offered to consumers at no charge.

subsection.text: A person may consume alcoholic beverages covered by a BWST license in a quantity not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: 1 ounce from a single brand of wine; and
4 ounces from all brands of wine in a single day; and
3 ounces from a single brand of beer; and
8 ounces from all brands of beer in a single day.

paragraph.text: An application for a BWST license shall be made on a form supplied by the Board of License Commissioners.
A BWST license may be issued without a public hearing.
If an initial application for a BWST license is denied:

subparagraph.text: The applicant may resubmit the application; and
On request from the applicant, the Board shall hold a public hearing on the application before determining whether to issue the license.

paragraph.text: A renewal of a BWST license may be made at the time the holder’s Class A license is renewed.

subsection.text: The fee for a BWST license is:

paragraph.text: $150 for not more than 15 beer or wine tastings per year; or
$250 for not more than 30 beer or wine tastings per year.
The Board of License Commissioners may not require the publication of an application for a BWST license before issuing the license.
The holder of a BWST license shall notify the Board in writing at least 7 days before the event at which the license is to be used.

subsection.text: At the end of the day for which a BWST license is valid, the holder of the license shall properly dispose of alcoholic beverages that remain in a container opened for tasting or sampling.
This section applies only in Frederick County.
A beer and wine sampling or tasting (BWST) license may only be issued to a holder of a Class A license.
The annual license fee is $200.

paragraph.text: Applications for a BWST license shall be made on forms supplied by the Board of License Commissioners.
Renewals of the license may be made at the time the regular license is renewed.
A license may be granted without a hearing.
If application for a license is denied, the applicant may request a public hearing before the Board.
A holder of a BWST license may allow consumption by a single individual for sampling or tasting purposes of:

subparagraph.text: Not more than 1 ounce of a given brand of light wine; and
Not more than 3 ounces of a given brand of beer.

paragraph.text: A maximum of six bottles of wine may be opened at any one time.
The licensee shall notify the Board in writing at least 5 days prior to each event.
Once opened, each bottle used for the beer and wine sampling or tasting event shall be marked that it is to be used for that purpose only.
The contents of each bottle may not be mixed with any other bottle and all bottles shall be destroyed once they are empty.
A BWST license is for on-premises consumption only.
Sampling or tasting of beer or wine may not be conducted from a drive-through window.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Frederick County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a beer, wine and liquor tasting (BWLT) license.
A beer, wine and liquor tasting license may be issued only to a holder of a Class A beer, wine and liquor license.

A beer, wine and liquor tasting license authorizes the consumption of one–half an ounce of liquor from a given brand and 1.5 ounces from all brands by any one person in a single day for tasting and sampling purposes only.
The limitations on the consumption of beer and wine under § 8–406 of this subtitle apply to a beer, wine and liquor tasting license.
The Board shall set the annual fee for a beer, wine and liquor tasting license.
This section applies only in Frederick County.
The Board of License Commissioners may issue a 1–day multivenue wine (MVW) (on– and off–sale) license to a bona fide nonprofit organization.
A holder of an MVW license may conduct simultaneous wine events at not more than five venues that are:

paragraph.text: Within walking distance of each other; and
Located in districts that allow the consumption of wine.

subsection.text: Under regulations that the Board of License Commissioners adopts, a holder of an MVW license at each wine event:

paragraph.text: May sell wine by the glass for on–premises consumption or by the bottle for off–premises consumption;
May allow a holder of a Class 4 limited winery license to conduct a wine tasting; and
Shall prohibit a guest from transporting wine from one venue to another.
In Garrett County, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a wine and beer tasting alcoholic beverages license.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a license only to holders of a beer, wine and liquor license or a beer and wine license.

The license permits the consumption of wine or beer authorized to be sold by the beer, wine and liquor license or the beer and wine license for tasting or sampling purposes only and for which no consideration may be charged or exacted.
The Board of License Commissioners shall regulate:

subparagraph.text: The quantity of wine or beer to be served to each person; and
The number of bottles of wine or beer from which this quantity is being served.

paragraph.text: The annual license fee is $100 in addition to the cost of the beer, wine and liquor license or the beer and wine license.
In addition to the annual license fee, the Board of License Commissioners shall charge an issuing fee of $100 for a wine and beer tasting alcoholic beverages license.
The privileges granted by this wine and beer tasting license may not be exercised during the Maryland Wine Festival.

subsection.text: The Board of License Commissioners may adopt rules or regulations providing additional requirements to implement this section.
In Harford County, subject to the provisions of subsections (c) and (d) of this section, the Liquor Control Board may issue:

paragraph.text: A CWBT license to holders of a Class A1 BWL license; and
A WBT license to holders of a Class A BW license.
The CWBT license permits the on-premises consumption of cordials, wine, beer, and liquor for tasting or sampling purposes only.
The WBT license permits the on-premises consumption of wine and beer for tasting or sampling purposes only.
The holder of a Class A1 BWL license may apply for and the Liquor Control Board may issue a CWBT license that is effective for a maximum of:

subparagraph.text: Any 26 days in a licensing period;
Any 52 days in a licensing period; or
365 days in a licensing period.

paragraph.text: The fees for a CWBT license under this subsection are:

subparagraph.text: For a license that is effective for any 26 days in a licensing period, $125;
For a license that is effective for any 52 days in a licensing period, $200; and
For a license that is effective for 365 days in a licensing period, $400.

paragraph.text: The holder of a Class A BW license may apply for and the Liquor Control Board may issue a WBT license that is effective for a maximum of:

subparagraph.text: Any 26 days in a licensing period;
Any 52 days in a licensing period; or
365 days in a licensing period.

paragraph.text: The fees for a WBT license under this subsection are:

subparagraph.text: For a license that is effective for any 26 days in a licensing period, $100;
For a license that is effective for any 52 days in a licensing period, $150; and
For a license that is effective for 365 days in a licensing period, $225.

subsection.text: A licensee that is issued a CWBT or a WBT license under this section for any 26 days in a licensing period or any 52 days in a licensing period shall notify the Liquor Control Board at least 7 days prior to exercising the provisions of the tasting or sampling license, of the licensee’s intent to have a tasting or sampling.
Tasting and sampling servings per person are limited to:

paragraph.text: 1 ounce of each given brand of beer or wine;
One-half ounce of each given brand of cordial; and
One-half ounce of each brand of any other alcoholic beverage.

subsection.text: The Liquor Control Board may adopt regulations providing additional requirements to implement this subsection.
In Howard County, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a WS (wine sampling) license to bona fide nonprofit organizations.
The WS license permits the consumption of wine only for tasting or sampling purposes on Class B licensed premises with authorization of the licensee or on nonlicensed premises.
The licensee may not serve more than 2 ounces from each given brand to any one person.
The bona fide nonprofit organization shall apply for a WS license at least 15 days prior to the day on which the license will be used.
The Board of License Commissioners may not issue more than 12 WS licenses to any 1 bona fide nonprofit organization in any given license year.
The cost of the WS license is $15 per day.
The WS license shall permit the applicant to carry wine onto the premises for wine sampling purposes with the authorization of the owner or licensee of a Class B license.

paragraph.text: In Howard County, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a beer and wine tasting (BWT) alcoholic beverages license.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a BWT license may be issued to a holder of:

subparagraph.text: A Class A beer, wine and liquor (BWL) license; or
A Class A beer and wine (BW) license.

paragraph.text: A BWT license authorizes the on–premises consumption, for tasting or sampling only, of:

subparagraph.text: Beer; or
Wine containing not more than 15.5% of alcohol by volume.

paragraph.text: A holder of a BWT license may not serve:

subparagraph.text: Wine in a quantity of more than 1 ounce from each given brand and no more than 4 ounces from all brands to any one person in a single day; or
Beer in a quantity of more than 3 ounces from each given brand and no more than 8 ounces from all brands to any one person in a single day.

paragraph.text: The annual license fee for a BWT license is $100 in addition to the fee of any other alcoholic beverages license.
In Howard County, the Board of License Commissioners may issue a beer, wine and liquor tasting (BWLT) alcoholic beverages license.
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a BWLT license may be issued to a holder of a Class A beer, wine and liquor (BWL) license.
A BWLT license authorizes the on–premises consumption, for tasting or sampling only, of:

subparagraph.text: Beer;
Wine containing not more than 15.5% of alcohol by volume; or
Liquor.

paragraph.text: A holder of a BWLT license may not serve:

subparagraph.text: Wine in a quantity of more than 1 ounce from each given brand and not more than 4 ounces from all brands to any one person in a single day;
Beer in a quantity of more than 3 ounces from each given brand and not more than 8 ounces from all brands to any one person in a single day; or
Liquor in a quantity of more than 1/4 ounce from each given brand and not more than 1 ounce from all brands to any one person in a single day.

paragraph.text: The annual license fee for a BWLT license is $100 in addition to the fee for any other alcoholic beverages license.

subsection.text: The Howard County Board of License Commissioners may adopt rules or regulations providing additional requirements to implement this section.
This section applies only in Montgomery County.
In this section, “Board” means the Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board may issue a beer and wine sampling or tasting (BWST) license to a holder of a Class A license to hold tastings or samplings of beer or wine.
A holder of a Class A wine license may use a BWST license to hold tastings or samplings of wine only.

subsection.text: The annual license fee for a BWST license is $200.

paragraph.text: A BWST license authorizes sampling or tasting of alcoholic beverages only on the licensed premises of the holder of a Class A license.
A holder of a BWST license may allow consumption by a single individual for sampling or tasting purposes of not more than:

subparagraph.text: 1 ounce from a single brand of wine;
4 ounces from all brands of wine in a single day;
3 ounces from a single brand of beer; and
12 ounces from all brands of beer in a single day.

paragraph.text: Once opened, each bottle used for the beer and wine tasting or sampling shall be marked that it is to be used for that purpose only.
The holder of a BWST license shall notify the Board in writing at least 7 days before each sampling or tasting event.
An application for a BWST license shall be made on a form supplied by the Board.
A BWST license may be issued without a public hearing.
If an initial application for a BWST license is denied, the applicant may request a public hearing before the Board.
The Board may not require the publication of an application for a BWST license before issuing the license.
A renewal of a BWST license may be made at the time the holder’s Class A license is renewed.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section are not restricted by:

paragraph.text: § 12–107(b) of this article; and
The provisions in § 9–102 of this article that prohibit the issuance of two licenses for the same premises.
In Prince George’s County, the Board of License Commissioners may approve the issuance of a beer tasting license, a wine tasting license, and a beer/wine tasting license.

subparagraph.text: A wine tasting or beer/wine tasting license is issued only to holders of a beer, wine and liquor (BWL) or a beer and wine (BW) license.

sub-subparagraph.text: A beer tasting or beer/wine tasting license is issued only to holders of a beer, wine and liquor (BWL) or a beer and wine (BW) license.
Holders of a beer (B) license may be issued only a beer tasting license.

subparagraph.text: A wine tasting or beer/wine tasting license permits the consumption of wine, containing not more than 15.5 percent of alcohol by volume, for tasting or sampling purposes only.
A beer tasting or beer/wine tasting license allows the consumption of beer for tasting or sampling purposes only.
