In Harford County no retail license which has been previously refused, suspended or revoked, shall be granted until the applicant shall have executed a bond to the State of Maryland in the penal sum of $1,000, with a corporate surety to be approved by the Liquor Control Board of Harford County, conditioned upon the faithful observance of all the laws of this State, general or local, and the regulations of the Board, controlling or affecting the sale of alcoholic beverages, and to pay all costs, fines and penalties which may be imposed upon the applicant, on any warrant or indictment for violation of this article or any other act of assembly or regulation of the Board relating to selling or furnishing alcoholic beverages in Harford County. The bond, when so approved, shall be deposited with the Board and recorded in a book to be kept for that purpose, and the record thereof, or a duly certified copy, shall be evidence in any court of record. If this bond has been provided for one calendar year and the Liquor Control Board finds that the licensee has complied faithfully with the terms thereof, then thereafter the Liquor Control Board may in its discretion waive the requirements of posting bond under this section. In the event of the failure to observe the terms of the bond and after due notice, the Liquor Control Board may file a petition for a forfeiture with the Circuit Court for Harford County. If the circuit court declares it forfeited, the bond shall belong to the Liquor Control Board. In lieu of the foregoing bond, the Liquor Control Board of Harford County may, in its discretion, accept $1,000 cash money, the deposit of the same to be deposited, conditioned, recorded and, if deemed advisable, waived. The Board may also, in its discretion, subsequently accept a bond as aforesaid in substitution of the cash money deposit.

section.text: Every person, who within this State, shall manufacture, rectify, blend, import, distribute, transport, store, warehouse, sell or offer for sale alcoholic beverages, or who is the holder of a license permitting the doing of any such acts, shall keep complete and accurate records of all alcoholic beverages purchased, sold, manufactured, rectified, blended, improved, brewed, fermented, distilled, produced, stored, warehoused, withdrawn from storage, imported or transported, and report (under oath if the Comptroller deems advisable) at any time, and from time to time, upon written request of the Comptroller, on forms prescribed by the Comptroller, any information relating to alcoholic beverages for which the records prescribed by this section are required to be kept. Such records shall be of a kind and in the form prescribed by the Comptroller and shall be safely preserved for two (2) years in such a manner as to insure permanency and accessibility for inspection by the Comptroller or any duly authorized employee of said Comptroller during all regular business hours. All records of license holders shall be kept and maintained at the location designated in the license and shall be available for audit or inspection by the Comptroller or his duly authorized representative during all regular business hours. Provided, however, where a person is permitted to have more than one location the records may be kept at the principal location. In addition to the other penalties provided by this article, the Comptroller shall have power to suspend immediately, without a hearing, for a period not exceeding thirty days, the license of any licensee who shall fail to comply with the provisions of this section, and such license may be further suspended or revoked after hearing, as elsewhere in this article provided.

subsection.text: Every common carrier, by rail, air, water or highway, transporting alcoholic beverages, either in interstate or intrastate commerce, to points within the State of Maryland, and every person transporting alcoholic beverages by any means within the State of Maryland, shall at any time and from time to time, upon written request of the Comptroller, report under oath on forms prescribed by the Comptroller, all such consignments or deliveries of alcoholic beverages, for such period as the Comptroller may specify.
If required by the Comptroller, the reports shall show:

paragraph.text: The name and address of the person to whom the deliveries of alcoholic beverages have actually and in fact been made;
The name and address of the original consignee, if alcoholic beverages have been delivered to any other person than the originally named consignee;

The point of origin, the point of delivery, the date of delivery and the number and initials of each car, if shipped by rail, the name of the boat, barge or vessel, if shipped by water, the license number of each truck, if shipped by motor truck, or if delivered by other means, the manner in which the delivery was made;
The kind of alcoholic beverages and the number of gallons of each contained in any such shipment or shipments; and
Any other additional information relative to shipments that the Comptroller may require.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section may be construed to authorize:

paragraph.text: The consignment of alcoholic beverages from any point outside of the State to points within the State of Maryland, to any person except:

subparagraph.text: The holder of a permit or manufacturer’s or wholesaler’s license, duly issued under this article; or
A consumer under Title 7.5 of this article; or

paragraph.text: The consignment of alcoholic beverages from any point within this State to a point outside the State, to any person not authorized to receive the same under the law of the point of destination.

section.text: The Comptroller shall include in his annual reports statements giving statistical information as to the alcoholic beverages business in this State, which, in his opinion, shall be of interest to the public and industry; it being the intent and purpose of this section to furnish a basis for annual comparison as to the scope of the industry in Maryland, and the consuming habits of Maryland residents.

subsection.text: The Comptroller, local licensing boards, and license issuing authorities shall severally keep an accurate record of every license issued or approved by them, respectively, under this article. The Comptroller and boards shall also keep an accurate record of all revocations, suspensions and cancellations of licenses and of all restrictions imposed upon any license, with a brief notation as to the cause for such action, and the boards shall in each case, forthwith report the same to the Comptroller. Such records shall be open to inspection at the respective offices of the Comptroller, board, or license issuing authority during regular business hours, by any person.

The records of licenses which are required to be maintained by subsection (a) of this section, and any indices or dockets created pursuant thereto, shall be retained for a period of three (3) years following the date of the last record entry therein and until all audit requirements have been complied with, and thereafter may be destroyed after compliance with the provisions of Title 10, Subtitle 6, Part V of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: For the jurisdictions in which this section is effective, the Governor, biennially, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, if in session, and if not in session, then the Governor alone, shall appoint three persons who shall constitute and be styled “The Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City or ............... County”, as the case may be.
In making the appointments, the Governor shall designate one of the appointees in Baltimore City and each of the counties to be the chairman of the respective boards.

The commissioners shall be residents and voters of Baltimore City or the respective counties, as the case may be, and they shall be persons of high character and integrity and of recognized business capacity.

In the case of any vacancies in the number of the license commissioners in Baltimore City or in any county which occur when the legislature is not in session, the Governor shall appoint some eligible person to fill the vacancy during the remainder of the term of office of the person originally appointed.
This subsection applies only in Allegany County.
Appointments shall be for terms of 6 years each. The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms of the members of the Board on January 1, 1994.

Two of the members of the Board of License Commissioners shall be members of that political party which at the last preceding general election in Allegany County polled the greatest number of votes in the aggregate for the several offices of County Commissioner therein. The third member of the Board of License Commissioners shall be a member of that political party which at the last preceding general election in Allegany County polled the second highest number of votes in the aggregate for the several offices of County Commissioner therein.
In Anne Arundel County not more than two members of the Board of License Commissioners shall belong to the same political party.
The provisions of § 15-107 of this article apply in the City of Annapolis.

subsection.text: The provisions of this section apply in Baltimore City.
The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Baltimore County.

paragraph.text: In Calvert County, 1 regular member of the Board shall always be a member of that political party which at the last preceding gubernatorial election polled the second highest number of votes throughout the State for that office.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the regular members appointed to the Board, the Governor shall appoint an alternate Board member.
The alternate Board member’s term shall run concurrently with the terms of the regular members serving in office on July 1, 1986.
The alternate Board member serves on the Board in the absence of a regular Board member.
When serving on the Board, the alternate Board member has all of the powers and responsibilities of a regular Board member.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Caroline County.
The members of the Liquor Control Board constitute the Board of License Commissioners.
The term of office for the members of the Board is 3 years.

Appointments to the Board shall be made by the Governor with the advice and consent of the House of Delegates, if in session, and if not in session, the Governor shall make the appointments which shall continue in force until the end of the next session of the General Assembly.

subparagraph.text: A substitute member of the Board shall be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the House of Delegates, if in session, and if not in session the Governor shall make the appointment which shall continue in force until the end of the next session of the General Assembly.
The term of office of the substitute member shall be 3 years from the first Monday in May.

In the event of the temporary or permanent incapacity, from any cause, of a regular member of the Board, or in the event of a vacancy from any cause on the regularly constituted Board, the substitute member upon the request of the chairman or the majority of the Board shall serve in the place of the regular member so incapacitated or causing the vacancy until the incapacity has terminated or the vacancy has been filled.
While serving, the substitute member has all the powers and authority and is subject to all the duties imposed by law upon a regularly appointed member of the Board.

subsection.text: The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Carroll County.
The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Cecil County.
The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Charles County.
The provisions of § 15-105 of this article apply in Dorchester County.
The provisions of § 15-103 of this article apply in Frederick County.
The provisions of § 15-108 of this article apply in Garrett County.
The provisions of § 15-201(c)(6) of this article apply in Harford County.
Repealed.

The provisions of § 15-105 of this article apply in Kent County until the Board of County Commissioners passes the resolution for which provision is made by Chapter 236 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1991.
The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies in Prince George’s County.

subparagraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners consists of 5 members.

The Governor shall appoint 4 of the 5 Commissioners from the political party obtaining the highest number of votes in the last gubernatorial general election in the county, and the Governor shall appoint 1 Commissioner from the political party obtaining the next highest number of votes in the county election.

Before making the appointments or filling any vacancy, the Governor shall request the central committees for Prince George’s County representing each of the 2 leading political parties of the State to designate at least 4 eligible candidates for each position; and the Governor shall appoint one of the persons so designated unless in his judgment all of the persons are unfit or incompetent, in which case he shall file a written statement to that effect with the Secretary of State. The statement shall set forth the facts and the grounds therefor and shall call upon the committees for Prince George’s County for another list of 6 names for each position to be filled, from which list and the original list the Governor shall make the appointments.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years. The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1985.
Not more than 4 of the appointees shall belong to the same political party.

subsection.text: The provisions of § 15-104 of this article apply in Queen Anne’s County.
The provisions of § 15-102 of this article apply in St. Mary’s County.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subsection apply only in Somerset County.
The Governor shall appoint three persons who constitute the Board of License Commissioners and who hold office for terms of 2 years each.
The appointments are subject to confirmation by the Senate of Maryland.
One of the members of the Board shall be designated as its chairman, and not more than two members of the Board shall belong to the same political party.

subsection.text: In Talbot County the appointments shall be for terms of 6 years. The Board shall organize by electing its own chairman.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subsection apply only in Washington County.
All terms shall be for 6 years and the terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms of the members of the Board on January 1, 1994.
No more than two of the appointees shall belong to the same political party.
This subsection applies only in Wicomico County.
The Governor shall appoint three persons, subject to the advice and consent of the Senate, who constitute the Board of License Commissioners.

subparagraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members continue to be staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1994.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

paragraph.text: One of the members of the Board shall be designated as its chairman.
This subsection applies only in Worcester County.

subparagraph.text: The Governor shall appoint three persons who constitute the Board of License Commissioners and who hold office for terms of 4 years each.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms of the members of the Board on January 1, 1994.

paragraph.text: The appointments are subject to confirmation by the Senate of Maryland.
One of the members of the Board shall be designated as its chairman.

subparagraph.text: In addition to the regular members appointed to the Board, the Governor shall appoint an alternate Board member.
The alternate Board member’s term shall run concurrently with the term of the regular members.
The alternate Board member shall serve on the Board in the absence of a quorum of the regular members due to illness or conflict of interest.
When serving on the Board, the alternate Board member has all of the powers and duties of a regular Board member.

paragraph.text: There is a Board of License Commissioners in St. Mary’s County known as the Alcohol Beverage Board of St. Mary’s County.
The Board consists of 5 members.
The Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate, shall appoint the members of the Board as follows:

subparagraph.text: 1 shall be appointed from each of the County Commissioner districts; and
1 shall be appointed at large.

paragraph.text: To qualify for appointment to the Board a person:

subparagraph.text: Shall be of good moral character and integrity;
Shall be at least 21 years of age; and
Shall be a resident of the Commissioner district at the time of appointment and during the term of office.
Except for the new Board appointed in accordance with this section, the term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on January 1, 1986.
A member appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve the remainder of the unserved term. A member so appointed is eligible to serve the next consecutive term if otherwise qualified and appointed.
A member may not serve more than 2 consecutive terms.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, or willful neglect of a duty required by law.
The removal procedure is as provided in § 15-110 of this article.

subsection.text: The member who is appointed at large is the Chairman.

paragraph.text: A majority of the members serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet a minimum of once a month.
All hearings held by the Board shall be open to the public.
The Board may appoint advisory committees composed of responsible persons in the county to advise the Board on matters relating to the administration of the alcoholic beverages laws.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners:

paragraph.text: Shall set the annual salary for the Chairman and each member of the Alcoholic Beverage Board; and
Shall provide for the reasonable and necessary expenses of the Alcoholic Beverage Board.
The Board shall appoint an attorney for the Board.
The County Commissioners shall set the annual salary for the attorney.
The Board shall appoint an inspector.
The County Commissioners shall set the salary of the inspector.
An inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: Possess the power of a peace officer of this State in respect to the enforcement of the alcoholic beverages laws of St. Mary’s County; and
Have the duties that the Board prescribes.

paragraph.text: The Board shall appoint an administrator.
The administrator shall carry out the duties assigned by the Board.
The County Commissioners shall set the salary of the administrator.
The County Commissioners may assign clerical assistance as is necessary to carry out the duties of the Board.

subparagraph.text: A member may not have any interest, direct or indirect, either proprietary or by means of any loan, mortgage or lien, in or to any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold; nor shall he have any interest, direct or indirect, in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or own any stock in any corporation which has any interest, proprietary or otherwise, direct or indirect, in any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold or in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or hold any elective public office or employment.

A person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, any agent or employee of that person or corporation, and any licensee licensed under the provisions of this article may not, either directly or indirectly, offer to pay any commission, profit or remuneration or make any gift to any member or Board employee or to anyone on behalf of such members or Board employee.

paragraph.text: Violations of this subsection are a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.
There is a Board of License Commissioners in Frederick County.
The Board consists of 3 members.
The Governor shall appoint the members of the Board.
To qualify for appointment to the Board, a person:

subparagraph.text: Shall be of good moral character and integrity;
Shall reasonably reflect the citizenry of the county; and
Shall be a registered voter of the county and shall continue to be a registered voter of the county during the person’s term of office.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1989.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Governor may remove a member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of a duty required by law, unprofessional conduct, or dishonorable conduct.
The removal procedure is as provided in this article.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a chairperson.

paragraph.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The Board shall meet at least once a month.
The chairperson of the Board shall receive an annual compensation of $7,000 and be reimbursed for reasonable expenses.
The members shall receive an annual compensation of $6,500 and be reimbursed for reasonable expenses.
The Governor shall appoint 1 alcoholic beverages inspector, with the advice and consent of:

subparagraph.text: The Senate; or
If there is no resident Senator, then with the consent of the members of the Frederick County delegation of the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: To qualify for appointment as an alcoholic beverages inspector, a person:

subparagraph.text: Shall be of high moral character;
Shall possess a sound reputation for sobriety, honesty, and integrity; and
Shall devote full time to the duties of the office.
The term of an inspector is 5 years.
An inspector who is appointed after a term has begun serves only until a successor is appointed.

paragraph.text: The Governor may remove an inspector with the advice and consent of:

subparagraph.text: The Senate; or
If there is no resident Senator, then with the consent of the members of the Frederick County delegation of the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: Grounds for removal are:

subparagraph.text: Incompetence;
Misconduct while performing the duties as an inspector;
Neglect of a duty required by law; or
Unprofessional or dishonorable conduct in performing the duties as an inspector.
An inspector shall receive an annual salary as set by the County Commissioners, be reimbursed for reasonable expenses, and receive mileage at the standard rate set by the County Commissioners.
Mileage does not include travel to and from the inspector’s home and office.

paragraph.text: An inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: Possess the power of a peace officer of this State with respect to the enforcement of the alcoholic beverages laws of Frederick County;
Make monthly reports in writing to the Board covering the activities and setting forth any complaints or violations that may have been observed or reported;
Assist the Board in enforcing the alcoholic beverages laws; and
Have any other duties as the Board may prescribe.

paragraph.text: The Board may appoint not more than two part–time alcoholic beverages inspectors.
To qualify for appointment as a part–time alcoholic beverages inspector, a person shall:

subparagraph.text: Be of high moral character; and
Possess a sound reputation for sobriety, honesty, and integrity.

paragraph.text: A part–time alcoholic beverages inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: Possess the power of a peace officer of the State with respect to the enforcement of the alcoholic beverages laws of Frederick County;
Make monthly reports in writing to the Board covering the activities and setting forth any complaints or violations that may have been observed or reported;
Assist the Board in enforcing the alcoholic beverages laws; and
Have any other duties that the Board may require.

paragraph.text: A part–time inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: Receive the compensation set by the County Commissioners and provided for in the county budget;
Be reimbursed for reasonable expenses; and
Receive reimbursement for mileage at the standard rate set by the County Commissioners.

paragraph.text: Reimbursement for mileage does not include travel to and from the part–time inspector’s home and office.

subsection.text: The chairperson of the Board, with the approval of the County Commissioners, may employ the clerical assistants necessary to carry out the duties of the Board and the salary of the clerical assistants shall be set by the County Commissioners and provided for in the county budget.

subparagraph.text: A Commissioner, full–time or part–time inspector, or employee of the Board may not:

sub-subparagraph.text: Have any interest, directly or indirectly, either proprietary or by means of any loan, mortgage, or lien, or in any other manner, in or to any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold;
Have any interest, directly or indirectly, in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages; or

Own any stock in any corporation which has any interest, proprietary or otherwise, directly or indirectly, in any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold or in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or hold any other public office or employment.

subparagraph.text: A Commissioner, full–time or part–time inspector, or employee of the Board may not solicit or receive, directly or indirectly, any commission, remuneration, or gift whatsoever from any person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, from any licensee, licensed under the provisions of this article.

A person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, any agent or employee of that person or corporation, and any licensee licensed under the provisions of this article may not, directly or indirectly, offer to pay any commission, profit, or remuneration or make any gift to any Commissioner, full–time or part–time inspector, or employee of the Board.

paragraph.text: Violations of this subsection are a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.

In Carroll County, the Board of County Commissioners shall appoint three persons, designating one of them as chairman, who shall constitute the Board of License Commissioners for said county; the first member of the Board to be appointed for one, two and three year terms, respectively and their successors thereafter for terms of three years each. The Board shall meet at least once a month.

subparagraph.text: The Carroll County Board of County Commissioners shall appoint 1 additional member to the Board of License Commissioners to serve as a substitute member in the event that any of the regular members are absent or incapacitated.
The Carroll County Commissioners shall set the additional member’s salary on a per diem basis and provide a term of office for that member.

paragraph.text: In Cecil County, the Board of County Commissioners shall appoint three persons, all of whom are to be of high moral character and possess a sound reputation for integrity, to constitute the Board of License Commissioners for the county.
The members of the Board shall designate their own chairman.

subparagraph.text: The members of the Board shall be appointed for 3–year staggered terms.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners shall meet at least once a month.

subparagraph.text: In Charles County, the Board of County Commissioners shall appoint five persons, who constitute the Board of License Commissioners for the county.

sub-subparagraph.text: Each member of the Board shall be a registered voter of the county.
Of the Board members, at least one member shall be appointed from each of the County Commissioner districts, and one member shall be appointed at large.
Preferably, at least one of the Board members shall have some familiarity or experience with the alcoholic beverages industry prior to the time of appointment.
Each member of the Board serves a term of 4 years, except that the initial term of one member authorized on October 1, 1993 shall be for 2 years.
A member may not serve more than two consecutive terms.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members on October 1, 1993.

subparagraph.text: The Board annually shall elect one of its members as chairman. A person may serve no more than 2 consecutive years as chairman.

Three members of the Board constitute a quorum for transacting business. At least three members who are present at the hearing concerning an alcoholic beverages license must concur in the approval, denial, revocation, suspension, or reclassification of that license.
The Board shall meet at least once a month.

No Commissioner shall have any interest, direct or indirect, either proprietary or by means of any loan, mortgage or lien, or in any other manner, in or to any premises where alcoholic beverages are sold; nor shall he have any interest, direct or indirect, in any business wholly or partially devoted to the sale of alcoholic beverages, or own any stock in any corporation which has any interest, proprietary or otherwise, direct or indirect, in any premises where alcoholic beverages are sold or in any business wholly or partially devoted to the sale of alcoholic beverages, or hold any other public office or employment.

No Commissioner shall solicit or receive directly or indirectly, any commission, remuneration or gift whatsoever from any person, or corporation engaged in the sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, nor from any agent or employee of such person or corporation, or from any licensee, licensed under the provisions of this article. No person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, nor any agent or employee of such person or corporation, and no licensee licensed under the provisions of this article, shall, either directly or indirectly, offer to pay any commission, profit or remuneration or make any gift to any Commissioner to anyone on behalf of such Commissioners.
A License Commissioner violating the provisions of this paragraph shall be removed from this appointed office.

paragraph.text: In Montgomery County, the Board of License Commissioners consists of 5 members, appointed by the county executive, subject to confirmation by the county council.

Each member of the Board serves a term of 4 years, except that the term of one member who is appointed or reappointed to fill one of the terms expiring in 1983 shall be for 3 years, and 4 years thereafter.
Not more than three members of the Board shall be members of the same political party.
The Board annually shall elect one of its members as chairman.

Three members of the Board constitute a quorum for transacting business. At least three members who are present at the voting session must concur in the approval, denial, revocation, suspension, or reclassification of an alcoholic beverage license.
Each member of the Board shall be a registered voter of the county.

subsection.text: In Queen Anne’s County, the Board of County Commissioners shall appoint 5 persons, designating 1 of them as chairman, who shall constitute the Board of License Commissioners for the county. At least 2 of the persons shall be a member of that political party which, at the most recent gubernatorial election, shall have received the second highest number of votes cast in Queen Anne’s County for the office of Governor. They shall be appointed for terms of 4 years each. In the event that at any time any member of the Board shall refuse or for any reason be unable to serve, the appointment for the unexpired term shall be made by said Board of County Commissioners. A quorum is 3 or more members for purposes of transacting the Board’s business. At least 3 members who are present at any voting session must concur in the approval, denial, revocation, suspension, or reclassification of an alcoholic beverages license.

In Baltimore County, the county executive shall appoint biennially three persons who shall constitute the Board of License Commissioners for the county. The Board shall appoint no less than four but no more than fifteen liquor inspectors for the county.

In Baltimore County, the county executive shall appoint biennially two substitute members to the County Board of License Commissioners. A substitute, designated by the Chairman of the Liquor Board, shall serve whenever a regular member is absent or incapacitated, for any reason, or in the event a vacancy is created. A substitute shall serve until either the regular member’s incapacity or absence ceases or the vacancy is filled. While serving on the Board, a substitute has all the powers, authority, and duties of a regularly appointed member. A substitute member shall receive a per diem salary set by the Board for each day actually served, but a substitute’s salary may not exceed the daily salary of a regular member.
The respective Boards of County Commissioners shall ex officio constitute the Boards of License Commissioners in Dorchester and Kent counties.

paragraph.text: In Dorchester County, the County Commissioners may appoint a substitute member to the Board of License Commissioners.
The substitute member shall be from the same County Commissioner district as the appointing County Commissioner.
The substitute member serves at the will of the appointing County Commissioner and shall serve for as long as the appointing County Commissioner remains in office as County Commissioner.
The substitute member has all the powers, authority, and duties of the appointing commissioner when acting on the Board.

section.on-what: in effect upon passage of Kent County Resolution
section.caption: NOT IN EFFECT
section.text: ** CONTINGENCY – NOT IN EFFECT – CHAPTER 236 OF 1991 **

paragraph.text: In Kent County, there is a Board of License Commissioners.
The Board consists of 3 members.
The Kent County Commissioners shall appoint the members of the Board.
To qualify for appointment to the Board, a person:

subparagraph.text: Shall be of good moral character and integrity;
Shall reasonably reflect the citizenry of the county; and
Shall be a registered voter of the county and shall continue to be a registered voter of the county during the person’s term of office.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on July 1, 1991.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Kent County Commissioners may remove a member for:

subparagraph.text: Incompetence;
Misconduct;
Neglect of a duty required by law;
Unprofessional conduct; or
Dishonorable conduct.

paragraph.text: The removal procedure is as provided in this article.

subsection.text: The Board shall elect a chairman from among its members.

paragraph.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
The chairman and members of the Board shall receive an annual compensation of $300.

subsection.text: The Board, with the approval of the County Commissioners, may employ the clerical assistants necessary to carry out the duties of the Board. The salary of the clerical assistants shall be set by the County Commissioners and as provided in the county budget.

subparagraph.text: A Commissioner, liquor inspector, or employee of the Board may not:

sub-subparagraph.text: Have any interest, directly or indirectly, either proprietary or by means of any loan, mortgage, or lien, or in any other manner, in or to any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold;
Have any interest, directly or indirectly, in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages; or

Own any stock in any corporation which has any interest, proprietary or otherwise, directly or indirectly, in any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold or in any business wholly or partly devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, or hold any other public office or employment.

subparagraph.text: A Commissioner, liquor inspector, or employee of the Board may not solicit or receive, directly or indirectly, any commission, remuneration, or gift from any person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, from any licensee, licensed under this article.

A person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, any agent or employee of that person or corporation, and any licensee licensed under this article may not, directly or indirectly, offer to pay any commission, profit or remuneration or make a gift to a Commissioner, liquor inspector, or employee of the Board.

paragraph.text: A violation of this subsection is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.

section.text: In Annapolis, the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Annapolis may constitute the Board of License Commissioners for the City or may delegate all or any portion of the authority to regulate alcoholic beverage licensees to a subsidiary board established by the Mayor and Aldermen. The Board of License Commissioners of Anne Arundel County shall have no jurisdiction in the City of Annapolis.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means Howard County.
“County Council” means the County Council for Howard County.
“Hearing Board” means the Appointed Alcoholic Beverage Hearing Board in Howard County.
“Hearing Board member” means a member of the Appointed Alcoholic Beverage Hearing Board in Howard County.
“Liquor Board” means the Board of License Commissioners for Howard County.

subsection.text: The County Council for Howard County shall ex officio constitute on a permanent basis the Board of License Commissioners for Howard County.

paragraph.text: There is an Appointed Alcoholic Beverage Hearing Board in Howard County.

Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Liquor Board shall delegate to the Hearing Board its authority to conduct hearings and render decisions on cases involving alcoholic beverage licensees in the county.
The Hearing Board consists of five members, one from each councilmanic district.

subparagraph.text: Not more than three members shall be registered with the same political party.

Each political party that polled at least 25% of the total vote cast for all candidates for the office of County Executive in the most recent general election shall have at least one representative on the Hearing Board.

If a political party that polled at least 25% of the total vote cast for all candidates for the office of County Executive in the most recent general election does not have at least one representative on the Hearing Board, the next vacancy on the Hearing Board shall be filled with an individual registered with that party.
Each member of the County Council shall nominate to the County Executive three qualified individuals who live in the district of the member of the County Council.
The County Executive shall appoint to the Hearing Board one individual from the list of nominees that each member of the County Council submits.
The County Council by resolution shall confirm the appointment of Hearing Board members.

paragraph.text: To qualify for appointment as a Hearing Board member, an individual shall be:

subparagraph.text: Of good moral character and integrity;
A registered voter of the county immediately prior to the appointment; and
At least 21 years of age.

paragraph.text: A Hearing Board member may not hold another public office or be employed by the Howard County government.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a Hearing Board member may not have a direct or indirect interest in any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured or sold, or in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages.
A Hearing Board member may be a holder of a 1–day or 2–day alcoholic beverage license.

paragraph.text: A Hearing Board member is required to be a registered voter of the county during the Hearing Board member’s term of office.

subparagraph.text: Except for the terms of some of the initial Hearing Board members, the term of a Hearing Board member is 5 years.
The terms of Hearing Board members are staggered as required by the terms provided for Hearing Board members on October 1, 1998.

paragraph.text: A Hearing Board member who is appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve the remainder of the unexpired term.
A Hearing Board member whose term has expired and who has served 8 or more consecutive years on the Hearing Board is not eligible for immediate reappointment to the Hearing Board.

The County Council may remove a Hearing Board member for incompetence, misconduct, neglect of a duty required by law, unprofessional conduct, dishonorable conduct, a violation of any of the provisions of paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection or failure to meet the qualifications of subsection (c)(6)(i), (ii), or (iii) of this section.
From among its members, the Hearing Board shall elect a chairperson.

subparagraph.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Hearing Board is a quorum.
A majority of the authorized membership of the Hearing Board is needed to take action.

paragraph.text: The Hearing Board shall meet at least once each month and may meet more often if needed.
The compensation of the Hearing Board members for the performance of their duties shall be:

subparagraph.text: For the chairperson, $55 per meeting attended, not to exceed $1,300 in a fiscal year regardless of the number of meetings attended; and
For other Hearing Board members, $50 per meeting attended, not to exceed $1,200 in a fiscal year regardless of the number of meetings attended; and

paragraph.text: The compensation of the Liquor Board members for the performance of their duties shall be:

subparagraph.text: For the chairperson, $55 per meeting attended, not to exceed $1,300 in a fiscal year regardless of the number of meetings attended; and
For other Liquor Board members, $50 per meeting attended, not to exceed $1,200 in a fiscal year regardless of the number of meetings attended.

paragraph.text: Personnel needed to carry out the duties of the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board shall be:

subparagraph.text: Included in the staff of the County Council; and
Supervised by the County Council Administrator.

paragraph.text: The Chief of the County Police Department shall provide a sworn member of the County Police Department as an inspector to assist the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board in carrying out their responsibilities and in enforcing the law.

subsection.text: The Hearing Board shall propose reasonable regulations to enable it to discharge its duties, including the issuance of alcoholic beverage licenses, and shall submit proposed regulations to the Liquor Board for approval.

paragraph.text: The Hearing Board and the Liquor Board shall submit an annual budget request to the County Council not later than January 15 in each year for the ensuing fiscal year.
A budget request shall include:

subparagraph.text: Salaries of the chairperson and Hearing Board members;
Compensation of personnel assigned to the Hearing Board; and
Expenses for office supplies, equipment, and services necessary for carrying out the responsibilities of the Hearing Board.

The County Council shall review the budget requests and shall submit budgets for the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board to the County Executive in the amounts that the County Council determines are adequate to support the duties and responsibilities of the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board.

The County Executive shall include the budget for the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board as submitted by the County Council in the county budget that is prepared in accordance with Article VI of the Howard County Charter.

subsection.text: A member or employee of the Hearing Board and the Liquor Board is subject to the public ethics laws of the county.

paragraph.text: After the Hearing Board proposes a decision regarding any case before it, a party or other participant in the case or other person who would be aggrieved by the decision may request the Liquor Board to conduct a hearing and make a final decision on the case.
A person that makes a request to the Liquor Board must:

subparagraph.text: Make the request in writing;
Include a copy of the proposed decision and order;
State the reasons why the person believes that the proposed decision is wrong; and
Send a copy of the request and accompanying materials to all other parties in the case.

paragraph.text: If a request is submitted to the Liquor Board, the proposed decision of the Hearing Board is stayed.

After a request for a hearing is submitted to the Liquor Board, any other party to the proceeding may submit to the Liquor Board a response stating why the proposed decision by the Hearing Board should be upheld.

subsection.text: After the period to file a response ends, the Liquor Board shall:

paragraph.text: Schedule a public meeting to decide whether to hear the case; and
Notify the parties of the meeting date.

subsection.text: The proposed decision of the Hearing Board becomes final if:

paragraph.text: No request for a hearing is submitted to the Liquor Board within the time allotted for a request; or
The Liquor Board decides not to hear the case.
After deciding to hear a case, the Liquor Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Schedule a hearing de novo at which the Liquor Board may hear witnesses; and
Notify the parties of the hearing date.

paragraph.text: After the close of the hearing record, the Liquor Board shall issue to the parties a final decision.

subsection.text: The Hearing Board shall give the Liquor Board regular and prompt notice of the filing of:

paragraph.text: Each application for an alcoholic beverage license or change in license; and
Each petition alleging that a violation of an alcoholic beverage law or regulation has occurred.

subsection.text: By giving notice to the Hearing Board and the applicant or the affected licensee, the Liquor Board may:

paragraph.text: Assume initial jurisdiction of any matter before the Hearing Board; and
Hear the case in the first instance when the Liquor Board determines that exercising initial jurisdiction is desirable and in the public interest.

A holder of a license, a person applying for an alcoholic beverage license, or a person engaged in the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages may not directly or indirectly offer to pay a commission, profit, or remuneration or make a gift of more than nominal value to:

subparagraph.text: A member of the Hearing Board or of the Liquor Board;
An employee of the member of the Hearing Board or of the Liquor Board; or
An agent acting on behalf of a member of the Hearing Board or of the Liquor Board or employee assigned to the Hearing Board or the Liquor Board.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than $1,000.

section.text: In Garrett County, the Liquor Control Board is hereby declared to be a State agency to administer the provisions of this article and as such is clothed with discretionary powers, in granting, refusing, revoking or suspending licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages, within the limits prescribed under this article.
The Wicomico County Board of License Commissioners is a State agency that administers this article and may grant, refuse, revoke, or suspend licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages.

subsection.text: The salaries of the members of the boards of license commissioners are specified in this section. Where no salary is specified for those boards which serve ex officio, the members may not receive additional compensation under the provisions of this section.
In Allegany County the annual salary of the members of the Board of License Commissioners shall be set by the County Commissioners in accordance with Article 24, Title 12, Subtitle 1 of the Code.

In Anne Arundel County the chairman of the Board of License Commissioners shall receive annually as salary not more than $18,000; each other member of the Board shall receive annually as salaries not more than $15,000, plus reimbursement for expenses reasonably incurred by them.
In Baltimore City:

paragraph.text: The chairman of the Board shall receive an annual salary of $28,500, and the other members of the Board shall receive an annual salary of $28,000.
The chairman and the other members of the Board are eligible to receive the same health benefits that full–time liquor inspectors of the Board receive.
The Board shall appoint an executive secretary and a deputy executive secretary whose salaries shall be fixed by the Board, subject to approval by the State Comptroller.
The executive secretary and the deputy executive secretary shall be residents of Baltimore City and of high character and integrity.

The executive secretary and the deputy executive secretary shall be appointed upon the basis of their executive skill and ability and once appointed shall hold office during good behavior regardless of changes in members constituting the Board. They shall be removed only for incompetency or immorality upon charges furnished in writing by the Board setting forth the grounds for dismissal and after opportunity for hearing.
Either the executive secretary or the deputy executive secretary shall be a member of the Bar of this State.

subsection.text: In Baltimore County:

paragraph.text: The salaries of the members of the Board of License Commissioners shall be as determined from time to time by “Baltimore County, Maryland”, in such amounts as are deemed reasonable and proper, but the annual salary of the chairman shall be not less than $11,500 and the annual salary of each of the associate members shall be not less than $10,500.

The Board of License Commissioners may appoint an executive secretary. The salary of the executive secretary shall be paid from the liquor license appropriation in the Baltimore County budget in an amount set forth under grade 27, step 3, and such longevity benefits as the executive secretary to the Board may be entitled.

subsection.text: In Calvert County:

paragraph.text: The chairman of the Board shall receive $4,200 annually for expenses incurred while carrying on the duties of the office;
The regular members of the Board shall receive $3,600 annually for expenses incurred while carrying on the duties of the office; and

The alternate Board member shall receive $200 compensation for each meeting of the Board attended as an acting regular member to compensate for expenses incurred while carrying on the duties of the office.

subsection.text: In Caroline County:

paragraph.text: The members of the Board of License Commissioners shall receive annual salaries as determined by the County Commissioners, but not less than:

subparagraph.text: $3,000 for the chairman; and
$2,500 for a regular Board member.

paragraph.text: The alternate member of the Board shall receive $100 per meeting but not more than $2,000 in any 1–year period.
The chairman, associate members and substitute member shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: In Carroll County, the annual salaries for the members of the Board of License Commissioners are set by the Carroll County Commissioners.

paragraph.text: In Cecil County, the Chairman of the Board of License Commissioners shall receive an annual salary of $3,000.
Each of the other members shall receive an annual salary in the amount of $2,500.
The Chairman and each member shall be reimbursed for expenses in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations.
The expenses shall be paid by the Commissioners.

subsection.text: In Charles County:

paragraph.text: The County Commissioners shall set the salaries of the chairman and the associate members of the Board of License Commissioners.

The County Commissioners also shall provide a clerk, counsel, and supplies to the Board as the County Commissioners consider appropriate. The County Commissioners may set salaries for the clerk and counsel as the County Commissioners consider appropriate.

subsection.text: In Dorchester County, the annual compensation for the members of theBoard of License Commissioners is:

paragraph.text: $3,000 for the Chairman; and
$2,500 for each regular member.

subsection.text: In Frederick County, the salary of the Board of License Commissioners is provided for in § 15–103 of this article.
In Garrett County the members of the Board of County Commissioners may not receive additional compensation for their services in acting as members of the Board of License Commissioners.
In Harford County the provisions of subsection (a) of this section apply.
Repealed.

In Kent County each member of the Board of County Commissioners shall receive, in addition to their salaries as County Commissioners, $300 per year for their services in acting as members of the Board of License Commissioners.
In Montgomery County, each member of the Board of License Commissioners shall receive $9,000 per year, except the chairman who shall receive $10,000 per year.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Prince George’s County.

subparagraph.text: Each of the members of the Board shall receive an annual salary of $17,000.
The chairman shall receive an annual salary of $18,000.

paragraph.text: The Board shall meet at least two times per month.

subparagraph.text: The administrator of the Board shall be appointed by and serve at the will of the Board and shall devote full time and attention to the duties of the Board.
The administrator may receive an annual salary of $40,705 as determined by the Board of License Commissioners after a performance evaluation.
The attorney for the Board shall be appointed by, and serve at the will of, the Board.
The attorney shall receive an annual salary of $15,500.
In addition to the annual salary designated in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the County Council shall pay to the attorney for the Board:

sub-subparagraph.text: All court costs and expenses incurred therein by the attorney to the Board; and
Legal fees that the Board approves for representing the Board in court.

subparagraph.text: The Board shall establish the fee rate for representing the Board in court.
The County Council shall pay for all expenses of the Board of License Commissioners upon the submission of an annual budget.

In that budget, the salary of the members of the Board, the salary of the attorney for the Board, and any additional compensation for legal fees for the attorney for the Board, shall be approved as hereinbefore set forth.

Except as provided in subparagraph (iv) of this paragraph, all other expenses, including, but not restricted to, the salary of the administrator as limited herein, compensation of other personnel, who shall be qualified and employed under the county merit system, printing, supplies, and office space, shall be at the discretion of the County Council.
Each inspector shall receive an annual salary of $10,900.
Members of the Board of Alcoholic Beverages License Commissioners and the attorney for the Board are eligible for:

sub-subparagraph.text: All county health benefits; and
Membership in and retirement benefits of the State Employees’ Pension System.

subparagraph.text: The health benefits under this paragraph include:

sub-subparagraph.text: Hospitalization;
Vision care;
Prescriptions;
Dental care;
Life insurance; and
Expense reimbursement.

subparagraph.text: The administrator of the Board of License Commissioners is eligible to participate in the County’s supplemental retirement plan.
The County Executive and the County Council may not adopt, either through public local law or personnel law, any policy contrary to the provisions of subparagraph (i) or (iii) of this paragraph.

paragraph.text: In Queen Anne’s County, the compensation for the Board of License Commissioners shall be at the rate to be determined by the County Commissioners.
The rate may not be less than:

subparagraph.text: $65 per meeting for the chairman; and
$60 per meeting for each regular member.

subsection.text: In St. Mary’s County the provisions of subsection (a) of this section apply.

paragraph.text: In Somerset County each of the members of the Board, except the chairman, shall receive an annual salary of $3,000, and the chairman shall receive an annual salary of $3,500.
The County Commissioners shall provide a sum sufficient to pay for the salaries of the members of the Board.
The County Commissioners may provide a sum sufficient to pay for all expenses of the Board, including:

subparagraph.text: Salaries of personnel other than members of the Board; and
Costs of printing, supplies, and other expenses related to the operation of the Board.

paragraph.text: In Talbot County each member of the Board shall receive as compensation a salary of $500 per year.
In addition, the chairman of the Board shall receive a salary of $250 per year.
This subsection applies only in Washington County.
The annual salaries for the Board of License Commissioners are:

subparagraph.text: Chairman – $9,850; and
Members – $9,600.

paragraph.text: The salaries specified in this subsection are payable monthly from the license fees derived from the issuance of licenses authorized by this article.
A member or employee of the Board may not have any pecuniary or other interest in any phase of the manufacture, sale or distribution of any alcoholic beverages.
This subsection applies only in Wicomico County.
The annual compensation for the Board of License Commissioners is:

subparagraph.text: Chairman – $5,000.
Members – $4,000.

subsection.text: In Worcester County:

paragraph.text: The regular members of the Board of License Commissioners shall receive an annual salary as determined by the County Commissioners but no less than:

subparagraph.text: Chairman – $2,500 per year; and
Each regular member – $2,100 per year; and

paragraph.text: The alternate member of the Board shall receive compensation, as determined by the County Commissioners, for services when acting on the Board.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove any member of any board of license commissioners appointed by him under the provisions of this article, for misconduct in office, incompetency or willful neglect of duty, giving him a copy of the charges against him and an opportunity of being publicly heard in person, or by counsel, in his own defense, upon not less than ten days’ notice. If any member shall be removed, the Governor shall file in the office of the Secretary of State, a statement of the charges made against such member and his findings thereon.

The board of county commissioners may remove any member of any board of license commissioners appointed by them, for the causes in this section prescribed. In Montgomery County, the County Executive may, with the approval of the County Council, remove any member of the Board of License Commissioners for the causes in this section prescribed.
The provisions of this section do not apply to the following:

paragraph.text: Class E (steamboats);
Class F (railroads); and
Class G (airplanes).

subsection.text: The provisions of this section apply to Wicomico County.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners shall issue licenses for which provision is made in this article.
The director of finance shall collect the license fees for which provision is made in this article.
The boards of license commissioners in this State may issue the alcoholic beverages licenses provided for by this article in their respective jurisdictions.
Each board may employ a secretary and inspectors, clerical and other assistance as is necessary, and fix the compensation of the employees, except as otherwise provided by this article.
In this section, “Board” means the Board of License Commissioners, unless otherwise noted.
This subsection applies only in Allegany County.
The inspectors shall:

subparagraph.text: Have all the powers of a peace officer or a constable or sheriff of this State;
Make oath to faithfully perform the duties entrusted to them, as provided in Article I, § 9 of the Constitution of this State; and

Furnish bond in the penalty of $2,000 to the Board and the Board of County Commissioners jointly, conditioned, “that inspectors shall well and faithfully execute the office in all things appertaining thereto”. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the County Commissioners. The inspectors shall be known as “alcoholic beverage inspectors for Allegany County”.
This subsection applies only in Anne Arundel County.
Except for paragraph (2) of this subsection, it does not apply in the City of Annapolis.
This paragraph applies only in the City of Annapolis.

The Mayor, Counsellor and Aldermen of Annapolis may make and enforce regulations and restrictions, in addition to, or in substitution of, those contained in this article, but not inconsistent therewith, as in their judgment would give the municipality more effective control of each of the places of business.

In addition to the powers given to the Board in subsection (a) of this section, the Board may employ one part–time chief inspector at an annual salary of $10,000, one part–time deputy chief inspector at an annual salary of $8,000 and 18 part–time inspectors at an annual salary of $6,000 each.
In addition to a salary stated in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, each of the inspectors shall receive a monthly expense of $300 per month, subject to the approval of the State Comptroller.

paragraph.text: The 20 inspectors shall:

subparagraph.text: Have all the powers of a peace officer or a constable or sheriff of this State;
Make oath to faithfully perform the duties entrusted to them, as provided in Article I, § 9 of the Constitution of this State; and

Furnish bond in the penalty of $2,000 to the Board and the County Council jointly, conditioned “that inspector shall well and faithfully execute the office in all things appertaining thereto”. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the county. The inspectors for Anne Arundel County are known as the “liquor inspectors for Anne Arundel County”.

paragraph.text: The Board of License Commissioners:

subparagraph.text: May employ up to two full–time administrators whose annual salaries shall be fixed by the Board as in a general Anne Arundel County classified salary schedule, within pay grade 16;
Shall employ a full–time secretary whose annual salary shall be fixed by the Board as in a general county classified salary schedule, within pay grade 13; and
Shall employ an attorney at an annual salary of $20,000.

The Board of License Commissioners may suspend immediately an alcoholic beverages license if a person authorized under § 16–405 of this article alleges that the licensee has sold or furnished alcoholic beverages to a person under the age of 21 years with such frequency and during such a limited time period so as to demonstrate a willful failure to comply with § 12–108(a) of this article.
A suspension under this paragraph may not exceed 7 days.
If a license is suspended under this paragraph, the Board shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: Hold a hearing on the matter within 7 days after the suspension; and
Give notice to the licensee at least 2 days before the hearing.

subparagraph.text: If the Board fails to provide the licensee with notice of a hearing before the end of the fifth day following a suspension, the suspension shall end, and the licensee shall be allowed to resume the sale of alcoholic beverages on the next day allowed under the license.
This paragraph does not prevent a licensee whose license is suspended under this paragraph from seeking an injunction or other appropriate relief.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Baltimore City.
A commissioner or employee of the Board:

subparagraph.text: May not have any interest, direct or indirect, either proprietary or by means of any loan, mortgage or lien, or in any other manner, in or on any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured, distributed, or sold;
May not have any interest, direct or indirect, in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture, distribution, or sale of alcoholic beverages;

May not own any stock in any corporation which has any interest, proprietary or otherwise, direct or indirect, in any premises where alcoholic beverages are manufactured, distributed, or sold or in any business wholly or partially devoted to the manufacture, distribution, or sale of alcoholic beverages; or
May not receive any salary or other compensation or any other thing of value from a business engaged in the manufacture, distribution, or sale of alcoholic beverages.

paragraph.text: An employee of the Board may not hold any other federal, State, or local public office or employment.
A commissioner of the Board may hold any other public office or employment, federal, State or local, unless that public office or employment would pose a conflict of interest.

subparagraph.text: Every employee of the Board:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall devote that employee’s whole time and attention to the business of the Board during the hours designated by the Board for the performance of official duties;
May not engage in any occupation, business or profession in any way connected or associated, directly or indirectly, with the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages; and

May not transact business of any kind whatsoever beyond his or her official duties with any licensee, or in connection with the operation of any establishment licensed for the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages.

subparagraph.text: Any employee of the Board who violates any of the provisions of this subsection shall be removed.

As to any entity licensed under the provisions of this article, a commissioner or employee of the Board may not solicit or receive directly or indirectly any commission, remuneration or gift whatsoever from any:

sub-subparagraph.text: Person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages;
Agent or employee of that person or corporation; or
Licensee licensed under the provisions of this article.

subparagraph.text: A person or corporation engaged in the manufacture or sale of beer or other alcoholic beverages, any agent or employee of that person or corporation, and a licensee licensed under the provisions of this article may not, either directly or indirectly, offer to pay any commission, profit or remuneration or make any gift to any commissioner or employee of the Board or to anyone on behalf of that commissioner or employee of the Board.

paragraph.text: The chairman of the Board:

subparagraph.text: Is its administrative officer and is charged with the duty of enforcing the provisions of this article;
Shall personally supervise the activities and investigations of the several inspectors and other employees of the Board;
Shall examine the location and general character of the licensees in the City; and
Shall make recommendations to the Board concerning zoning of licensees, methods of enforcement, and promulgation of regulations to carry out the purposes of this article.

paragraph.text: Regulations adopted by the Board shall be published and distributed to whichever licensees are affected by them. The Board may require any licensee to display prominently in the licensee’s place of business any regulation of the Board, or any excerpt or statement from this article.
The Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Employ 12 permanent part–time inspectors; and
Set the annual salary for permanent part–time inspectors at not less than $3,600.

paragraph.text: The Board shall:

subparagraph.text: Employ a qualified attorney to serve as appellate counsel for the Board in actions of appeal; and
Set for appellate counsel the same compensation and benefits as are set for the Assistant Chief Inspector–Grade 097 or the Chief Inspector–Grade 099.

sub-subparagraph.text: In this paragraph, “inspectors” means full–time inspectors who are employees of the Board. “Inspectors” does not include an inspector supervisor or assistant inspector supervisor.
Inspectors who were appointed prior to October 1, 1997, shall continue their appointment after that date unless removed in accordance with classified civil service procedures.

subparagraph.text: As of October 1, 1997:

sub-subparagraph.text: Inspectors are part of the classified civil service of the City;
The Board may appoint and remove inspectors only in accordance with the provisions of law that govern classified civil service employees of the City;
An employee of the Board may not solicit or receive, directly or indirectly or on behalf of another person, a commission, political contribution, remuneration, or gift from:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: A licensee or other person who is engaged in the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages; or
An agent or employee of a licensee or other person who is engaged in the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages; and

sub-subparagraph.text: An employee or other person specified in sub–subparagraph 3 of this subparagraph who violates the provisions of that sub–subparagraph is subject to the penalties specified in § 16–503 of this article.

subparagraph.text: The provisions of this paragraph do not alter the process by which inspectors’ salaries are funded.
The inspector supervisor and assistant inspector supervisor shall be residents of Baltimore City.

The inspector supervisor, assistant inspector supervisor, office assistant, accounting assistant, secretary III, office supervisor, and applications investigator appointed prior to October 1, 1998 shall continue their appointment after that date unless removed in accordance with classified civil service procedures.
As of October 1, 1998:

sub-subparagraph.text: The inspector supervisor, assistant inspector supervisor, office assistant, accounting assistant, secretary III, and office supervisor are part of the classified civil service of Baltimore City.

There shall be an assistant executive secretary which position shall replace the position of administrative coordinator. The assistant executive secretary shall be part of the classified civil service of Baltimore City.

subparagraph.text: Subject to the provisions in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the salaries of employees of the Board shall be determined by the members of the Board with the advice and consent of the senators from Baltimore City.
The Board may consider an employee’s length of service in determining the appropriate salary level.

paragraph.text: The following is the schedule of City Union of Baltimore (CUB) salary grade levels for employees of the Board:

subparagraph.text: Office Assistant – Grade 082;
Inspector I – Grade 082;
Inspection Division Office Assistant – Grade 082;
Inspector II – Grade 085;
Accounting Assistant II – Grade 085;
Secretary III – Grade 086;
311 Call Center Supervisor – Grade 093;
Inspector III – Grade 088;
Assistant Executive Secretary – Grade 099;
Assistant Chief Inspector – Grade 097; and
Chief Inspector – Grade 099.

Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, each inspector employed by the Board may examine any identification used as proof of age by a person for the purchase of alcoholic beverages in the City.
An examination shall be made on the premises of the licensed establishment where the purchase is attempted.

paragraph.text: An action of a commissioner or employee of the Board is subject to State requirements for open or public meetings, including requirements for open sessions under Title 10, Subtitle 5 of the State Government Article.
This subsection applies only in Baltimore County.

The Board may appoint a Chief License Inspector and at least 14 license inspectors. The salaries shall be as determined by the county, but the salary of the Chief License Inspector may not be less than $9,500 a year and the salary of each of the remaining license inspectors may not be less than $9,000 a year. Each license inspector and the Chief License Inspector may request and examine any identification used as proof of age by any person for the purchase of alcoholic beverages provided that the request and examination are made on the licensed premises in the county.
In addition to the other powers and duties conferred on them, the Board may prescribe regulations:

subparagraph.text: Regarding the presence of any person not designated under § 1–102(a)(6) of this article on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages; and
Concerning the granting and the date of issuing licenses when the actual use of the license is to be deferred until the completion of construction work or alterations on the premises.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Calvert County.
The Board may appoint:

subparagraph.text: A clerk and an attorney at a salary to be set by the County Commissioners; and

With the approval of the County Commissioners, full–time or part–time alcoholic beverages inspectors whose salary shall be set by the County Commissioners on an annual or per diem basis, and who shall be paid reasonable expenses related to performance of duties.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Caroline County.

subparagraph.text: The county codes administrator is the inspector for the Board of License Commissioners.

The salary of the inspector shall be as provided in the county budget. The duties of the inspector shall be as specified by the Board, including the proper administration and enforcement of the alcoholic beverages laws of Caroline County.
The Board may appoint an attorney for the Board.
The compensation for the attorney shall be set by the County Commissioners.
The attorney is subject to the county ethics ordinance.

subsection.text: Reserved.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Cecil County.
The Board shall issue all retail alcoholic beverages licenses authorized under this article, except Class E, F, and G licenses.

The Board may employ one full–time alcoholic beverages inspector and may also employ as many additional part–time alcoholic beverages inspectors as it deems necessary. The salary shall be as provided in the annual budget of the Board of County Commissioners for part–time inspectors and within the total appropriations for this purpose. The employment of the alcoholic beverages inspectors shall be subject to the provisions of the Cecil County Personnel Policy and Procedure Manual. The salaries and travel expenses of the alcoholic beverages inspectors shall be established by the Board of County Commissioners of Cecil County using county personnel department regulations and guidelines.

The inspector shall investigate all applicants for an alcoholic beverages license or transfer of license, enforce all alcoholic beverages laws, and investigate all violations of the alcoholic beverages laws and report them to the Board.
The inspector shall:

subparagraph.text: Have all the powers of a peace officer of this State in respect to the enforcement of the alcoholic beverages laws of the county;
Make an oath, as provided in the Constitution of Maryland, to faithfully perform the duties entrusted to him;
Visit and inspect at unannounced times every licensed premises in the county at least every 90 days; and
Make monthly reports in writing to the Board covering his activities, setting forth any complaints, and listing any violations that may have been observed or reported to the inspector.

paragraph.text: A person may not accept appointment or continue as an inspector if either the inspector or any member of the inspector’s immediate family has any personal or financial interest either directly or indirectly in any license or in any licensed premises under the provisions of this article.
This subsection applies only in Charles County.
The Board is the alcoholic beverages license issuing authority.
This subsection applies only in Dorchester County.

subparagraph.text: A member or employee of the Board may not:

sub-subparagraph.text: Have any financial interest, directly or indirectly, in the manufacture of any alcoholic beverage or in any alcoholic beverage purchased or sold under the provisions of this article; or

Derive any profit or remuneration from the purchase or sale of any alcoholic beverage, other than the salary or wages payable for the performance of the duties of the office or position as required and authorized under this section.

subparagraph.text: A person who violates this paragraph is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,000 or a term of imprisonment not exceeding 30 days.
With the approval of the Dorchester County Council, the Board may employ an inspector and a recording secretary who shall be employees of the county as provided in the county budget.
With the approval of the Dorchester County Council, the Board may appoint legal counsel.
Restrictions applicable to Board members shall apply to legal counsel and staff assigned to the Board.
County personnel policies and rules shall apply to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Staff assigned to the Board; and
Board and staff expenses.

subparagraph.text: Board and staff expenses shall be provided for in the county budget.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Frederick County.
The appointment of an inspector and the employment of clerical assistants are provided for in § 15–103 of this article.

subsection.text: Reserved.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Harford County.

In addition to any inspector who is serving prior to July 1, 1979, the Board and general manager may appoint additional inspectors as necessary to provide appropriate control over newly created Class A off–sale licensees.

subsection.text: Repealed.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only in Kent County.

Notwithstanding §§ 10–401 and 10–403 of this article, the Board may suspend any alcoholic beverages license for any violation of this article for not less than 15 nor more than 90 days. An appeal does not stay the order of the Board suspending a license.
The Board:

subparagraph.text: Shall employ one full–time alcoholic beverages inspector whose salary shall be set by the County Commissioners; and
May employ one additional part–time or full–time alcoholic beverages inspector whose compensation shall be set by the County Commissioners.
